urn:contentItem:5X7V-R4X1-F00X-J3G8-00000-00Jim Cramer: What Would Make a Good Stock in This Environment?2019-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJim Cramer: What Would Make a Good Stock in This Environment?Jim Cramer

Let me give you the items I want to see before I bless buying anything in what has become a plain, out and out, treacherous market.

We need better reasons than what we have to buy most stocks. We need something more concrete to expect or anticipate than this economy and this world can give us.

This morning I went over 300 stocks - three hundred stocks! - with an eye toward finding a new stock to introduce to members of the Action Alerts PLUS club where I give a talk each month and offer a compelling idea.

You know how many I found? How about four. That's right, four stocks that I think could survive the tests that I am looking for.

What would make a good stock in this environment? Let me give you the items I want to see before I bless buying anything in what has become a plain, out and out, treacherous market.

First, I want a stock that does not need a trade deal to make me money. As these talks drag on the list of those impacted grows and grows. Earlier this week we had David Farr on, the long-service CEO of Emerson , and I think the company might be willing to do something big, literally split in half, if management thinks that it can bring out value. Classically that's great and worth buying, if the fundamentals allow you to hold it through the process.

However, I don't think you can do that with Emerson. Farr's been a visionary. He has a gigantic presence in China because he correctly anticipated that's where the growth will be. But he, along with pretty much everyone else, didn't see the dramatic shift in policy when President Trump came into office. What do you do now? Hope things blow over? Hope the Chinese economy isn't hurt too badly? Hope that your factories aren't expropriated and your executives kicked out of China? What a terrible parade of potential horribles awaits the most forward thinking U.S. manufacturer.

To me Emerson has become binary: a deal no deal situation and that makes the stock too difficult to own.

China can be totally toxic. Remember when the 2% of Cisco business that was China played a role in its shortfall last quarter? Here's Cisco going down again today and while it has become incredibly cheap how do I know that numbers aren't done coming down?

Of course the ramifications are so huge we never know when a solid story can spring a leak. Who knew that Nvidia's stock would plummet seven points because our government is cracking down on technologies that could be used for facial recognition against Muslim enemies of the Chinese state? What would have happened if Apple hadn't pulled its app showing where police were located in Hong Kong because it puts its policy in jeopardy violating its safety promise? How about if you are a retailer without the clout of a WATCH, a Walmart , Amazon , Target , Costco or Home Depot ? How about if you are a supplier who can't switch supply chains fast enough ahead of the next round of tariff increases next week? When I was flipping through the S&P a huge number of stocks had one or more of these flash points.

Next, am I about to buy a stock that's going to be disrupted by those who play with free money? Think about Domino's the other day when CEO Ritch Allison talked about how third party delivery companies are willing to lose big money to get business with companies that Domino's competes with. Domino's has the best distribution system in the food delivery business but it can't compete effectively with a pizza chain that has a delivery option that's sold below the cost of delivery because the venture funds backing the company are insensitive to anything but scale. Where does that leave the publicly traded GrubHub ? How about near the 52 week low list?

There are disruptions going on all over the place. Amazon has disrupted freight deliverers like FedEx . Online and off price retailers have disrupted traditional brick and mortar companies like Macy's and Kohl's . Merck has disrupted the oncology protocols with Keytruda. Wind and solar have disrupted coal and natural gas. Pipelines have disrupted crude by rail. Roku has disrupted traditional cable. Facebook and Alphabet have crushed newspapers and magazines. Rent the Runway has disrupted clothes buying. Harry's and Dollar Shave have disrupted razors. And most visible of all? Cloud and its derivatives are crushing anything on premise.

It's tough to be worried about something that hasn't happened but there are fewer and fewer stocks of companies that are immune to disruption.

Some markets can't be sold into and therefore some stocks can't be owned. GM's on strike. I didn't want to own any stock of a company that sells into autos to begin with. Now with a strike that's expected to linger anything from a paint company to a glass company to a seat company to a parts company to a steel company to an aluminum company to a plastics company is likely to miss numbers. You can't miss numbers in this environment.

Then there's Boeing's woes. There are so many companies that make parts for airplanes that they are too numerous to list. But you will soon hear from them and they will all tell the street to lower numbers. Total no-fly zone.

Fossil fuels? They are toxic wherever they are found, whether they are involved in the drilling, the servicing, the packaging, the piping and, of course, the actual liquids. Of course this extends to plastic, which the millennial fund managers think is the new coal.

Finally, there's the Warren factor. This is the one that fund managers can't stop talking about. She's a one person disruptor in the eyes of Wall Street. Single Payor? The end of managed care and the beginning of the end of big profits for drug stocks. Banks? Break-ups and re-regulations. Fracking? Out of the question, which eliminates any growth that's left from the fossil fuel cohort. Big tech? Massive antitrust investigations.

Fund managers fear for their own livelihood if Warren is elected.

I think all of this is alarmist. I do think that Warren stands for ending the great wealth disparities in this country and that is a very popular view among all but the millionaire and billionaires.

But my view means absolutely nothing when it comes to what Wall Street regards as the second coming of Lenin or at least a mixture of Huey Long and Mary "raise less corn and more hell" Lease.

Now the problem isn't that there are no stocks to find given those off-limits parameters. There are. There's just not enough of them. They are too hard to find. And because there are so many that are in trouble or potential trouble you are not going to be immune from huge waves of S&P futures selling. Sure, you can buy the stocks of companies that can escape the grim reaper after they are knocked down by endless S&P futures tsunamis. But then when the next wave occurs you just go down again with them.

Of course, we could get a trade deal of sorts. I think it is possible that the President forestalls the next round of tariffs if the Chinese give him any concessions, including a buy of something like all the hogs we produce given that the African Swine Flu has decimated the supply which is vital to the Chinese.

But then there will just be another deadline and another set of talks and another rinse and repeat. And throughout the water torture bankers will heap more and more supply on the market with hapless Smile Direct like IPOs.

It's an unhealthy moment with the only saving grace being that I don't know a soul who feels it isn't. Sentiment is so negative. But occasionally, rarely, the sentiment is correct. If we don't do some sort of trade deal on the President's terms, then the sentiment will be right.

(Cisco, Nvidia, Apple, Amazon. Home Depot, Kohl's, Facebook and Alphabet are holdings in Jim Cramer's . Want to be alerted before Jim Cramer buys or sells these stocks? )

urn:contentItem:5VMJ-FD61-JDPH-B3HP-00000-00Jim Duffy comment: Is cryptocurrency heading for the mainstream?2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJim Duffy comment: Is cryptocurrency heading for the mainstream?Jim Duffy

Cryptocurrency and crypto ­markets are still bubbling away, despite what is being called a bear market ruling the day.

After the fever pitch rises of 2017, these markets have gone ­quiet. The companies behind the currencies are beavering away to create essentially great investable companies. But, are you ready yet to buy into the crypto markets?

As I write, the cryptocurrency ­market cap is hovering at around $134 billion (£102bn). There are more than 2,100 cryptocurrencies listed and Bitcoin has market dominance of 51 per cent. While the value of this market is way off its peak, many investors are still in for the long term.

The carpetbaggers and millennials who were hoping for their small holdings to go "to the moon" have since all gone quiet. No longer the lengthy chats in crypto chatrooms about this coin or that token rocketing. No, it's radio silence. Well almost...

I have a small holding in crypto and as I have written here before, my favourite is Tron. To be clear, this is no recommendation, and you should always do your own research. I am hoping one day in the next ten years that this particular coin will grow and I can have a surprise pension enhancement.

To be honest, I had forgotten about it as it was a small investment. Somewhat speculative, if you will. But, only last week I received a text from one of those millennial types who had laughed his socks off when I bought Tron initially. Not only did he chortle, but he told others how funny it was watching an old fart dabble in the cryptocurrency markets and buy an ­outsider with no real hope. Yes, it did feel like taking a punt on a 200/1 shot in the Grand National. But, what a surprise to hear from the laughing laddie again.

The text read: "I'm hearing great things about Dapps. Hope you still have your Tron." This was as close to an endorsement that I was going to get. But, it made me curious as to how the crypto world was performing. Dapps, by the way, are ostensibly apps that run on the Tron blockchain.

The CEO of Tron, a young entrepreneur called Justin Sun, has been a busy chap. Sun has had much criticism over the last two years as he is a colourful character, not afraid to say it how it is. He has ­stellar ambitions for his company. In short, to reinvent the internet so that users, instead of Big Tech, own the content and have more control over it. He has the likes of YouTube in his sights. He has worked hard and now, it seems, has some credibility.

Tron is just one of the exciting little gems surfacing and creating companies that have purpose, potential customers, users and some form of end goal. But it has taken, and will take, a long time for these fledgling start-ups to truly be the next generation of tech. However, and this is the important element, credibility is starting to kick in. Only then will institutional investors think about putting their capital at risk.

Bitcoin, Ethereum and other larger coins have seen their values slashed and some argue that Bitcoin has no real future and may even disappear. This is where the smaller companies who are creating firms that can generate revenue and hold up to closer scrutiny see the opportunity. For too long, cryptocurrencies have had no real regulation or governance. But the new generation of crypto CEO wants this built in to the market to ease future investors nerves, while at the same time adding value to their stock. This is key to this $134bn marketplace becoming ten times that in the next ten years. Who knows, in the future, ­pension companies may hold the likes of Tron in the funds. But, not quite yet...

The USA is the key as, if it weighs in with cash, then regulation will ease nerves. Even Facebook is introducing its own cryptocurrency. Mind you, I'm not sure that will do ­anything to boost the image of crypto. Only time will tell.

Up until proper regulation, I've still got my money on the outsider at the four o'clock at Kempton. Otherwise known as Tron.

Jim Duffy, MBE, Create Special.

urn:contentItem:60G7-H9H1-F03R-N4BF-00000-00Jim Jordan's Mask, Jeff Bezos on the Hot Seat and 5 More Highlights From Big Tech Congressional Hearing2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJim Jordan's Mask, Jeff Bezos on the Hot Seat and 5 More Highlights From Big Tech Congressional HearingSean Burch

Jul 29, 2020( The Wrap: http://www.thewrap.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Wednesday's congressional hearing on potential antitrust practices among major tech companies — featuring testimony from the chief executives of Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Alphabet, Google's parent company — vacillated between insightful and downright absurd; frankly, the hearing leaned more toward the latter and appears unlikely to have a lasting impact. Together, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Apple's Tim Cook, Amazon's Jeff Bezos, and Alphabet's Sundar Pichai run companies that have a combined valuation of $4.85 trillion. There were relevant questions worth asking them about how their businesses operate — and some were asked — but on several occasions, the hearing devolved into a farce; questions about censorship decisions made by tech companies not even included in the hearing were asked, while at other times, representatives yelled at each other to wear their masks. If you missed the hearing, don't worry about it.

Here are the seven moments that stood out. Also Read: Why Movie Theater Reopenings Overseas Show 'Early Signs of Progress' for the Industry[1] 1. Censorship was a hot topic Wednesday's hearing was nominally focused on anti-competitive practices by the four tech giants. But social media censorship, as some might have expected, remained a topic several GOP congressmen preferred to discuss. Things did not get off to a great start, though. Early in the hearing, Rep. Jim Sensenbrenner (R-Wis.) asked Zuckerberg why his company had taken down Donald Trump Jr.'s recent post about hydroxychloroquine. The problem, though, was Sensenbrenner was referring to something Twitter did, not Facebook. 'I think you might be referring to what happened on Twitter,' Zuckerberg said. At other points, Zuckerberg defended Facebook's track record on censoring content, saying the company had 'distinguished ourselves as one of the companies that defends free expression the most.' He added that Facebook has no interest in being the 'arbiters of truth,' but that it remains focused on weeding out hateful content. The dividing line on Wednesday seemed to be Republicans worrying Facebook was cracking down too much on content, while Democratic representatives like Dave Cicilline ripped Facebook for not doing enough to censor hate speech. 2. Bezos had it easy — until he didn't Amazon's head honcho went nearly two hours without being asked a single question — a conspicuous length of time that many Twitter users were quick to point out. Circumstances changed, though, when Rep. Pramila Jayapal, from Amazon's home state of Washington, pressed Bezos on Amazon's business practices. 'Let me ask you, Mr. Bezos, does Amazon ever access and use seller data when making business decisions?' the Democrat asked. Bezos said Amazon's policy prohibits such a move, but that he 'can't guarantee' it's never happened. Later, Bezos was asked whether Amazon had purposely slashed the price of diapers to undermine Diapers.com; Rep. Mary Gay Scanlon (D-Penn.) said documents showed Amazon was willing to lose $200 million on selling cheap diapers to bust its competitor. Ultimately, Amazon bought Diapers.com in 2010 for $450 million. The move, according to Scanlon, was a prime example of Amazon using its weight to systematically weed out rivals. Bezos said he didn't agree with the premise, and that he didn't remember too much about the events, which happened a decade ago. The two exchanges stood out as rare moments when Wednesday's hearing seemed to stick to the script. Also Read: Triller Nears Deal to Raise at Least $200 Million[2] 3. Masks became the new muzzle There were a few testy moments, including when Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) was told to put on his mask when he took exception to Scanlon saying he was pushing 'fringe conspiracy theories' on censorship. You can see the moment below, courtesy of CBS News: "Put your mask on!" Shouting breaks out among members of the House subcommittee during tech hearing, after Rep. Mary Gay Scanlon suggests Rep. Jim Jordan is pushing "fringe conspiracy theories" https://t.co/83sKht0bRx[3] pic.twitter.com/E6fEZKT6tO[4] — CBS News (@CBSNews) July 29, 2020[5]Also Read: Triller Nears Deal to Raise at Least $200 Million[6] 4. Zuckerberg defends Instagram acquisition Zuckerberg animatedly pushed back when House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler (D-NY) said Facebook violated antitrust laws when it acquired Instagram for $1 billion in 2012. The move was not illegal, Zuckerberg said, because Facebook and Instagram had a number of competitors at the time in terms of photo-sharing apps; he also pointed out the Federal Trade Commission understood this when it approved the deal. Zuckerberg acknowledged that the deal doesn't look as fair now that Instagram has more than 1 billion users, but that the platform's success wasn't a guarantee at the time. 'I think with hindsight it looks probably obvious that Instagram would have reached the scale that it has today, but at the time it was far from obvious,' Zuckerberg said. Nadler doubled down, saying Zuckerberg's admission Instagram was a threat to Facebook's business only shows it was a corrupt deal in the first place. 'This is exactly the kind of anticompetitive acquisition that the antitrust laws were designed to prevent,' Nadler said. 'This should never have happened in the first place, this should never have been permitted to happen, and it cannot happen again.' Also Read: 8 Burning Questions for TV's Summer Press Tour: Where Are the Execs? How Much Footage Will We See?[7] 5. Pichai says Google isn't playing political favorites Despite concerns from many conservatives, Pichai said Google isn't deliberately weeding out conservative outlets from its search results. Pichai added that Google is politically 'neutral' and isn't doing anything to unfairly push stories in favor of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden at the expense of President Trump. 'We won't do any work to politically tilt anything one way or another,' Pichai said. 'It's against our core values.' His comments come after Breitbart.com editor-in-chief Alex Marlow told Fox News' Tucker Carlson his website had seen its Google-referred traffic fall off a cliff[8] since the 2016 election.; 6. No slave labor All four tech execs vowed to never use slave labor to create their products in response to a question from Rep. Ken Buck from Colorado. 'I would love to engage on the legislation with you, congressman. Let me be clear: Forced labor is abhorrent, and we would not tolerate it in Apple,' Cook said. The question wasn't completely out of the blue; Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Missouri)'s office recently said a number of global companies, including Nike, have been tied to slave labor camps of the ethnic Uighur minority in China. Considering Apple's close business ties to China, as well as Alphabet's connections to the country, the collective response was good to hear. Ultimately, Cook — the man running the world's most valuable company — had a relatively quiet day. He did defend the App Store at a few different points, saying the company may charge a 30% commission on all App Store sales, but that it's nowhere near a monopoly when it comes to the app market (or any other market). Also Read: If TikTok Gets Banned in the US, These 4 Apps Could Benefit Most[9] 7. Email problems One of the funnier moments — or bigger wastes of time, depending on your point of view — came when Rep. Greg Steube (R-Fla.) asked Pichai a simple question: Why are his campaign emails going directly to Gmail's spam folder?[10] Steube worried his parents and followers were having a hard time getting his campaign emails — and wondered if it had anything to do with an anti-Republican bias at Google. Pichai said that certainly wasn't the case, and that it merely boiled down to Gmail prioritizing emails from accounts it knew were connected to friends and family. You can see Steube's full question here: Rep. Steube complains to Google CEO about his campaign emails going to Gmail spam boxes and says that it's only happening to republicans. (No, pretty much every campaign deals with email delivery issues.) pic.twitter.com/XH1floO9ff[11] — Tony Webster (@webster) July 29, 2020[12]The exchange was a microcosm of the day. The hearing not only gravitated toward questions that weren't germane to the topic at hand, it also failed to provided few worthwhile details on whether the four companies have participated in anti-competitive practices. Don't expect much to come of Wednesday's hearing.Related stories from TheWrap: Coronavirus: The Canceled and Postponed Events in Tech, Media, Sports and Entertainment (Updating)[13]Ben & Jerry's Joins Growing Facebook Ad Boycott, Says Tech Giant Helps 'Spread and Amplify Racism'[14]Justice Department Targets Law Allowing Tech Giants to Regulate Content[15] [ 1]: https://www.thewrap.com/overseas-theater-reopenings/ [ 2]: https://www.thewrap.com/triller-nears-raise-several-hundred-million-dollars/ [ 3]: https://t.co/83sKht0bRx [ 4]: https://t.co/E6fEZKT6tO [ 5]: https://twitter.com/CBSNews/status/1288558652513820673?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 6]: https://www.thewrap.com/triller-nears-raise-several-hundred-million-dollars/ [ 7]: https://www.thewrap.com/ctam-tca-summer-press-tour-questions-executive-sessions-new-footage-the-boys-aretha/ [ 8]: https://www.breitbart.com/clips/2020/07/29/marlow-google-has-diminished-breitbart-search-results-99-7-big-tech-will-do-anything-in-their-power-to-get-biden-elected/ [ 9]: https://www.thewrap.com/four-apps-that-could-benefit-from-tiktok-ban/ [ 10]: http://www.thewrap.com/greg-steube-gmail-spam-sundar-pichai/ [ 11]: https://t.co/XH1floO9ff [ 12]: https://twitter.com/webster/status/1288555617926316032?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 13]: https://www.thewrap.com/everything-canceled-by-coronavirus/ [ 14]: https://www.thewrap.com/ben-jerrys-facebook-ad-boycott/ [ 15]: https://www.thewrap.com/justice-department-targets-law-allowing-tech-giants-to-regulate-content/

urn:contentItem:5S27-V7G1-JDPT-T2HD-00000-00JIM MCCAUGHAN, CEO, PRINCIPAL GLOBAL INVESTORS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION2018-04-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJIM MCCAUGHAN, CEO, PRINCIPAL GLOBAL INVESTORS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

April 6, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

JIM MCCAUGHAN, CEO, PRINCIPAL GLOBAL INVESTORS; ANNA EDWARDS, BLOOMBERG NEWS; NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG NEWS

CEHIC: China's state news agency vowed that Beijing would defend its interests against new U.S. actions this morning. Joining us now is Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors.

Great to see you, Jim, good morning to you --

(CROSSTALK)

MCCAUGHAN: Good morning. Great to be here.

CEHIC: Yes, thank you for giving us some of your time while you're in London. In terms of the risks around an escalation of a trade war, this is one of the sort of scenarios that you see as more of an outlier, among other things. A 20 to 30 percent probability of risk. How do you see this evolving?

MCCAUGHAN: Well, I think that the market consensus is actually, in this case, valid. Which is that the administration, President Trump in particular, are using the threat of tariffs as a bargaining counter in order to get other things.

It was very interesting, when the steel and aluminum tariffs were announced, what, three weeks ago or three or four weeks ago, you had the photo up in the Oval Office with the steelworkers.

You then went straight to Mr. Trump's comments, in which he walked back the tariffs almost immediately. He said, "Canada and Mexico are our friends, we won't target them. And the Germans might get better treatment if they pay for their own defense."

So in other words, using the tariffs as a threat to actually get other agenda items. Now. My 20 or 30 percent probability is that others call his bluff, and we end -- we end up, by default, with a rather unintended trade war. But I don't think that's the course that they think they're on.

And I think that some of the more free trade-oriented heads within government -- you're talking to Larry Kudlow later in the day -- I think many of them would actually sympathize with the idea of using tariffs as a bargaining counter.

EDWARDS: So buying very much into this argument that this is posturing, this is not where we end up, then, Jim. But things do seem to be escalating pretty quickly, don't they? I mean, the market's just getting its head around the $50 billion versus $50 billion --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- the two countries. And then we get this announcement overnight, that the Trump administration wants to investigate the possibility of further tariffs on another $100 billion of Chinese imports.

I've got this chart, 7061, which shows that, actually, it would be very difficult for China to match this toe-to-toe because of the scale of the imbalance in deficit. It would be difficult for China to find enough U.S. imports to, then, match this. So then it begs the question, how China then retaliates. What other tools do they have in their toolkit.

I mean, I wonder whether we need to get to a point where we've got a date in the diary, an announcement of a meeting, some kind of firm commitment to -- to negotiate something away from this posturing.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes. I think the negotiation is happening behind the scenes anyway. I don't think it necessarily needs President Xi to go to Mar-a-Lago for the two sides to be talking. I think there is quite a lot of conversation going on.

Having said that, it's not yet decisive and constructive conversation. And I think that's something that the market expects to develop over the next few weeks. You probably will see some sort of head-of-government-type conversation between the U.S. and China.

But it's -- it needn't be imminent. The conversations can happen. The -- the concessions can be made at a lower level and get ratified later. The market thinks that's where it's going.

But, you know, it's so political. If you look at what the Chines retaliation was, you know, soybeans and pork. That's aimed at the people who elected Trump. It's not aimed at the U.S. economy more broadly. And so it's highly politicized when you look at the specific targeting of tariffs that's been suggested.

And I think that's the clue to what's really going on, that there is this 20 or 30 percent possibility that bluffs get called, things degenerate --

CEHIC: Yes.

EDWARDS: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- and that would be very bad for the market, and quite bad for the economy.

CEHIC: Yes. And, Jim, you sort of advised to not really adjust your portfolio based on that 20 to 30 percent probability. But before we get to there with what's happening now, we've seen a lot of equity volatility, more volatility in equities than in other asset classes as we've --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: -- talked a lot about this week. I just want to take you to a chart which shows the relative performance of stocks versus bonds. And that has actually come down recently --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: -- you can see towards the end of the chart, it's coming up a little bit. In the scenario that we're in now, before we get to that 20 to 30 percent probability, how would you allocate? Would you reduce your exposure to equities, or not yet?

MCCAUGHAN: Probably not yet. I think you're -- in U.S. equities, you should be keeping up to wait (ph) because, you know, the U.S. equity market is, in terms of average rating, it's now on about between 16 and 17 times current-year earnings on the Standard & Poor's 500.

That's about in line with a long-term average, at a time when the fundamental background is better than usual. You know, you've got the impact of the new tax code coming through. You've got at least the late stages of a synchronized global upturn.

It's actually pretty good conditions for profitability and for the equity market. That's why I nervously say, "Stay up to wait," even in spite of the possibility of some pretty nasty policy mistakes.

EDWARDS: And -- and you don't attach a very high probability to those policy mistakes, as Nejra was saying, then, Jim. But do you have a handle on what the end goal of the Trump administration is here?

I mean, is it about bringing down the deficit, as he talks about so often? Is it about a decent performance in the midterms? It seems that we need to understand on what basis he will rate his own success, to understand where this goes.

MCCAUGHAN: And he measures his success very clearly, by popularity on -- among his base. And so what he wants to see, I suspect, is better job picture for his base, rising wages for the middle of the country, for the people that really elected him. And I think that's his ultimate aim.

I think a lot of the anti-foreigner rhetoric is really just aimed at the elements in that who are anti-foreigner. And I think that, in a sense, that's the noise around the fundamental economic aim, which is to try to take away the decline, relatively speaking, in living standards among the -- basically the white working class.

CEHIC: Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, stays with us.

(BREAK)

EDWARDS: Now, Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, still with us here on-set in London.

Jim, let's dive into the U.S. economy. We mentioned the job story. What do you expect to see today from the report, more broadly from the report?

I got a message overnight from Ben Emons at Intellectus Partners. He talks about how market activity, in his view, is starting to impact on economic activity. Do you see any early signs of that in the United States? Or it's way too soon?

MCCAUGHAN: I think it's too soon. What I see when we -- we at Principal have a lot of contact with small- and mid-size businesses all over the U.S. Morale is actually quite high.

There is a very strong feeling that federal regulation is getting less in the way of small- and mid-size business. And that's kind of away from the political rhetoric and what's happening in the stock market.

So I think that that momentum is actually leading to a more positive, more constructive approach to hiring by small- and mid-size business. It's interesting, Mr. Bostic was talking about inflation. What we've seen is that wage rates are actually rising in small, mid-size and growing businesses more than they are in big companies and state and local employment.

So I think you've already got a kind of leading indicator of job -- of -- of wage growth here, which I think is quite healthy for the underlying tone of the U.S. economy.

CEHIC: When it comes to wage growth, I was reading a note yesterday, somebody saying, "Look, payrolls are eventually going to pay. That wage growth that everyone's waiting for is going to come through."

Meanwhile, yesterday, we were talking about the fact that the U.S. sort of jobs picture, the employment picture, looking like the 1960s. We all know what happened then. Unemployment fell, inflation ratcheted up.

But this isn't really the '60s, is it, Chairman? I mean, it's very different globally. We're a much more globalized world. That's what's keeping wages down.

MCCAUGHAN: It's globalized. It's also technology, Nejra --

CEHIC: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- that's the -- to me, that's the big difference from the '60s, is the impact of e-commerce and of communication, the deflationary impact of automation.

There's an enormous amount of deflation in the economy that's actually not properly recorded in the inflation numbers. So for example, where people used to buy stuff from department stores, a big proportion of them now go through e-commerce, primarily Amazon.

Why do they do that? Because the prices are maybe 30 percent lower. But that's not recorded in the inflation numbers. You have a very large outlet substitution effect, meaning that there is more deflation around than the reported inflation numbers suggest.

EDWARDS: And a lot of price discover as well, and we --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- we -- yes. We all know President Trump's views on Amazon.

Just on the subject of the U.S. economy more broadly, then, Jim, how does this trade story stick to the Fed? Because on the one had, you could argue this gives the -- the Fed reason to pause, to assess what damage, if any, is done or -- or benefit is achieved.

On the other hand, though, you could say tariffs put (ph) up inflation, and therefore it forces the Fed to act more quickly.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, although that's not really inflation. It's simply an extra tax, which puts prices up but it's a relative price effect. Tariffs actually ultimately decrease inflation by decreasing economic activity.

So I think they'd be making a policy mistake if tariffs come in and they say, "Hey, inflation needs to be choked back by higher interest rates." That could compound the felony (ph), actually, and make -- make the -- a -- a policy error on the interest rate front.

I -- I suspect if the Fed does four rate rises this year, they're probably making a policy mistake. I think they run the risk of getting yields into a territory that will slow the economy. And I don't think that has to happen yet. Even though unemployment is very low, the safety valve here is increasing the labor force participation --

EDWARDS: Yes.

CEHIC: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- we're seeing that happening quite consistently, and I think that's a benign situation if they can keep on the current policy track.

CEHIC: Indeed. Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, stays with us.

(BREAK)

EDWARDS: Let's talk about tech, then. Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, is still with us.

And, Jim, we often talk about technology and its role on inflation. And you mentioned that in the previous half hour. But let's talk about regulatory risks.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: Regulatory risk, specifically -- specifically around those business models in technology that are funded by advertising and therefore rely on data.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: How big a threat to these types of business is more regulation?

MCCAUGHAN: Oh. I think that Facebook in particular is in an existential threat. You mentioned earlier, the 10 or 15 percent setback we've seen in the stock price. That seems to me like a modest setback compared with the dangers they face, particularly on regulation.

EDWARDS: So existential. So this could really threaten the whole of what we know as Facebook? This could threaten the business model in its entirety?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, it could. Now what's happened with Facebook is, it's gone -- two or three years ago, everybody loved them. They were well-intentioned, they were positive. There was -- the tech sector and Facebook in particular were just extraordinarily popular.

Now with the stories around how they share data, with the use of data, with the monopoly power that comes from being in so many parts of social media, you have -- they're moving, to be honest, as unpopular as banks.

And, you know, I think that that --

(CROSSTALK)

MCCAUGHAN: I don't know about journalists.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCAUGHAN: I wouldn't go there.

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: A (ph) state agent?

MCCAUGHAN: I wouldn't go there. Yes, maybe. But the point I'd make here is, when that sort of political problem hits, regulators come after them.

How might that end up? It might end up with regulation on (ph) use of data. The U.S. has a -- has a track record over the very long term, of breaking up companies --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- that become too powerful. I wouldn't rule that out on a three-year view. It's not going to happen under the current administration. But, you know, what happens in the midterms? What happens in the next presidential election?

You could well see a political situation where even a breakup of Facebook is in -- is on the cards.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: So there is a lot of risk there. I've been saying, "Buy the U.S. market on the dips."

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: I'm not (ph) sure I'd buy Facebook on the dips. I think I'd probably go to others that don't have the specific --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Right.

MCCAUGHAN: -- perils that they have.

CEHIC: Yes. I mean, and, Jim, tech stocks were a big part of the sell-off and the volatility in the U.S. equity market generally, but you say we're not looking at a bubble-like situation circa '99, it's more like early 1998.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: How? What are the signs that you see there?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, the main one I would point to is that the stock market rating got very high at late '99. We got to 25 times our earnings on the S&P 500.

The reason I think we're still in a much -- in a less perilous situation is that the average rating on the fundamentals is a lot lower at a time when things are really pretty good for particularly American business.

So I -- I think that what would get me to a feeling that we were in late-'99 and in real peril in the market is one of two things. It's either the market going up a long way to get to that 25-times earnings-plus --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Right.

MCCAUGHAN: -- or it's something that brings the next recession much closer. Now that could be tariffs. The fashionable one six months ago is it could be military hostility in Korea. It could be an interruption of oil supplies. It could be credit problems.

You know, there's a lot of different things which are in that 20 or 30 percent probability of things going wrong. The main one at the moment is tariffs --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- but it's not the only one.

EDWARDS: Volatile (ph) risks. And some people have pointed to recent appointments in -- in Washington, and when that changes --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- the percentages around some of the -- the possibility --

MCCAUGHAN: That's right.

EDWARDS: -- of military action. In terms of the debate around technology, then, Jim, so Facebook and business models such as that, perhaps, maybe face regulatory risk.

What about hardware businesses that operate in technology? We have numbers out of Samsung overnight, supported by their chip business. Are you more interested in hardware stories around tech, or are you not loading up on those either?

MCCAUGHAN: Yeah, I'm not sure particularly a hardware story. Because the hardware is -- the -- the intrinsic value, the value to the consumer is dependent on the software and the apps.

You know, Apple is very modestly rated and a very strong company. I think I'd rather have that than Facebook in the current market. I might even rather have Amazon, actually, even though the president appears to want to get his claws into them. Because I'm not sure there's really so much that can be done about that. They're in a more competitive market anyway.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: They don't face an existential threat?

MCCAUGHAN: I don't think they do, actually. I don't see it yet. So I do think that my "buy the dips" on markets is a little bit qualified.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: And it -- you -- you have to look at companies that have particular dangers at the moment, and the two that are being talked about on this show are right here, Deutsche Bank and Facebook.

You also have to look at other markets. Here's one place I go with the equity market. The rest of the world is more at peril from tariffs than the U.S. is. The U.S. is a massive, integrated domestic economy.

That's why I'm beginning to say, and have been beginning to say over the last two or three months, "Sell the international markets on strength" as opposed to continue to buy the dips on the U.S. I think that the U.S. will do better even with tariffs than many of the international markets.

CEHIC: That's interesting. I was going to ask you about Big Tech and whether you were still positive on it, given that valuations in tech are three times the broader market --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: -- so we may not be looking at 1999, but still the tech valuation's that high. But you've sort of answered the question with what you said about Amazon.

But on what you said about global versus U.S., I want to show you this chart, which is the VIX topping the European volatility gauge as trade issues and the tech stock slump have played out.

And this is unusual, U.S. stocks being more volatile than their counterparts in Europe. So the euro stocks, 50 volatility index. The V (ph) stocks. Given that, you still think that you should be more positive on the U.S. versus the rest of the world?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, I do. I don't really buy the VIX as a measure of risk. It's too volatile to be anything to do with fundamental risk.

CEHIC: And these are normal volatility levels, historically, right?

MCCAUGHAN: Well, that's -- that's the point. You know, the -- the volatility, so far this year, looks high compared with where it's been over most of the last decade. What is it, 26 or 27 1 percent days so far this year. In the '80s and '90s, that wouldn't have been unusual.

Whereas in the current time, it's thought of as very unusual because the last 10 years have been a period of moderation and of gradual upturn in markets.

I think we probably, because of changes in market structure, just have to get used to be a bit -- to a bit more day-to-day volatility. I think that that's not really making the market fundamentally more risky.

EDWARDS: OK. Jim, thank you very much for your thoughts so far.

Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors. He stays with us here on the program.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: And Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, is still with us.

So, Jim, what's your view on Deutsche Bank and -- and German banks in general? And how they kind of fit into the broader European banking picture.

MCCAUGHAN: I think the thing I would add to Jan-Patrick's comments about the succession at Deutsche Bank is, the ideal new person would also be something of a change agent. So it's an awful lot of things to ask for in one chief executive.

Now, why do I say that? If I look at the period when Deutsche Bank was doing particularly well in market share terms, they were very aggressive. They were aggressive on trading, they were aggressive on the investment banking products they were offering. So aggressive, quite highly leveraged.

Secondly, if I look at European banks in general and Deutsche Bank by extension, they're not well-capitalized. The non-performing (ph) loans were not dealt with after the crisis as effectively as they were in the United States.

So I would think that the new chief executive, if there is a new one at Deutsche Bank, will have to look very carefully at how to shrink some activities, notably in the aggressive end of investment banking.

They don't really need to compete with Goldman as a global investment bank. They need to be much more satisfying their base in Germany. And also to look at the capital situation. So there's (ph) going to be some unpopular things to do.

And I think it's a microcosm of the European banking picture. You know, there are strengths and weaknesses in the European economy. One of the weaknesses is, how will they create enough credit once growth gets going? I don't see that at the moment and I think there is an issue there.

EDWARDS: Would be a big task, then, for a new -- a new CEO in there, yes (ph). If they could speak German, I like the way Jan-Patrick said that would be an added bonus, of course, as well.

So in terms of the underlying picture for the eurozone economy, then, Jim, I've got a chart here that shows a couple of data points on the eurozone economy that maybe have been ticking down.

In fact, this is on German factory orders, eurozone retail sales, (INAUDIBLE) to inflation, to output numbers, as being a bit disappointing. And blame a host of factors. The weather, flu, even, the movement of Easter, the stronger euro. How concerned are you about data points that disappoint a little bit or come in below estimate?

MCCAUGHAN: I think they're symptomatic, Anna, of an economy that may not be quite as robust as many people hoped. And which may well not be in an -- such an escape velocity, self-sustaining recovery mode.

I think that, you know, Europe has done well. There has been improved sentiment, particularly in Germany. The French election put the European business sentiment on a much better course. Monsieur Macron has been a -- a big asset to the European economy by being very pro-business.

But what's happening next? You know, you're seeing recurrent resurgence of populism, even in Germany. You're seeing a very difficult outcome of the Italian election. Still not clear who will form a government.

So, you know, if you just (ph) look at the political situation in Europe, it's deteriorating. I would suggest that the European recovery is pretty fragile, and I go back to the banks as one of the reasons for that being the case.

CEHIC: What does this mean for the bond markets, Jim? Earlier you were saying that you prefer U.S. equities over European. If we look at the Treasury-Bund spread, for example, does -- do Treasuries outperform?

MCCAUGHAN: I think they probably do, relative to the Bunds. Although I don't -- I'm not one of those who think that -- that eurozone interest rates are going up rapidly.

I think they're -- I think they're going to be pinned to zero for a while because of this lack of sustainability about the recovery. So I think that, if anything, the -- the difference between U.S. and European rates might edge up a little rather than -- rather than closing.

But eventually, there will be a convergence. But it will really be very dependent on economic conditions' demand for funds. But at the moment, I would actually be more bullish of the dollar. And that's one of the reasons why I am favoring U.S. investments rather than -- rather than international.

EDWARDS: That's interesting, Jim. So you think you've got a -- a clear idea of how further trade tension, if that's what we're in for, impacts the dollar?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes. I think that trade tension, if it leads to recession, which eventually it would do, then it will tend to lead to a push towards safe harbors, which will include the dollar and U.S. Treasuries.

That may seem a little perverse since the U.S. basically seems to have started these trade skirmishes, but I think they were started on a fairly clear calculation, that if it all goes wrong, it hurts everybody else much more than it hurts the U.S.

EDWARDS: I remember the height of the financial crisis, lots of people asked -- or at the start of it, lots of people asked if this kind of started in the United States, how come we find safe harbor in -- in U.S. assets? That --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

CEHIC: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- similar, again --

(CROSSTALK)

CEHIC: -- still serve (ph) currency.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes. It's the reserve currency, which is a -- which is an extraordinary privilege. And, you know, I -- I do think that the openness of foreign economies is one of the reasons they're vulnerable. It's one of the reasons they've grown, of course.

EDWARDS: Yes. All right, Jim. Thank you so much for spending the last hour with us --

MCCAUGHAN: Thank you.

EDWARDS: -- we appreciate it. Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors.

END

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JIM MCCAUGHAN, CEO, PRINCIPAL GLOBAL INVESTORS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

APRIL 6, 2018

SPEAKERS: JIM MCCAUGHAN, CEO, PRINCIPAL GLOBAL INVESTORS

ANNA EDWARDS, BLOOMBERG NEWS

NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: China's state news agency vowed that Beijing would defend its interests against new U.S. actions this morning. Joining us now is Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors.

Great to see you, Jim, good morning to you --

(CROSSTALK)

JIM MCCAUGHAN, CEO, PRINCIPAL GLOBAL INVESTORS: Good morning. Great to be here.

CEHIC: Yes, thank you for giving us some of your time while you're in London. In terms of the risks around an escalation of a trade war, this is one of the sort of scenarios that you see as more of an outlier, among other things. A 20 to 30 percent probability of risk. How do you see this evolving?

MCCAUGHAN: Well, I think that the market consensus is actually, in this case, valid. Which is that the administration, President Trump in particular, are using the threat of tariffs as a bargaining counter in order to get other things.

It was very interesting, when the steel and aluminum tariffs were announced, what, three weeks ago or three or four weeks ago, you had the photo up in the Oval Office with the steelworkers.

You then went straight to Mr. Trump's comments, in which he walked back the tariffs almost immediately. He said, "Canada and Mexico are our friends, we won't target them. And the Germans might get better treatment if they pay for their own defense."

So in other words, using the tariffs as a threat to actually get other agenda items. Now. My 20 or 30 percent probability is that others call his bluff, and we end -- we end up, by default, with a rather unintended trade war. But I don't think that's the course that they think they're on.

And I think that some of the more free trade-oriented heads within government -- you're talking to Larry Kudlow later in the day -- I think many of them would actually sympathize with the idea of using tariffs as a bargaining counter.

ANNA EDWARDS, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: So buying very much into this argument that this is posturing, this is not where we end up, then, Jim. But things do seem to be escalating pretty quickly, don't they? I mean, the market's just getting its head around the $50 billion versus $50 billion --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- the two countries. And then we get this announcement overnight, that the Trump administration wants to investigate the possibility of further tariffs on another $100 billion of Chinese imports.

I've got this chart, 7061, which shows that, actually, it would be very difficult for China to match this toe-to-toe because of the scale of the imbalance in deficit. It would be difficult for China to find enough U.S. imports to, then, match this. So then it begs the question, how China then retaliates. What other tools do they have in their toolkit.

I mean, I wonder whether we need to get to a point where we've got a date in the diary, an announcement of a meeting, some kind of firm commitment to -- to negotiate something away from this posturing.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes. I think the negotiation is happening behind the scenes anyway. I don't think it necessarily needs President Xi to go to Mar-a- Lago for the two sides to be talking. I think there is quite a lot of conversation going on.

Having said that, it's not yet decisive and constructive conversation. And I think that's something that the market expects to develop over the next few weeks. You probably will see some sort of head-of-government-type conversation between the U.S. and China.

But it's -- it needn't be imminent. The conversations can happen. The -- the concessions can be made at a lower level and get ratified later. The market thinks that's where it's going.

But, you know, it's so political. If you look at what the Chines retaliation was, you know, soybeans and pork. That's aimed at the people who elected Trump. It's not aimed at the U.S. economy more broadly. And so it's highly politicized when you look at the specific targeting of tariffs that's been suggested.

And I think that's the clue to what's really going on, that there is this 20 or 30 percent possibility that bluffs get called, things degenerate --

CEHIC: Yes.

EDWARDS: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- and that would be very bad for the market, and quite bad for the economy.

CEHIC: Yes. And, Jim, you sort of advised to not really adjust your portfolio based on that 20 to 30 percent probability. But before we get to there with what's happening now, we've seen a lot of equity volatility, more volatility in equities than in other asset classes as we've --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: -- talked a lot about this week. I just want to take you to a chart which shows the relative performance of stocks versus bonds. And that has actually come down recently --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: -- you can see towards the end of the chart, it's coming up a little bit. In the scenario that we're in now, before we get to that 20 to 30 percent probability, how would you allocate? Would you reduce your exposure to equities, or not yet?

MCCAUGHAN: Probably not yet. I think you're -- in U.S. equities, you should be keeping up to wait (ph) because, you know, the U.S. equity market is, in terms of average rating, it's now on about between 16 and 17 times current-year earnings on the Standard & Poor's 500.

That's about in line with a long-term average, at a time when the fundamental background is better than usual. You know, you've got the impact of the new tax code coming through. You've got at least the late stages of a synchronized global upturn.

It's actually pretty good conditions for profitability and for the equity market. That's why I nervously say, "Stay up to wait," even in spite of the possibility of some pretty nasty policy mistakes.

EDWARDS: And -- and you don't attach a very high probability to those policy mistakes, as Nejra was saying, then, Jim. But do you have a handle on what the end goal of the Trump administration is here?

I mean, is it about bringing down the deficit, as he talks about so often? Is it about a decent performance in the midterms? It seems that we need to understand on what basis he will rate his own success, to understand where this goes.

MCCAUGHAN: And he measures his success very clearly, by popularity on -- among his base. And so what he wants to see, I suspect, is better job picture for his base, rising wages for the middle of the country, for the people that really elected him. And I think that's his ultimate aim.

I think a lot of the anti-foreigner rhetoric is really just aimed at the elements in that who are anti-foreigner. And I think that, in a sense, that's the noise around the fundamental economic aim, which is to try to take away the decline, relatively speaking, in living standards among the - - basically the white working class.

CEHIC: Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, stays with us.

(BREAK)

EDWARDS: Now, Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, still with us here on-set in London.

Jim, let's dive into the U.S. economy. We mentioned the job story. What do you expect to see today from the report, more broadly from the report?

I got a message overnight from Ben Emons at Intellectus Partners. He talks about how market activity, in his view, is starting to impact on economic activity. Do you see any early signs of that in the United States? Or it's way too soon?

MCCAUGHAN: I think it's too soon. What I see when we -- we at Principal have a lot of contact with small- and mid-size businesses all over the U.S. Morale is actually quite high.

There is a very strong feeling that federal regulation is getting less in the way of small- and mid-size business. And that's kind of away from the political rhetoric and what's happening in the stock market.

So I think that that momentum is actually leading to a more positive, more constructive approach to hiring by small- and mid-size business. It's interesting, Mr. Bostic was talking about inflation. What we've seen is that wage rates are actually rising in small, mid-size and growing businesses more than they are in big companies and state and local employment.

So I think you've already got a kind of leading indicator of job -- of -- of wage growth here, which I think is quite healthy for the underlying tone of the U.S. economy.

CEHIC: When it comes to wage growth, I was reading a note yesterday, somebody saying, "Look, payrolls are eventually going to pay. That wage growth that everyone's waiting for is going to come through."

Meanwhile, yesterday, we were talking about the fact that the U.S. sort of jobs picture, the employment picture, looking like the 1960s. We all know what happened then. Unemployment fell, inflation ratcheted up.

But this isn't really the '60s, is it, Chairman? I mean, it's very different globally. We're a much more globalized world. That's what's keeping wages down.

MCCAUGHAN: It's globalized. It's also technology, Nejra --

CEHIC: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- that's the -- to me, that's the big difference from the '60s, is the impact of e-commerce and of communication, the deflationary impact of automation.

There's an enormous amount of deflation in the economy that's actually not properly recorded in the inflation numbers. So for example, where people used to buy stuff from department stores, a big proportion of them now go through e-commerce, primarily Amazon.

Why do they do that? Because the prices are maybe 30 percent lower. But that's not recorded in the inflation numbers. You have a very large outlet substitution effect, meaning that there is more deflation around than the reported inflation numbers suggest.

EDWARDS: And a lot of price discover as well, and we --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- we -- yes. We all know President Trump's views on Amazon.

Just on the subject of the U.S. economy more broadly, then, Jim, how does this trade story stick to the Fed? Because on the one had, you could argue this gives the -- the Fed reason to pause, to assess what damage, if any, is done or -- or benefit is achieved.

On the other hand, though, you could say tariffs put (ph) up inflation, and therefore it forces the Fed to act more quickly.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, although that's not really inflation. It's simply an extra tax, which puts prices up but it's a relative price effect. Tariffs actually ultimately decrease inflation by decreasing economic activity.

So I think they'd be making a policy mistake if tariffs come in and they say, "Hey, inflation needs to be choked back by higher interest rates." That could compound the felony (ph), actually, and make -- make the -- a -- a policy error on the interest rate front.

I -- I suspect if the Fed does four rate rises this year, they're probably making a policy mistake. I think they run the risk of getting yields into a territory that will slow the economy. And I don't think that has to happen yet. Even though unemployment is very low, the safety valve here is increasing the labor force participation --

EDWARDS: Yes.

CEHIC: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- we're seeing that happening quite consistently, and I think that's a benign situation if they can keep on the current policy track.

CEHIC: Indeed. Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, stays with us.

(BREAK)

EDWARDS: Let's talk about tech, then. Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, is still with us.

And, Jim, we often talk about technology and its role on inflation. And you mentioned that in the previous half hour. But let's talk about regulatory risks.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: Regulatory risk, specifically -- specifically around those business models in technology that are funded by advertising and therefore rely on data.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: How big a threat to these types of business is more regulation?

MCCAUGHAN: Oh. I think that Facebook in particular is in an existential threat. You mentioned earlier, the 10 or 15 percent setback we've seen in the stock price. That seems to me like a modest setback compared with the dangers they face, particularly on regulation.

EDWARDS: So existential. So this could really threaten the whole of what we know as Facebook? This could threaten the business model in its entirety?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, it could. Now what's happened with Facebook is, it's gone -- two or three years ago, everybody loved them. They were well- intentioned, they were positive. There was -- the tech sector and Facebook in particular were just extraordinarily popular.

Now with the stories around how they share data, with the use of data, with the monopoly power that comes from being in so many parts of social media, you have -- they're moving, to be honest, as unpopular as banks.

And, you know, I think that that --

(CROSSTALK)

MCCAUGHAN: I don't know about journalists.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCAUGHAN: I wouldn't go there.

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: A (ph) state agent?

MCCAUGHAN: I wouldn't go there. Yes, maybe. But the point I'd make here is, when that sort of political problem hits, regulators come after them.

How might that end up? It might end up with regulation on (ph) use of data. The U.S. has a -- has a track record over the very long term, of breaking up companies --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- that become too powerful. I wouldn't rule that out on a three-year view. It's not going to happen under the current administration. But, you know, what happens in the midterms? What happens in the next presidential election?

You could well see a political situation where even a breakup of Facebook is in -- is on the cards.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: So there is a lot of risk there. I've been saying, "Buy the U.S. market on the dips."

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: I'm not (ph) sure I'd buy Facebook on the dips. I think I'd probably go to others that don't have the specific --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Right.

MCCAUGHAN: -- perils that they have.

CEHIC: Yes. I mean, and, Jim, tech stocks were a big part of the sell-off and the volatility in the U.S. equity market generally, but you say we're not looking at a bubble-like situation circa '99, it's more like early 1998.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: How? What are the signs that you see there?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, the main one I would point to is that the stock market rating got very high at late '99. We got to 25 times our earnings on the S&P 500.

The reason I think we're still in a much -- in a less perilous situation is that the average rating on the fundamentals is a lot lower at a time when things are really pretty good for particularly American business.

So I -- I think that what would get me to a feeling that we were in late- '99 and in real peril in the market is one of two things. It's either the market going up a long way to get to that 25-times earnings-plus --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Right.

MCCAUGHAN: -- or it's something that brings the next recession much closer. Now that could be tariffs. The fashionable one six months ago is it could be military hostility in Korea. It could be an interruption of oil supplies. It could be credit problems.

You know, there's a lot of different things which are in that 20 or 30 percent probability of things going wrong. The main one at the moment is tariffs --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: -- but it's not the only one.

EDWARDS: Volatile (ph) risks. And some people have pointed to recent appointments in -- in Washington, and when that changes --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- the percentages around some of the -- the possibility --

MCCAUGHAN: That's right.

EDWARDS: -- of military action. In terms of the debate around technology, then, Jim, so Facebook and business models such as that, perhaps, maybe face regulatory risk.

What about hardware businesses that operate in technology? We have numbers out of Samsung overnight, supported by their chip business. Are you more interested in hardware stories around tech, or are you not loading up on those either?

MCCAUGHAN: Yeah, I'm not sure particularly a hardware story. Because the hardware is -- the -- the intrinsic value, the value to the consumer is dependent on the software and the apps.

You know, Apple is very modestly rated and a very strong company. I think I'd rather have that than Facebook in the current market. I might even rather have Amazon, actually, even though the president appears to want to get his claws into them. Because I'm not sure there's really so much that can be done about that. They're in a more competitive market anyway.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: They don't face an existential threat?

MCCAUGHAN: I don't think they do, actually. I don't see it yet. So I do think that my "buy the dips" on markets is a little bit qualified.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

MCCAUGHAN: And it -- you -- you have to look at companies that have particular dangers at the moment, and the two that are being talked about on this show are right here, Deutsche Bank and Facebook.

You also have to look at other markets. Here's one place I go with the equity market. The rest of the world is more at peril from tariffs than the U.S. is. The U.S. is a massive, integrated domestic economy.

That's why I'm beginning to say, and have been beginning to say over the last two or three months, "Sell the international markets on strength" as opposed to continue to buy the dips on the U.S. I think that the U.S. will do better even with tariffs than many of the international markets.

CEHIC: That's interesting. I was going to ask you about Big Tech and whether you were still positive on it, given that valuations in tech are three times the broader market --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

CEHIC: -- so we may not be looking at 1999, but still the tech valuation's that high. But you've sort of answered the question with what you said about Amazon.

But on what you said about global versus U.S., I want to show you this chart, which is the VIX topping the European volatility gauge as trade issues and the tech stock slump have played out.

And this is unusual, U.S. stocks being more volatile than their counterparts in Europe. So the euro stocks, 50 volatility index. The V (ph) stocks. Given that, you still think that you should be more positive on the U.S. versus the rest of the world?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes, I do. I don't really buy the VIX as a measure of risk. It's too volatile to be anything to do with fundamental risk.

CEHIC: And these are normal volatility levels, historically, right?

MCCAUGHAN: Well, that's -- that's the point. You know, the -- the volatility, so far this year, looks high compared with where it's been over most of the last decade. What is it, 26 or 27 1 percent days so far this year. In the '80s and '90s, that wouldn't have been unusual.

Whereas in the current time, it's thought of as very unusual because the last 10 years have been a period of moderation and of gradual upturn in markets.

I think we probably, because of changes in market structure, just have to get used to be a bit -- to a bit more day-to-day volatility. I think that that's not really making the market fundamentally more risky.

EDWARDS: OK. Jim, thank you very much for your thoughts so far.

Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors. He stays with us here on the program.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: And Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors, is still with us.

So, Jim, what's your view on Deutsche Bank and -- and German banks in general? And how they kind of fit into the broader European banking picture.

MCCAUGHAN: I think the thing I would add to Jan-Patrick's comments about the succession at Deutsche Bank is, the ideal new person would also be something of a change agent. So it's an awful lot of things to ask for in one chief executive.

Now, why do I say that? If I look at the period when Deutsche Bank was doing particularly well in market share terms, they were very aggressive. They were aggressive on trading, they were aggressive on the investment banking products they were offering. So aggressive, quite highly leveraged.

Secondly, if I look at European banks in general and Deutsche Bank by extension, they're not well-capitalized. The non-performing (ph) loans were not dealt with after the crisis as effectively as they were in the United States.

So I would think that the new chief executive, if there is a new one at Deutsche Bank, will have to look very carefully at how to shrink some activities, notably in the aggressive end of investment banking.

They don't really need to compete with Goldman as a global investment bank. They need to be much more satisfying their base in Germany. And also to look at the capital situation. So there's (ph) going to be some unpopular things to do.

And I think it's a microcosm of the European banking picture. You know, there are strengths and weaknesses in the European economy. One of the weaknesses is, how will they create enough credit once growth gets going? I don't see that at the moment and I think there is an issue there.

EDWARDS: Would be a big task, then, for a new -- a new CEO in there, yes (ph). If they could speak German, I like the way Jan-Patrick said that would be an added bonus, of course, as well.

So in terms of the underlying picture for the eurozone economy, then, Jim, I've got a chart here that shows a couple of data points on the eurozone economy that maybe have been ticking down.

In fact, this is on German factory orders, eurozone retail sales, (INAUDIBLE) to inflation, to output numbers, as being a bit disappointing. And blame a host of factors. The weather, flu, even, the movement of Easter, the stronger euro. How concerned are you about data points that disappoint a little bit or come in below estimate?

MCCAUGHAN: I think they're symptomatic, Anna, of an economy that may not be quite as robust as many people hoped. And which may well not be in an - - such an escape velocity, self-sustaining recovery mode.

I think that, you know, Europe has done well. There has been improved sentiment, particularly in Germany. The French election put the European business sentiment on a much better course. Monsieur Macron has been a -- a big asset to the European economy by being very pro-business.

But what's happening next? You know, you're seeing recurrent resurgence of populism, even in Germany. You're seeing a very difficult outcome of the Italian election. Still not clear who will form a government.

So, you know, if you just (ph) look at the political situation in Europe, it's deteriorating. I would suggest that the European recovery is pretty fragile, and I go back to the banks as one of the reasons for that being the case.

CEHIC: What does this mean for the bond markets, Jim? Earlier you were saying that you prefer U.S. equities over European. If we look at the Treasury-Bund spread, for example, does -- do Treasuries outperform?

MCCAUGHAN: I think they probably do, relative to the Bunds. Although I don't -- I'm not one of those who think that -- that eurozone interest rates are going up rapidly.

I think they're -- I think they're going to be pinned to zero for a while because of this lack of sustainability about the recovery. So I think that, if anything, the -- the difference between U.S. and European rates might edge up a little rather than -- rather than closing.

But eventually, there will be a convergence. But it will really be very dependent on economic conditions' demand for funds. But at the moment, I would actually be more bullish of the dollar. And that's one of the reasons why I am favoring U.S. investments rather than -- rather than international.

EDWARDS: That's interesting, Jim. So you think you've got a -- a clear idea of how further trade tension, if that's what we're in for, impacts the dollar?

MCCAUGHAN: Yes. I think that trade tension, if it leads to recession, which eventually it would do, then it will tend to lead to a push towards safe harbors, which will include the dollar and U.S. Treasuries.

That may seem a little perverse since the U.S. basically seems to have started these trade skirmishes, but I think they were started on a fairly clear calculation, that if it all goes wrong, it hurts everybody else much more than it hurts the U.S.

EDWARDS: I remember the height of the financial crisis, lots of people asked -- or at the start of it, lots of people asked if this kind of started in the United States, how come we find safe harbor in -- in U.S. assets? That --

MCCAUGHAN: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

CEHIC: Yes.

EDWARDS: -- similar, again --

(CROSSTALK)

CEHIC: -- still serve (ph) currency.

MCCAUGHAN: Yes. It's the reserve currency, which is a -- which is an extraordinary privilege. And, you know, I -- I do think that the openness of foreign economies is one of the reasons they're vulnerable. It's one of the reasons they've grown, of course.

EDWARDS: Yes. All right, Jim. Thank you so much for spending the last hour with us --

MCCAUGHAN: Thank you.

EDWARDS: -- we appreciate it. Jim McCaughan, CEO of Principal Global Investors.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
