Jim O'Neill, Viraj Patel, And Antony Jenkins discuss economics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JIM O'NEILL, FORMER COMMERCIAL SECRETARY, U.K. TREASURY; VIRAJ PATEL, FX STRATEGIST, ING BANK; AND ANTONY JENKINS, CHAIRMAN, BITC; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

MAY 01, 2018

SPEAKERS: JIM O'NEILL, FORMER COMMERCIAL SECRETARY, U.K. TREASURY

VIRAJ PATEL, FX STRATEGIST, ING BANK

ANTONY JENKINS, CHAIRMAN, BITC

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us now for the hour, Viraj Patel, FX Strategist at ING Bank, and Jim O'Neill, former Goldman Sachs Asset Management Chairman, Former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury and the incoming Chair of Chatham House, and also actually author of this book which I want to talk to you a little bit about because it does also have an impact, of course, on NHS spending, and therefore, economic Superbugs: An Arms Race Against Bacteria, and this came out last Thursday.

JIM O'NEILL, FORMER COMMERCIAL SECRETARY, U.K. TREASURY: Yes.

LACQUA: All right. Trade, let's start with trade. Jim, how much focus do you do on trade? And when you take over as Chairman of Chatham House, how much do you think -- how many lectures or how many sessions and seminars will there be on U.S.-China relationships?

O'NEILL: A lot. Judging by the emails I've received with the news about me becoming Chair, a large number of them have got to do with issues about China, especially China's engagement with the rest of the world. So that's one of the reasons I think I was asked to do it, so it's hugely important. It's hugely important.

LACQUA: Viraj, when you look at the currency markets and you kind of fold in to geopolitics and a bit of trade, do we just assume right now that actually the allies will be exempted? It was kind of -- we thought it was an America-first policy. And then as time progresses, President Trump is kind of backtracking, saying, but you're an ally, you'll be fine. You're an ally, you'll be fine.

VIRAJ PATEL, FX STRATEGIST, ING BANK: Yes. But it's a thorn in the side of FX markets. So I think this is only in the mid placed (ph) until June the 1st. So you've always got this perennial uncertainty. But what it's done is -- it's ambiguous. It's not some of the global as global animal spirits started those pro-cyclical currencies, like the euro, that have been benefitting on sort of cycles. Now, that's -- the idea there is that can we look through that? Will investors -- will activity, really activity look through that and sort of the second quarter activity news (ph), so it bounce back. We get on back on track with the normalization story that fuelled the euro sort of upward swing, that's our base case, that's what we're looking forward.

LACQUA: Jim, do you worry that global growth has peaked? And I don't whether it's a trade question or whether it's just, in general, we kind of reached the (inaudible).

O'NEILL: With the usual caveat, one among here that I don't look at this stuff as much or as closely as they do, it is still in my veins, so I do. And actually probably with Chatham House, I'll probably look at it more. It looks that way. I mean, these five things I say every time I'm here, I look at every month whenever I see those five things and I think I know exactly what's going on with the world and both slowed. Some of it's actually surprisingly in Europe, most of it. And I don't really understand that. It's not from the lead leading indicators that I'm used to. It wasn't predictable that Europe had just suddenly slowed, so it could weather related. I think here in the U.K., a lot of it is almost definitely weather related. So I wouldn't -- I think today, we get the PMI, don't we? It would be very interesting to see if you've got any kind of bounce back in some places, because I'm suspicious that the slowdown is temporary, but it certainly looks like the world has slowed since (inaudible).

LACQUA: Yes. Viraj, I think last time you were on, we were talking about the German economy overheating, and suddenly we're talking about a possible slowdown. Do you think that economy has peaked and what does that mean for euro?

PATEL: Yes, it's kind of with (ph) because I think we went 2018 with sort of overexuberant expectations. So the economy has underperformed and underperformed a bit more than we expected relative to high expectations. What you now look at and what we look at as sort of the (inaudible) for the Eurozone, that's at its sort of three, four-year low. So the only way that we can see that sort of worsening is if this is a more structural sort of slowdown in the Eurozone economy. But if it's cyclical, we would expect the expectations to adjust (ph) lower and surge (ph) and in line with the data. And that, in itself, should keep the euro supported. So I think the euro is probably running on hot air at the start of the year but were back to sort of more at normal levels, I would say, but not that -- nothing that should take the euro any further though in our view.

LACQUA: Yes. What does that mean for central banks? So the central banks kind of -- we've been talking about the normalizing for quite some time. Do you think, Jim, they need the arsenal to deal with the next crisis or should they temperate down if we're seeing the slowdown kind of (inaudible)?

O'NEILL: Well, I think it's a bit of a tag team battle, right? So as a couple of them have indicated recently, they want to get rates up when they can. So when the inevitable next problem comes, the (inaudible) will cut them. But the residue of what's happened in the past decade and the first signs of a slip, especially if it turns out to be more than just a couple of months blip, then I think the panic thing for some will set in pretty quickly. So I think it's going to be a tricky call about the (inaudible) of how -- outside the U.S., how some of these guys move in the next month or so?

LACQUA: What do you expect from the fed, Viraj, and what does it mean for dollar overall?

PATEL: We think the fed story is probably priced in, right? The mutual rate, when you look at the short end of the curve, it's there or thereabout with the sort of terminal or the end of the fed tightening. So 25 basis points here or there just doesn't set the dollar trend unless we start to see inflation in the U.S. escape out of control such that markets -- the consensus shifts above mutual pricing of the fed cycle, we don't think that that's going to happen soon. It's really a story about the rest of the world. That's where the FX markets will take the key from going forward.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you both. Both will stick around. Jim O'Neill, Former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury and incoming Chairman of Chatham House, and Viraj Patel from ING Bank.

Still with us, Viraj Patel from ING and Jim O'Neill, former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury and incoming Chairman of Chatham House. Once you become Chairman, we're going to lose all the other titles and make it hosrter.

O'NEILL: It sounds very grand, doesn't it?

LACQUA: It does sound very grand, and, of course, the House of Lords. Lord Jim, when you look at Iran, is it geopolitics story or is it an old story?

O'NEILL: I don't know, obviously a bit of both. It seems to me there's all sorts of tactical things going on as well as strategic things. Yes, you imagine that the U.S. were eager for the Israelis to say what they just did (ph) today. And obviously in hindsight, it looks like the French and German visits to Washington were heavily designed to influence this. Very interesting for Macron, right? How does he -- he's positioned himself as this globally outward guy, at the same time, a big (inaudible) of Donald Trump's, intriguing. So as he made a really smart (inaudible) that he can rescue some kind of an Iranian deal. It's tough but --

LACQUA: But, Jim, when you saw headline cross, right, from the Israeli Prime Minister, who was he speaking to? Was it --

O'NEILL: I think he was speaking to all of us. I think he was speaking to the international media and trying to perhaps get the U.S. media more --

LACQUA: To pick up on it?

O'NEILL: Yes, I would guess. But underlying, one of -- I remember being at some Middle Eastern -- a huge Middle Eastern oil event last autumn. And because of the strength of the world economy, for some reason, I was asked about oil in this panel. I said, I think it's more likely to be 80 than 40 in one year's time. And that was without any of these. So it seems to me notwithstanding what we've said earlier about a bit of a slowing of the world. The world has picked up so much in so many places. The oil market is in a position that is right to price in some kind of risk of a new disruption because it's probably that outside (ph), unless we see a lot more slowing in the world economy, I would have thought.

LACQUA: Yes. And, Viraj, we did see that the oil price basically spiked up. Did we see similar moves for oil currencies?

PATEL: Well, you saw the Canadian dollar sort of have a bit of support. But I think when you're at these elevated levels, the marginal follow-through is quite limited especially for the FX markets which kind of takes its cue right now from the equity and bond market. The oil market is kind of a second or tertiary flatter (ph) for these currencies.

LACQUA: Okay. How do you see it panning out? I mean, again, it's so unpredictable, right? First, because you have President Trump having to decide on the accord by May 12. But does -- how much? Is it difficult to price in these big geopolitics moves in currency markets away from the dollar (ph)?

O'NEILL: That's what all these guys get paid for.

LACQUA: (Inaudible) to do it?

O'NEILL: I used to do that in first (inaudible.)

LACQUA: But is it a nightmare?

O'NEILL: That's what it's all about.

LACQUA: It might have changed, right, in the last 30 years. Now, the world is much more complicated or am I -- or is it not?

PATEL: It's interchanging, right? But there is, to some extent, the short- term risk premium priced into the dollar. That's why it's been disconnected from rates differentials with pretty much six months, six to 12 months. I think the idea now is just kind of how much can U.S. political uncertainty elevate to another. And I think what we're seeing is sort of a consolidation in that uncertainty, but it needs to move massively one way or the other. All these short-term stories don't take us in either direction.

LACQUA: But we used to have Kissinger. Now, you have President Trump that you have to model. I mean, how do you --

O'NEILL: Clearly, we've not had a President quite like this. But this idea that we're in some world of uncertainty, I mean, it's likely rubbish from what I can see. It's always -- that's what makes markets potentially interesting for somebody that's good at them. But you cannot try to anticipate and make some kind of risk adjusted debt which way it's going to go. I mean, remember if I go back -- my pre-Goldman days arriving in Q8, the morning after the U.S. had just bombed Iraq. That's what's --

LACQUA: Good. No, you're right. But then we saw the Koreas, right, on Friday, you saw the Peninsula. Then you see Russia and the role they're trying to play in the Middle East. It just feels like we could be going through a massive shift without really realizing the consequences five years down the line.

O'NEILL: I mean, there is lots of media attention to unknown uncertainties. But this big issue about known unknowns and unknown unknowns and it's a fact of life. I'm reminded as you asked me of another book that I'd reviewed actually recently. Remember Hans Rosling, a posthumous book called Factfulness, which is fantastic. Because it points out just how well the world has done the past 20-30 years despite all of these things we all worry about and (inaudible), including Trump and Brexit. There're a lot of good things that -- such as people living longer and people trying to give attention to getting new antibiotics. And so, yes, they start to worry about it. But for me, for the financial markets, that's why these guys get paid a lot of money to kind of deal with that. Otherwise, what's the point of the (inaudible)?

LACQUA: Well, let's see if they're making money in Brexit. Let's give it to Brexit. Let's change the focus. The U.K. is proposing a new plan to kick start stalled Brexit talks. It's hoping to make progress on the issue of the Irish border when negotiations resume in Brussels tomorrow. Speaking at the Milken Institute conference in California, the former Prime Minister and remain campaigner, Tony Blair, told me Bloomberg, when it comes to the customs union, there's no easy solution.

Okay. Let's get back to Jim and Viraj. Viraj, let me bring you over to a chart that Hillary Clark, the queen of charts, have kind of made for me this morning, and this is looking at fair value of sterling. We have a Bloomberg economics pound fair value estimate. In white, we have IMF U.K. real effective exchange rate. I mean, what do you look at? Do you just look at trade weighted?

PATEL: Trade weighted in terms of -- for the sterling sort of appreciation in the short-term. But I think when we look at sort of fair value, fair value is the black box right now when the Brexit sort of end state is still highly unknown. So I think for us, what we see is this is gravitational pull, which is sterling is cheap. One of the reasons why we've kind of seen it as like a long run sort of a move higher. And you're seeing is a structural repricing of the Brexit tail risk, that the tail risk risk premium of a cliff edge Brexit in 2019. That's been postponed thanks to sort of the transition deal. But we're still caught between where it ends. And I think it just wants to, especially against, say, a clearer currencies, like the dollar, which is the sort of their trend. It wants to gradually move higher. The Bank of England story is a short-term story. It doesn't actually affect it from a long run perspective. That's not what is keeping sort of the pound at these elevated depressed levels.

LACQUA: Okay. I do want to ask you about Governor Carney and the label that he's got, fairly or unfairly, but the unreliable boyfriend. But first of all, do you think it will all play out in parliament? But actually we talk about Brexit but the people.

O'NEILL: My colleagues goes a bit at first last night in the house.

LACQUA: They did. But will they decide yes or no, actually, Brexit goes through in the end?

O'NEILL: It seems to me that there is a growing appetite, although the most passionate Brexiteers are going to fight it, for some kind of extension of the customs union going on. Last night though takes some of the attention away from that in a way but it brings it more to the realities of what (inaudible) tactics are and notwithstanding Amber Rudd's disappearance, so the cabinet balance has shifted a bit. But I smell that some kind of extension or underlying replication of the customs union is the way that things are shifting.

LACQUA: Okay. In 30 seconds, do you expect to hike from BOE in May?

PATEL: Not officially, but it's not dead and buried. I think it's just more about sentiment just coming back on when -- it's moving in line with data. Data will drive the pound, not political directions.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you both for joining us. Viraj Patel, FX Strategist at ING Bank. They're on some pretty bold pound moves in the past. And Jim O'Neill, former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury, incoming Chairman of Chatham, stays with us.

Jim O'Neill, as we look at these numbers and we're talking a little bit about Brexit, does that actually have an impact? I mean, should Governor Carney look through or are we going to see a slowdown because of Brexit?

O'NEILL: It's like days gone by for me. That should be on the trade floor talking to the (inaudible).

LACQUA: Which you're going straightaway, right?

O'NEILL: I am slightly surprised and my immediate reaction to that is slightly boring (ph). Because if it was weather related, we should be getting some stabilization or bounce backs. So that is -- if I were an MPC voting member and had been thinking about a hike, I might be backing off a bit.

LACQUA: Yes. And so just to put that into context, the U.K. manufacturing slows more than forecast. It's now at a 17-month low and actually does seem to be adding two signs that the poor first quarter performance of the U.K. could actually persist. So we'll be back with Jim O'Neill and we also have the former Chief Executive of Barclays with us to talk Fintech shortly. 437 LACQUA: We're now joined by Antony Jenkins. He's the former Chief Executive of Barclays, the current Chief Executive of 10x Future Technology, a Fintech firm that aims to use technology to redefine how banks operate. And still with us, Jim O'Neill, former Commercial Secretary to the U.K. Treasury and incoming Chairman for Chatham House. Antony, thank you so much for joining us. What exactly are you working on? So we have you regularly on the program every three to four months. What's fundamentally changed from the last time you were on? You were kind of going deeper into technologies that you really think will transform the way banks operate.

ANTONY JENKINS, CHAIRMAN, BITC: It's really fascinating. 2.5 years ago, I gave a speech actually at Chatham House, which Jim is now Chair, and I talked about uber moments and financial services, moments where there was transformation. And since that speech 2.5 years ago, we've seen I think two of them. So the first is in the growth of mobile banking, which has caused a phenomenal drop in branch traffic, and that's a problem for the big banks because they have that cost base to sustain even while customers are going elsewhere. Secondarily, we've seen a huge rise in crypto. Now, crypto itself is a huge topic, whether subcategories of that, like the ICO market, which I think is very interesting. And I think the third uber moment that we're going to see is about data, who controls data, how that's used, how that's monetized to solve customer problems. In my business, we basically rethought how to deliver banking services around the customer data. And we've made a huge progress in proving that we can deliver the 10x benefit that we've talked about.

LACQUA: What does that mean? Do you sell it to the big banks, because if you look at Uber, Airbnb, it's things that directly impact me as a consumer? But actually Fintech, will it change fundamentally my experience with the bank, is it challenger banks or is it kind of the old way but it's stuff that I don't realize is going?

JENKINS: So I think the trend is going to be that consumers are going to embrace services that make their lives much better. How do you make your life better in banking? Firstly, you make it just easier, all the paperwork and forms you have to get at to get a mortgage take that away. Secondarily, you make it instant because everybody wants their problems solved instantly. Thirdly, you make it more cost effective by better pricing decisions, eliminating things like fraud. And what our platform does is deliver that but we do it through a third party. So we're a B2B2C business. We can do it through banks and we're mostly talking to banks at the moment. We can also do it through people who have digitally engaged customer base.

LACQUA: But, for me, to get a mortgage easier or to get a decision quicker, does it not mean that I have to give up all of my data so the bank can make an informed decision in 2.5 seconds?

JENKINS: Somebody has to take your data, collect it, curate it and put it together in a way that works for you. Now, if you think about how it works today, your data is fragmented and spread across hundreds of different sources, probably thousands of different sources, employment, education, healthcare, financial, all of those things. And those things are assembled rather painfully and slowly today through things like credit bureaus. I mean, credit bureaus have an imperfect snapshot of you as a credit risk. The more you can collect that data and make better decisions, the better they customer will be. At the moment, it's very difficult to do that because the data is so fragmented. But the new technologies allow those things to be collected and curated much more efficiently.

LACQUA: Do you look at Fintech, Jim?

O'NEILL: I think about it a lot. But because part of the many things about the change in (inaudible), certainly my new life as Chairman at Chatham House, it's something I think we should with many other things, be it the forefront of the right thing to do, whatever that is globally. So, yes, it's something I do think about. And before I had my investment trust, I made some personal direct investments and some of the emerging players. So, yes, I assume my trust is to all --

LACQUA: I'm sure they're watching. So I'm sure they are probably trying to do the right thing. Are big banks thinking about this and are they thinking about it in the right way?

JENKINS: Yes. So in the course of my business, I speak to be banks all around the world. I would say, the big change between now and 2.5 years ago is that the banks are now aware of this issue and they are worried about it. And so they're all thinking about how can we transform. They've done a job of innovation and mobile banking is a great example of innovation in banking. But it's painful, it's slow and expensive. Transformation is something completely different. You have to rebuild from scratch. And many banks are thinking about that now.

O'NEILL: There's not the dilemma, right, we're talking (inaudible) big banks, just a shift quickly. It's just really a hard thing to do that.

JENKINS: The only way you can do it is if you take a bunch of resources and put them off to the side and just let them have their head. But as we know from other industries, it's very unusual for incumbents to be able to reinvent themselves.

LACQUA: What does it mean for the banks? Do they have to consolidate? And we also have a story on the Bloomberg talking about transfer-wise now joining the banks in the U.K. payment system. If a lot of these kind of banking services are opened up, where does it leave the big banks?

JENKINS: Well, of course, what's happening is the barriers to entry are massively falling. To support a big bank 10 or 15 years ago, you need to run huge datacenters you don't need to do and you do it in the cloud now. And as those barriers to entry fall, it exposes the flanks of the banks to people who can create better more effective customer experience using technologies. And so what is the response for a bank? I think there are very few things the bank can do. They've got to keep elevating in their core business. But recommendation would be take some resources, set them outside the existing organization and let them build the future, unconstrained by the cultural and other restrictions of the main organization.

LACQUA: Jim, is it impossible to figure out the jobs of tomorrow? I'm thinking of A.I. I'm thinking about the future of transport. I'm thinking of Fintech. How do we train the workforce of today to have jobs in 15 to 20 year?

O'NEILL: I have contradictory views in my own head about this. The biggest one is that I don't think it's right to worry so much about one of the jobs tomorrow. Who would have dreamt 25 years ago that Apple and Google would have been the kind of things that they are today or the kind of employers that we have in areas that are employing a lot of people. (Inaudible) very importantly, the big surprise the past decade in this country, not with all the chaos that's going on, is just how strong employment is. And you could have some of these arguments about job displacements a decade ago.

LACQUA: But certain people feel left out.

O'NEILL: So the flipside is, of course, and I see a lot with my northern powerhouse hat on, when you've got a local community that has been dominated by a big employer that is being arbitraged away in some areas like this, the consequences are a bit like, what will happen when we lost all the pit villages and steel mills in various parts of the country, and dealing with that on a social perspective is tough. So the other part of your life, we need some much more imaginative and more serious focus on skills that don't equate to going to Oxford and Cambridge, in my view.

LACQUA: Which is apprenticeships?

JENKINS: Yes. And as Chair of the Institute for Apprenticeships, that's one of the other things that I work on. I think, Francine, the key to this is not to try and predict the future because you're always wrong. But we do know the skills -- the sorts of skills that people need. People need to be more entrepreneurial. They're living longer and the world of work is changing faster. So they need to be able to re-skill themselves many times in their lives. We know people need to be creative, they need to be able to collaborate, to do things that humans are good at, right, to create new things, new opportunities. And these are areas where we need to build into our educational system. So we need to get our systems aware of that. But I do think there's a huge demand in this country for engineering talent and software. I mean, I've got a software business, I need engineers. They're impossible to hire in London. We need to develop centers of excellence for engineering in places like the north (ph) where we've got fantastic universities, we've got great talent and people love living there. So I am actually quite positive about this for the U.K. if we act now.

LACQUA: All right. But -- I mean, want to study it or they don't want to study it? I guess it's getting people interested in this subject matter, right?

JENKINS: Yes. People think it's just all bits and bytes, but it's not. It's problem solving, right? Now, you do need a certain level of math attainment to write code and do engineering, but it's a fascinating work. And you could be on the forefront of changing huge aspects of our lives.

O'NEILL: Tangentially, getting back to my life in antibiotics, a couple of months ago, I went to open a new antimicrobial resistance research center in a place on the edge, just in Cheshire, South of Manchester. It's on the old AstraZeneca site. But the end of the week, I was there. The number of high paid people working on that site was actually bigger than AstraZeneca's peak. So there's lots of things going on there that relates to the north, so called four prime areas, life sciences. Using modern technology, for example, is a probably enormous future employer of talent would be my guess.

LACQUA: Blockchain, what will blockchain become? How many questions you get about cryptocurrencies? And you always try and kind of bring you back to blockchain.

JENKINS: No. I think crypto is fascinating use case for what is probably going to be the most defining technology over the next hundred years, which is distributed ledger technology. If you think about most of the systems in our life, they rely on centralization. So if you want to make a payment in this country, you go to a system like chats or faster payments, and there's many, many parties in the middle. Using restricted ledger technology, you don't need to do that at all. So it's faster, cheaper, more secure. Now, crypto is just the first incarnation of that. We can debate whether it's going to be a massive that's going to be in future (ph). Personally, I think there is a market for cryptocurrencies. I think the ability to trade, to support international trade with crypto, to take out the friction and the cost that goes along with that is very important and could help global GDP. I also believe that the connection of these technologies, and what Jim referred to a moment ago about biotech, I mean, these technologies don't exist in a vacuum. They come together and they stack on top of each other. Why can we have driverless cars now? It's not just because of tech. it is because you've got 5G coming in, it's because you've got LIDAR and all the radar technologies improving. It's the same here, internet of things, which allows you to track to physical and then finance them along the supply chain combined with a distributed ledger for its huge economic opportunities.

LACQUA: Can regulators keep up?

O'NEILL: Can they ever?

JENKINS: I think that's a genuine question. Because if you think about the internet, nobody really regulates the internet. There's a set of protocols that allow computers to talk to each other. But there isn't a sort of department for the internet globally. And that some of these financial transmission mechanism become global, regulation is going to become increasingly difficult. And it will be a balance between the benefit that these systems bring and the loss of control that nations face.

LACQUA: Antony, who do you think should regulate cryptocurrencies? The G20, there was a push from the European Central Bank and G20 kind of shied away from it. Does it have to be domestic? Do you think it should be regulated?

JENKINS: I think in a way, it's too soon to say. I do think that (inaudible) to self-regulation is going to be incredibly important here, particularly as you say, where regulators are increasingly racing to keep up with the tech. So self-regulation becomes very important. And I think it's a little early to say whether we're going to have an overarching regulatory body for crypto, for example.

LACQUA: Do you think we're --

O'NEILL: Like Antony's answer, I don't, I think, have too strong a view about the right way to do it is dangerous. In fact, part of the problem of regulation, in general, for my adult life is they kind of don't and they come like a battering ram and they end up overregulating yesterday's problems. So obviously we need way -- but if you look at the Facebook, the whole Facebook issue, I mean, clearly, something has got to change. Listening to Antony early, maybe added to one of my beliefs that I have a suspicion that individual might end up having to pay. Facebook's future model might be -- people pay to have access, which would certainly influence some of these issues. But it's very hard to be overly prescriptive is exactly what's the right thing. But the scale of change going on, it will be my guess.

JENKINS: I think they may -- I think you're right, Jim. They might pay but they're going to get much more back in terms of value they don't get because that value --

O'NEILL: By the price mechanism.

JENKINS: Exactly.

O'NEILL: So it is up.

LACQUA: Okay. But where are these -- all of these technology companies, where do you see them going? Does it impact your world? Actually, I know it's kind of like at the margins. But do you see Facebook becoming a bang or because of the concerns we've had about data protection. That's now something that is more unlikely than it was six months ago.

JENKINS: I think it's -- my view is that it's quite unlikely that the big tech companies would want to become banks as we know them because it's a highly regulated space, and frankly, it's a low return space. I mean, when you're at a high returns space, why would you deploy a high capital in a low return space. It wouldn't make any economic sense. But I do think what's interesting is if you accept that data is going to be what drives the future, people who are good at data are going to be good at doing financials. We all go into shopping sites, like Amazon, and these ten recommendations of things you brought before. That's a very, very early version of what could happen with your financial life. For most people, their financial life is a tedious thing that they don't really want to spend time on. If you could have an intelligent agent do that for you, wouldn't we all love that? And if we see --

O'NEILL: I wouldn't be surprised in the wealth management space where it's also not super returns but at least it's more stable and relatively easy to get returns. So I have a suspicion that some of them might get into that part of finance. But standard banking is too low returns.

JENKINS: The separation of the customer relationship from the balance sheet, that's the key. And if you've seen that in other areas, like shopping, like content, that you don't have to make all the content to sell it to customers when you position it at exactly the right time for them.

LACQUA: Antony, thank you so much. Antony Jenkins there, former Chief Executive of Barclays and Founder and Executive Chairman of 10x Futures Technology. Jim O'Neill stays with us and we'll be talking a little bit about microbiology.

Now, let's talk about Jim O'Neill's new book coming out, actually came out on Thursday, Superbugs: An Arms Race Against Bacteria. Still with us Jim O'Neill and Antony Jenkins. Jim, this is something that you've just actually been working on for quite some time. And your premise is that we're oversubscribing antibiotics, which means that we have then these superbugs that we can't treat.

O'NEILL: So there're ten different areas and it's -- we don't have time to go into them all. But at the core of it is we treat these things like sweets. We have to learn, in my generation, that they are a miracle cure but only if you use them when we have a bacterial infection, in the U.K., the U.S., where we have decent health systems, at least 30% over prescription. And going back to what we've chatted about before and where Antony is in the middle of, we need modern technology through diagnostics to force and our doctors to not have an antibiotic unless there is clear evidence that it's necessarily. As an aside (ph), it will dramatically reduce the pressure on the health service.

LACQUA: Okay. So is the U.S. the biggest defender? And actually, how much do these technologies cost? It all boils down to NHS, how much money you have.

O'NEILL: In food, the U.S. is a horrific offender. Europe is one of the few areas where Europe is better than the U.S. in most things in life. In China and India, they're bad on both.

LACQUA: And we have the technology.

JENKINS: Yes. And there's definitely tech sold (ph) for this. I mean, I've got a colleague who works for me. He used to work in health centers. They came up with an A.I. program that could save 40,000 stroke deaths a year. So 40,000 lives saved, but also think of the save in resources against those. So if we can use technology to be more predictive, then we don't need to go down at (inaudible).

LACQUA: Antony and Jim, thank you so much for your time. We'll have plenty more in this book and, of course, treasuries. This is Bloomberg.

[*]

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JIM O'NEILL, FORMER COMMERCIAL SECRETARY, U.K. TREASURY; VIRAJ PATEL, FX STRATEGIST, ING BANK; AND ANTONY JENKINS, CHAIRMAN, BITC; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

MAY 01, 2018

Jim, this is something that you've just actually been working on for quite some time. And your premise is that we're oversubscribing antibiotics, which means that we have then these superbugs that we can't treat.

O'NEILL: So there're ten different areas and it's -- we don't have time to go into them all. But at the core of it is we treat these things like sweets. We have to learn, in my generation, that they are a miracle cure but only if you use them when we have a bacterial infection, in the U.K., the U.S., where we have decent health systems, at least 30% over prescription. And going back to what we've chatted about before and where Antony is in the middle of, we need modern technology through diagnostics to force and our doctors to not have an antibiotic unless there is clear evidence that it's necessarily. As an aside (ph), it will dramatically reduce the pressure on the health service.

LACQUA: Okay. So is the U.S. the biggest defender? And actually, how much do these technologies cost? It all boils down to NHS, how much money you have.

O'NEILL: In food, the U.S. is a horrific offender. Europe is one of the few areas where Europe is better than the U.S. in most things in life. In China and India, they're bad on both.

LACQUA: And we have the technology.

JENKINS: Yes. And there's definitely tech sold (ph) for this. I mean, I've got a colleague who works for me. He used to work in health centers. They came up with an A.I. program that could save 40,000 stroke deaths a year. So 40,000 lives saved, but also think of the save in resources against those. So if we can use technology to be more predictive, then we don't need to go down at (inaudible).

LACQUA: Antony and Jim, thank you so much for your time. We'll have plenty more in this book and, of course, treasuries. This is Bloomberg.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JIM O'NEILL, FORMER COMMERCIAL SECRETARY, U.K. TREASURY; VIRAJ PATEL, FX STRATEGIST, ING BANK; AND ANTONY JENKINS, CHAIRMAN, BITC; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

MAY 01, 2018

SPEAKERS: JIM O'NEILL, FORMER COMMERCIAL SECRETARY, U.K. TREASURY

VIRAJ PATEL, FX STRATEGIST, ING BANK

ANTONY JENKINS, CHAIRMAN, BITC

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us now for the hour, Viraj Patel, FX Strategist at ING Bank, and Jim O'Neill, former Goldman Sachs Asset Management Chairman, Former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury and the incoming Chair of Chatham House, and also actually author of this book which I want to talk to you a little bit about because it does also have an impact, of course, on NHS spending, and therefore, economic Superbugs: An Arms Race Against Bacteria, and this came out last Thursday.

JIM O'NEILL, FORMER COMMERCIAL SECRETARY, U.K. TREASURY: Yes.

LACQUA: All right. Trade, let's start with trade. Jim, how much focus do you do on trade? And when you take over as Chairman of Chatham House, how much do you think -- how many lectures or how many sessions and seminars will there be on U.S.-China relationships?

O'NEILL: A lot. Judging by the emails I've received with the news about me becoming Chair, a large number of them have got to do with issues about China, especially China's engagement with the rest of the world. So that's one of the reasons I think I was asked to do it, so it's hugely important. It's hugely important.

LACQUA: Viraj, when you look at the currency markets and you kind of fold in to geopolitics and a bit of trade, do we just assume right now that actually the allies will be exempted? It was kind of -- we thought it was an America-first policy. And then as time progresses, President Trump is kind of backtracking, saying, but you're an ally, you'll be fine. You're an ally, you'll be fine.

VIRAJ PATEL, FX STRATEGIST, ING BANK: Yes. But it's a thorn in the side of FX markets. So I think this is only in the mid placed (ph) until June the 1st. So you've always got this perennial uncertainty. But what it's done is -- it's ambiguous. It's not some of the global as global animal spirits started those pro-cyclical currencies, like the euro, that have been benefitting on sort of cycles. Now, that's -- the idea there is that can we look through that? Will investors -- will activity, really activity look through that and sort of the second quarter activity news (ph), so it bounce back. We get on back on track with the normalization story that fuelled the euro sort of upward swing, that's our base case, that's what we're looking forward.

LACQUA: Jim, do you worry that global growth has peaked? And I don't whether it's a trade question or whether it's just, in general, we kind of reached the (inaudible).

O'NEILL: With the usual caveat, one among here that I don't look at this stuff as much or as closely as they do, it is still in my veins, so I do. And actually probably with Chatham House, I'll probably look at it more. It looks that way. I mean, these five things I say every time I'm here, I look at every month whenever I see those five things and I think I know exactly what's going on with the world and both slowed. Some of it's actually surprisingly in Europe, most of it. And I don't really understand that. It's not from the lead leading indicators that I'm used to. It wasn't predictable that Europe had just suddenly slowed, so it could weather related. I think here in the U.K., a lot of it is almost definitely weather related. So I wouldn't -- I think today, we get the PMI, don't we? It would be very interesting to see if you've got any kind of bounce back in some places, because I'm suspicious that the slowdown is temporary, but it certainly looks like the world has slowed since (inaudible).

LACQUA: Yes. Viraj, I think last time you were on, we were talking about the German economy overheating, and suddenly we're talking about a possible slowdown. Do you think that economy has peaked and what does that mean for euro?

PATEL: Yes, it's kind of with (ph) because I think we went 2018 with sort of overexuberant expectations. So the economy has underperformed and underperformed a bit more than we expected relative to high expectations. What you now look at and what we look at as sort of the (inaudible) for the Eurozone, that's at its sort of three, four-year low. So the only way that we can see that sort of worsening is if this is a more structural sort of slowdown in the Eurozone economy. But if it's cyclical, we would expect the expectations to adjust (ph) lower and surge (ph) and in line with the data. And that, in itself, should keep the euro supported. So I think the euro is probably running on hot air at the start of the year but were back to sort of more at normal levels, I would say, but not that -- nothing that should take the euro any further though in our view.

LACQUA: Yes. What does that mean for central banks? So the central banks kind of -- we've been talking about the normalizing for quite some time. Do you think, Jim, they need the arsenal to deal with the next crisis or should they temperate down if we're seeing the slowdown kind of (inaudible)?

O'NEILL: Well, I think it's a bit of a tag team battle, right? So as a couple of them have indicated recently, they want to get rates up when they can. So when the inevitable next problem comes, the (inaudible) will cut them. But the residue of what's happened in the past decade and the first signs of a slip, especially if it turns out to be more than just a couple of months blip, then I think the panic thing for some will set in pretty quickly. So I think it's going to be a tricky call about the (inaudible) of how -- outside the U.S., how some of these guys move in the next month or so?

LACQUA: What do you expect from the fed, Viraj, and what does it mean for dollar overall?

PATEL: We think the fed story is probably priced in, right? The mutual rate, when you look at the short end of the curve, it's there or thereabout with the sort of terminal or the end of the fed tightening. So 25 basis points here or there just doesn't set the dollar trend unless we start to see inflation in the U.S. escape out of control such that markets -- the consensus shifts above mutual pricing of the fed cycle, we don't think that that's going to happen soon. It's really a story about the rest of the world. That's where the FX markets will take the key from going forward.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you both. Both will stick around. Jim O'Neill, Former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury and incoming Chairman of Chatham House, and Viraj Patel from ING Bank.

Still with us, Viraj Patel from ING and Jim O'Neill, former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury and incoming Chairman of Chatham House. Once you become Chairman, we're going to lose all the other titles and make it hosrter.

O'NEILL: It sounds very grand, doesn't it?

LACQUA: It does sound very grand, and, of course, the House of Lords. Lord Jim, when you look at Iran, is it geopolitics story or is it an old story?

O'NEILL: I don't know, obviously a bit of both. It seems to me there's all sorts of tactical things going on as well as strategic things. Yes, you imagine that the U.S. were eager for the Israelis to say what they just did (ph) today. And obviously in hindsight, it looks like the French and German visits to Washington were heavily designed to influence this. Very interesting for Macron, right? How does he -- he's positioned himself as this globally outward guy, at the same time, a big (inaudible) of Donald Trump's, intriguing. So as he made a really smart (inaudible) that he can rescue some kind of an Iranian deal. It's tough but --

LACQUA: But, Jim, when you saw headline cross, right, from the Israeli Prime Minister, who was he speaking to? Was it --

O'NEILL: I think he was speaking to all of us. I think he was speaking to the international media and trying to perhaps get the U.S. media more --

LACQUA: To pick up on it?

O'NEILL: Yes, I would guess. But underlying, one of -- I remember being at some Middle Eastern -- a huge Middle Eastern oil event last autumn. And because of the strength of the world economy, for some reason, I was asked about oil in this panel. I said, I think it's more likely to be 80 than 40 in one year's time. And that was without any of these. So it seems to me notwithstanding what we've said earlier about a bit of a slowing of the world. The world has picked up so much in so many places. The oil market is in a position that is right to price in some kind of risk of a new disruption because it's probably that outside (ph), unless we see a lot more slowing in the world economy, I would have thought.

LACQUA: Yes. And, Viraj, we did see that the oil price basically spiked up. Did we see similar moves for oil currencies?

PATEL: Well, you saw the Canadian dollar sort of have a bit of support. But I think when you're at these elevated levels, the marginal follow-through is quite limited especially for the FX markets which kind of takes its cue right now from the equity and bond market. The oil market is kind of a second or tertiary flatter (ph) for these currencies.

LACQUA: Okay. How do you see it panning out? I mean, again, it's so unpredictable, right? First, because you have President Trump having to decide on the accord by May 12. But does -- how much? Is it difficult to price in these big geopolitics moves in currency markets away from the dollar (ph)?

O'NEILL: That's what all these guys get paid for.

LACQUA: (Inaudible) to do it?

O'NEILL: I used to do that in first (inaudible.)

LACQUA: But is it a nightmare?

O'NEILL: That's what it's all about.

LACQUA: It might have changed, right, in the last 30 years. Now, the world is much more complicated or am I -- or is it not?

PATEL: It's interchanging, right? But there is, to some extent, the short- term risk premium priced into the dollar. That's why it's been disconnected from rates differentials with pretty much six months, six to 12 months. I think the idea now is just kind of how much can U.S. political uncertainty elevate to another. And I think what we're seeing is sort of a consolidation in that uncertainty, but it needs to move massively one way or the other. All these short-term stories don't take us in either direction.

LACQUA: But we used to have Kissinger. Now, you have President Trump that you have to model. I mean, how do you --

O'NEILL: Clearly, we've not had a President quite like this. But this idea that we're in some world of uncertainty, I mean, it's likely rubbish from what I can see. It's always -- that's what makes markets potentially interesting for somebody that's good at them. But you cannot try to anticipate and make some kind of risk adjusted debt which way it's going to go. I mean, remember if I go back -- my pre-Goldman days arriving in Q8, the morning after the U.S. had just bombed Iraq. That's what's --

LACQUA: Good. No, you're right. But then we saw the Koreas, right, on Friday, you saw the Peninsula. Then you see Russia and the role they're trying to play in the Middle East. It just feels like we could be going through a massive shift without really realizing the consequences five years down the line.

O'NEILL: I mean, there is lots of media attention to unknown uncertainties. But this big issue about known unknowns and unknown unknowns and it's a fact of life. I'm reminded as you asked me of another book that I'd reviewed actually recently. Remember Hans Rosling, a posthumous book called Factfulness, which is fantastic. Because it points out just how well the world has done the past 20-30 years despite all of these things we all worry about and (inaudible), including Trump and Brexit. There're a lot of good things that -- such as people living longer and people trying to give attention to getting new antibiotics. And so, yes, they start to worry about it. But for me, for the financial markets, that's why these guys get paid a lot of money to kind of deal with that. Otherwise, what's the point of the (inaudible)?

LACQUA: Well, let's see if they're making money in Brexit. Let's give it to Brexit. Let's change the focus. The U.K. is proposing a new plan to kick start stalled Brexit talks. It's hoping to make progress on the issue of the Irish border when negotiations resume in Brussels tomorrow. Speaking at the Milken Institute conference in California, the former Prime Minister and remain campaigner, Tony Blair, told me Bloomberg, when it comes to the customs union, there's no easy solution.

Okay. Let's get back to Jim and Viraj. Viraj, let me bring you over to a chart that Hillary Clark, the queen of charts, have kind of made for me this morning, and this is looking at fair value of sterling. We have a Bloomberg economics pound fair value estimate. In white, we have IMF U.K. real effective exchange rate. I mean, what do you look at? Do you just look at trade weighted?

PATEL: Trade weighted in terms of -- for the sterling sort of appreciation in the short-term. But I think when we look at sort of fair value, fair value is the black box right now when the Brexit sort of end state is still highly unknown. So I think for us, what we see is this is gravitational pull, which is sterling is cheap. One of the reasons why we've kind of seen it as like a long run sort of a move higher. And you're seeing is a structural repricing of the Brexit tail risk, that the tail risk risk premium of a cliff edge Brexit in 2019. That's been postponed thanks to sort of the transition deal. But we're still caught between where it ends. And I think it just wants to, especially against, say, a clearer currencies, like the dollar, which is the sort of their trend. It wants to gradually move higher. The Bank of England story is a short-term story. It doesn't actually affect it from a long run perspective. That's not what is keeping sort of the pound at these elevated depressed levels.

LACQUA: Okay. I do want to ask you about Governor Carney and the label that he's got, fairly or unfairly, but the unreliable boyfriend. But first of all, do you think it will all play out in parliament? But actually we talk about Brexit but the people.

O'NEILL: My colleagues goes a bit at first last night in the house.

LACQUA: They did. But will they decide yes or no, actually, Brexit goes through in the end?

O'NEILL: It seems to me that there is a growing appetite, although the most passionate Brexiteers are going to fight it, for some kind of extension of the customs union going on. Last night though takes some of the attention away from that in a way but it brings it more to the realities of what (inaudible) tactics are and notwithstanding Amber Rudd's disappearance, so the cabinet balance has shifted a bit. But I smell that some kind of extension or underlying replication of the customs union is the way that things are shifting.

LACQUA: Okay. In 30 seconds, do you expect to hike from BOE in May?

PATEL: Not officially, but it's not dead and buried. I think it's just more about sentiment just coming back on when -- it's moving in line with data. Data will drive the pound, not political directions.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you both for joining us. Viraj Patel, FX Strategist at ING Bank. They're on some pretty bold pound moves in the past. And Jim O'Neill, former U.K. Commercial Secretary to the Treasury, incoming Chairman of Chatham, stays with us.

Jim O'Neill, as we look at these numbers and we're talking a little bit about Brexit, does that actually have an impact? I mean, should Governor Carney look through or are we going to see a slowdown because of Brexit?

O'NEILL: It's like days gone by for me. That should be on the trade floor talking to the (inaudible).

LACQUA: Which you're going straightaway, right?

O'NEILL: I am slightly surprised and my immediate reaction to that is slightly boring (ph). Because if it was weather related, we should be getting some stabilization or bounce backs. So that is -- if I were an MPC voting member and had been thinking about a hike, I might be backing off a bit.

LACQUA: Yes. And so just to put that into context, the U.K. manufacturing slows more than forecast. It's now at a 17-month low and actually does seem to be adding two signs that the poor first quarter performance of the U.K. could actually persist. So we'll be back with Jim O'Neill and we also have the former Chief Executive of Barclays with us to talk Fintech shortly. 437 LACQUA: We're now joined by Antony Jenkins. He's the former Chief Executive of Barclays, the current Chief Executive of 10x Future Technology, a Fintech firm that aims to use technology to redefine how banks operate. And still with us, Jim O'Neill, former Commercial Secretary to the U.K. Treasury and incoming Chairman for Chatham House. Antony, thank you so much for joining us. What exactly are you working on? So we have you regularly on the program every three to four months. What's fundamentally changed from the last time you were on? You were kind of going deeper into technologies that you really think will transform the way banks operate.

ANTONY JENKINS, CHAIRMAN, BITC: It's really fascinating. 2.5 years ago, I gave a speech actually at Chatham House, which Jim is now Chair, and I talked about uber moments and financial services, moments where there was transformation. And since that speech 2.5 years ago, we've seen I think two of them. So the first is in the growth of mobile banking, which has caused a phenomenal drop in branch traffic, and that's a problem for the big banks because they have that cost base to sustain even while customers are going elsewhere. Secondarily, we've seen a huge rise in crypto. Now, crypto itself is a huge topic, whether subcategories of that, like the ICO market, which I think is very interesting. And I think the third uber moment that we're going to see is about data, who controls data, how that's used, how that's monetized to solve customer problems. In my business, we basically rethought how to deliver banking services around the customer data. And we've made a huge progress in proving that we can deliver the 10x benefit that we've talked about.

LACQUA: What does that mean? Do you sell it to the big banks, because if you look at Uber, Airbnb, it's things that directly impact me as a consumer? But actually Fintech, will it change fundamentally my experience with the bank, is it challenger banks or is it kind of the old way but it's stuff that I don't realize is going?

JENKINS: So I think the trend is going to be that consumers are going to embrace services that make their lives much better. How do you make your life better in banking? Firstly, you make it just easier, all the paperwork and forms you have to get at to get a mortgage take that away. Secondarily, you make it instant because everybody wants their problems solved instantly. Thirdly, you make it more cost effective by better pricing decisions, eliminating things like fraud. And what our platform does is deliver that but we do it through a third party. So we're a B2B2C business. We can do it through banks and we're mostly talking to banks at the moment. We can also do it through people who have digitally engaged customer base.

LACQUA: But, for me, to get a mortgage easier or to get a decision quicker, does it not mean that I have to give up all of my data so the bank can make an informed decision in 2.5 seconds?

JENKINS: Somebody has to take your data, collect it, curate it and put it together in a way that works for you. Now, if you think about how it works today, your data is fragmented and spread across hundreds of different sources, probably thousands of different sources, employment, education, healthcare, financial, all of those things. And those things are assembled rather painfully and slowly today through things like credit bureaus. I mean, credit bureaus have an imperfect snapshot of you as a credit risk. The more you can collect that data and make better decisions, the better they customer will be. At the moment, it's very difficult to do that because the data is so fragmented. But the new technologies allow those things to be collected and curated much more efficiently.

LACQUA: Do you look at Fintech, Jim?

O'NEILL: I think about it a lot. But because part of the many things about the change in (inaudible), certainly my new life as Chairman at Chatham House, it's something I think we should with many other things, be it the forefront of the right thing to do, whatever that is globally. So, yes, it's something I do think about. And before I had my investment trust, I made some personal direct investments and some of the emerging players. So, yes, I assume my trust is to all --

LACQUA: I'm sure they're watching. So I'm sure they are probably trying to do the right thing. Are big banks thinking about this and are they thinking about it in the right way?

JENKINS: Yes. So in the course of my business, I speak to be banks all around the world. I would say, the big change between now and 2.5 years ago is that the banks are now aware of this issue and they are worried about it. And so they're all thinking about how can we transform. They've done a job of innovation and mobile banking is a great example of innovation in banking. But it's painful, it's slow and expensive. Transformation is something completely different. You have to rebuild from scratch. And many banks are thinking about that now.

O'NEILL: There's not the dilemma, right, we're talking (inaudible) big banks, just a shift quickly. It's just really a hard thing to do that.

JENKINS: The only way you can do it is if you take a bunch of resources and put them off to the side and just let them have their head. But as we know from other industries, it's very unusual for incumbents to be able to reinvent themselves.

LACQUA: What does it mean for the banks? Do they have to consolidate? And we also have a story on the Bloomberg talking about transfer-wise now joining the banks in the U.K. payment system. If a lot of these kind of banking services are opened up, where does it leave the big banks?

JENKINS: Well, of course, what's happening is the barriers to entry are massively falling. To support a big bank 10 or 15 years ago, you need to run huge datacenters you don't need to do and you do it in the cloud now. And as those barriers to entry fall, it exposes the flanks of the banks to people who can create better more effective customer experience using technologies. And so what is the response for a bank? I think there are very few things the bank can do. They've got to keep elevating in their core business. But recommendation would be take some resources, set them outside the existing organization and let them build the future, unconstrained by the cultural and other restrictions of the main organization.

LACQUA: Jim, is it impossible to figure out the jobs of tomorrow? I'm thinking of A.I. I'm thinking about the future of transport. I'm thinking of Fintech. How do we train the workforce of today to have jobs in 15 to 20 year?

O'NEILL: I have contradictory views in my own head about this. The biggest one is that I don't think it's right to worry so much about one of the jobs tomorrow. Who would have dreamt 25 years ago that Apple and Google would have been the kind of things that they are today or the kind of employers that we have in areas that are employing a lot of people. (Inaudible) very importantly, the big surprise the past decade in this country, not with all the chaos that's going on, is just how strong employment is. And you could have some of these arguments about job displacements a decade ago.

LACQUA: But certain people feel left out.

O'NEILL: So the flipside is, of course, and I see a lot with my northern powerhouse hat on, when you've got a local community that has been dominated by a big employer that is being arbitraged away in some areas like this, the consequences are a bit like, what will happen when we lost all the pit villages and steel mills in various parts of the country, and dealing with that on a social perspective is tough. So the other part of your life, we need some much more imaginative and more serious focus on skills that don't equate to going to Oxford and Cambridge, in my view.

LACQUA: Which is apprenticeships?

JENKINS: Yes. And as Chair of the Institute for Apprenticeships, that's one of the other things that I work on. I think, Francine, the key to this is not to try and predict the future because you're always wrong. But we do know the skills -- the sorts of skills that people need. People need to be more entrepreneurial. They're living longer and the world of work is changing faster. So they need to be able to re-skill themselves many times in their lives. We know people need to be creative, they need to be able to collaborate, to do things that humans are good at, right, to create new things, new opportunities. And these are areas where we need to build into our educational system. So we need to get our systems aware of that. But I do think there's a huge demand in this country for engineering talent and software. I mean, I've got a software business, I need engineers. They're impossible to hire in London. We need to develop centers of excellence for engineering in places like the north (ph) where we've got fantastic universities, we've got great talent and people love living there. So I am actually quite positive about this for the U.K. if we act now.

LACQUA: All right. But -- I mean, want to study it or they don't want to study it? I guess it's getting people interested in this subject matter, right?

JENKINS: Yes. People think it's just all bits and bytes, but it's not. It's problem solving, right? Now, you do need a certain level of math attainment to write code and do engineering, but it's a fascinating work. And you could be on the forefront of changing huge aspects of our lives.

O'NEILL: Tangentially, getting back to my life in antibiotics, a couple of months ago, I went to open a new antimicrobial resistance research center in a place on the edge, just in Cheshire, South of Manchester. It's on the old AstraZeneca site. But the end of the week, I was there. The number of high paid people working on that site was actually bigger than AstraZeneca's peak. So there's lots of things going on there that relates to the north, so called four prime areas, life sciences. Using modern technology, for example, is a probably enormous future employer of talent would be my guess.

LACQUA: Blockchain, what will blockchain become? How many questions you get about cryptocurrencies? And you always try and kind of bring you back to blockchain.

JENKINS: No. I think crypto is fascinating use case for what is probably going to be the most defining technology over the next hundred years, which is distributed ledger technology. If you think about most of the systems in our life, they rely on centralization. So if you want to make a payment in this country, you go to a system like chats or faster payments, and there's many, many parties in the middle. Using restricted ledger technology, you don't need to do that at all. So it's faster, cheaper, more secure. Now, crypto is just the first incarnation of that. We can debate whether it's going to be a massive that's going to be in future (ph). Personally, I think there is a market for cryptocurrencies. I think the ability to trade, to support international trade with crypto, to take out the friction and the cost that goes along with that is very important and could help global GDP. I also believe that the connection of these technologies, and what Jim referred to a moment ago about biotech, I mean, these technologies don't exist in a vacuum. They come together and they stack on top of each other. Why can we have driverless cars now? It's not just because of tech. it is because you've got 5G coming in, it's because you've got LIDAR and all the radar technologies improving. It's the same here, internet of things, which allows you to track to physical and then finance them along the supply chain combined with a distributed ledger for its huge economic opportunities.

LACQUA: Can regulators keep up?

O'NEILL: Can they ever?

JENKINS: I think that's a genuine question. Because if you think about the internet, nobody really regulates the internet. There's a set of protocols that allow computers to talk to each other. But there isn't a sort of department for the internet globally. And that some of these financial transmission mechanism become global, regulation is going to become increasingly difficult. And it will be a balance between the benefit that these systems bring and the loss of control that nations face.

LACQUA: Antony, who do you think should regulate cryptocurrencies? The G20, there was a push from the European Central Bank and G20 kind of shied away from it. Does it have to be domestic? Do you think it should be regulated?

JENKINS: I think in a way, it's too soon to say. I do think that (inaudible) to self-regulation is going to be incredibly important here, particularly as you say, where regulators are increasingly racing to keep up with the tech. So self-regulation becomes very important. And I think it's a little early to say whether we're going to have an overarching regulatory body for crypto, for example.

LACQUA: Do you think we're --

O'NEILL: Like Antony's answer, I don't, I think, have too strong a view about the right way to do it is dangerous. In fact, part of the problem of regulation, in general, for my adult life is they kind of don't and they come like a battering ram and they end up overregulating yesterday's problems. So obviously we need way -- but if you look at the Facebook, the whole Facebook issue, I mean, clearly, something has got to change. Listening to Antony early, maybe added to one of my beliefs that I have a suspicion that individual might end up having to pay. Facebook's future model might be -- people pay to have access, which would certainly influence some of these issues. But it's very hard to be overly prescriptive is exactly what's the right thing. But the scale of change going on, it will be my guess.

JENKINS: I think they may -- I think you're right, Jim. They might pay but they're going to get much more back in terms of value they don't get because that value --

O'NEILL: By the price mechanism.

JENKINS: Exactly.

O'NEILL: So it is up.

LACQUA: Okay. But where are these -- all of these technology companies, where do you see them going? Does it impact your world? Actually, I know it's kind of like at the margins. But do you see Facebook becoming a bang or because of the concerns we've had about data protection. That's now something that is more unlikely than it was six months ago.

JENKINS: I think it's -- my view is that it's quite unlikely that the big tech companies would want to become banks as we know them because it's a highly regulated space, and frankly, it's a low return space. I mean, when you're at a high returns space, why would you deploy a high capital in a low return space. It wouldn't make any economic sense. But I do think what's interesting is if you accept that data is going to be what drives the future, people who are good at data are going to be good at doing financials. We all go into shopping sites, like Amazon, and these ten recommendations of things you brought before. That's a very, very early version of what could happen with your financial life. For most people, their financial life is a tedious thing that they don't really want to spend time on. If you could have an intelligent agent do that for you, wouldn't we all love that? And if we see --

O'NEILL: I wouldn't be surprised in the wealth management space where it's also not super returns but at least it's more stable and relatively easy to get returns. So I have a suspicion that some of them might get into that part of finance. But standard banking is too low returns.

JENKINS: The separation of the customer relationship from the balance sheet, that's the key. And if you've seen that in other areas, like shopping, like content, that you don't have to make all the content to sell it to customers when you position it at exactly the right time for them.

LACQUA: Antony, thank you so much. Antony Jenkins there, former Chief Executive of Barclays and Founder and Executive Chairman of 10x Futures Technology. Jim O'Neill stays with us and we'll be talking a little bit about microbiology.

Now, let's talk about Jim O'Neill's new book coming out, actually came out on Thursday, Superbugs: An Arms Race Against Bacteria. Still with us Jim O'Neill and Antony Jenkins. Jim, this is something that you've just actually been working on for quite some time. And your premise is that we're oversubscribing antibiotics, which means that we have then these superbugs that we can't treat.

O'NEILL: So there're ten different areas and it's -- we don't have time to go into them all. But at the core of it is we treat these things like sweets. We have to learn, in my generation, that they are a miracle cure but only if you use them when we have a bacterial infection, in the U.K., the U.S., where we have decent health systems, at least 30% over prescription. And going back to what we've chatted about before and where Antony is in the middle of, we need modern technology through diagnostics to force and our doctors to not have an antibiotic unless there is clear evidence that it's necessarily. As an aside (ph), it will dramatically reduce the pressure on the health service.

LACQUA: Okay. So is the U.S. the biggest defender? And actually, how much do these technologies cost? It all boils down to NHS, how much money you have.

O'NEILL: In food, the U.S. is a horrific offender. Europe is one of the few areas where Europe is better than the U.S. in most things in life. In China and India, they're bad on both.

LACQUA: And we have the technology.

JENKINS: Yes. And there's definitely tech sold (ph) for this. I mean, I've got a colleague who works for me. He used to work in health centers. They came up with an A.I. program that could save 40,000 stroke deaths a year. So 40,000 lives saved, but also think of the save in resources against those. So if we can use technology to be more predictive, then we don't need to go down at (inaudible).

LACQUA: Antony and Jim, thank you so much for your time. We'll have plenty more in this book and, of course, treasuries. This is Bloomberg.

[*]

Asia’s richest man Mukesh Ambani changed India's mobile market forever when he launched the operator Reliance Jio three years ago. Now he's to attempt the same for broadband, according to Benjamin Parkin in Mumbai.

Reliance's service, launched this month, promises ultrafast speeds, lower prices and even free TVs for annual subscribers. India’s fragmented broadband market seems ripe for the taking. Reliance Jio plans to compete with existing providers such as Bharti Airtel and sign up new users, with an initial target of 20m homes and 15m businesses.

This might appear small fry compared to the huge changes Jio brought to India’s mobile market. Since launching in 2016, it has attracted 340m customers, forced some incumbents like Vodafone to consolidate and others, like his brother Anil’s Reliance Communications, out of the sector altogether. Read more

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. Apple TV+ is already into losses
Apple has lost longtime board director Bob Iger, with Walt Disney’s chief executive resigning  ahead of his Disney Plus streaming service competing with Apple's Netflix rival from November. Goldman Sachs said it also expects Apple to lose about a quarter of its market value over the next year as its profits take a hit from the accounting method the company will use for Apple TV+.

2. Last reel for MoviePass
Hold the popcorn. MoviePass's questionable business model and the response by cinema chains to have their own all-you-can-watch passes appear to have put paid to the $9.95 a month service. Parent company Helios & Matheson Analytics shut down MoviePass, possibly for good on Saturday, saying it would explore strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the group in its entirety.

3. Qualcomm pays $3.1bn for key 5G tech
The leading mobile chipmaker has bought out TDK's interest in Singapore-based    RF360. It's a Qualcomm subsidiary that makes   Radio Frequency Front End (RFFE) components, which link up with smartphone antennas to help them connect to mobile networks. The RF Front End has become a key area with the higher speed and power demands of 5G and Qualcomm taking full control of RF360 makes good strategic sense as it seeks to offer complete, integrated chip packages and increase customers' dependency on its products.

4. Little Tech makes up 10% of Big Tech revenues
Tech start-ups spent $44bn on advertising and cloud computing from Facebook, Google and Amazon last year, according to new estimates that underline the growing economic clout of venture-capital-backed businesses. Research by the hedge fund Bridgewater found that spending by private tech start-ups made up about 10 per cent of the revenue of tech giants.

5. Jurisprudence for the mind in a neurotech world
Neural interface technology may make it hard to define where humans end and computers begin. It will demand new legal rights, writes John Thornhill,  such as the right to refuse your brain being activity monitored or its data shared, brainwashing should be banned and your personal identity should not be compromised. The FT View warns that neural implants which make the users smarter but which are only accessible to the wealthy could further entrench inequality, creating a permanent “augmented” elite.

Tech Week Ahead

Monday Facebook is being questioned today on its proposed Libra coin project by global regulators after a weekend in which EU finance ministers meeting in Helsinki expressed concern about the financial stability implications of the project. Representatives of Libra will meet officials from 26 central banks, including the Federal Reserve and the Bank of England, in Basel. Benoît Coeuré of the European Central Bank, who will chair the meeting, warned that “the bar for regulatory approval will be very high” for Libra to operate in the EU. 

Tuesday 
Judges in Luxembourg will hear  arguments in the court battle over the European Commission’s finding that Apple and Ireland created an “artificial” profit arrangement enabling the iPhone maker to pay a tax rate of less than 1 per cent. Apple will seek to convince the EU’s second-highest court to overturn an EU order to pay €13bn in back taxes to Ireland.

Creative software publisher Adobe will report fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market close.

Wednesday
Alphabet, Facebook and Twitter are scheduled to testify before a US Senate panel on efforts by social media firms to remove violent content from online platforms. The hearing of the Senate Commerce Committee follows growing concern in Congress about the use of social media by people committing mass shootings and other violent acts.

Thursday
Huawei will launch its Mate 30 in Munich, but the Android smartphone may not have Google apps and services.

Tech tools — Sonos Move and Port

Sonos moved from its own mesh network to WiFi to feed music to rooms around the home. Now it's gone beyond that with its first portable Bluetooth speaker, Sonos Move. It can still be linked to your Sonos network in the house, but once outside, Bluetooth can take over, along with Alexa or Google Assistant, for this weather-resistant, battery-powered $399 speaker. Sonos has also   launched Port, the successor to its Connect product, for connecting up your turntable and regular stereo system to a Sonos network.
