Nov 21, 2019( IPKat Weblog: http://ipkitten.blogspot.com Delivered by Newstex)   https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ni_aFjn6hBI/XdaD4O9IN0I/AAAAAAAAGmc/hrj7dt5JteoUR0lGrQ1eTODjKRWSx3LcQCLcBGAsYHQ/s1600/Hon%2BDiane%2BWood.jpgEvery Halloween, if the moon is right, the AmeriKat ventures west to the windy city of Chicago to take part in the UIC John Marshall Law School Annual IP Conference [1]organized by the ever energetic Professor Daryl Lim[2]. This year marked its 63rd Annual IP Conference. But this year the moon wasn't quite right, so instead some Kat friends appeared in Chicago. Having arrived in an unexpected Halloween snow storm,Amy Crouch (Simmons ...mmons[3], London) was ready to report and excited to be speaking on the afternoon patents panel session.

Over to Amy: "After a rousing introduction from Daryl and Susan Posner (Provost UIC), the conference was opened by a keynote address from Hon. Diane Wood (U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit) on the topic of 'Antitrust ...: Does it Need to be Retooled?' Chief Judge Wood explained that, in her view, there are reforms that could be helpful to rejuvenate the intersection between IP and Antitrust law, particularly on the procedural side, but also in some substantive respects. The question to be asked is: has the right balance been struck to date between intervention and restraint? To date the approach taken, whilst not being completely hands off, has been fairly cautious which begs the question as to whether that has been a mistake for 21st century industries. Whilst there are things that can be done to preserve competition as it is in the market, once a tight oligopoly is established, the tools for fixing that are quite limited. This is true in relation to both conventional property and IP. IP is of course a type of property; it is simply harder to define, but for the purposes of antitrust the same analysis is applied: agencies do not presume that IP creates power in the antitrust context, rather it depends on the usual criteria. Importantly, IP is a whole and should be considered that way. However, that is not how it is considered procedurally; where instead patents are carved off into one corner and everything else is dealt with separately. A choppy system is created as patent appeals are dealt with by the Federal Circuit, whereas anything else goes to the state Appeal Courts. This means that all types of cases that deal with patents more generally don't go to the Federal Circuit, for example licensing disputes which end up in the regular Appeal Courts. Another lacuna is created by the fact that the statue dictates that 'compulsory' counter claims for patents fall under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Federal Circuit, whereas 'permissive' counter claims go to the regional courts. Chief Judge Wood was of the view that this should change so that only one Court has authority over any one patent and that choice should be optional to allow the parties to decide the Court. This would allow the development of different thinking in the Courts. Statistics show that the Supreme Court has suffered from a lack of diversity of thinking in this area. Since 2000, they have affirmed the Federal Circuit 28% of the time and reversed it 72% if the time - so it is clear that there are other views out there. As such, the key procedural reform supported by Chief Judge Wood is to allow IP to be viewed as a whole in the tribunals. In terms of substantive reform it is less clear. Much of the recent commentary in the US is calling for more aggressive intervention, in particularly in relation to big tech companies. Is SEP and FRAND licensing a good way to do this? Whilst this may work for IP, Chief Judge Wood was personally sceptical of how such an approach could be applied to other types of property. The session then continued with a panel session on the same issues, moderated by Daryl . Koren Wong-Ervin (Qualcomm) explained that the Department of Justice Guidelines do highlight that IP is a type of property and also that ease of appropriation will be kept in mind. Whilst ideally there is a desire to provide it to everyone, the incentive to innovate is important. In Koren's view there is a risk of equating the concentration issue with an effect on consumers. The concentration contention is not taking account of relevant antitrust markets but looking at hugely broad categories, not quite in the realm of 'all plastics' / 'all metals' but nearly this extreme in scope. A fundamental flaw in the court's reasoning on SEP compulsory licensing to date is the failure to appreciate that licensing at the device level is more valuable than licensing at the component level, which does not fully value the IP. Andrew Finch (Paul Weiss, previously U.S. Department of Justice's Antitrust Division) explained that there is a sea change from the previous view at the DOJ. The DOJ intervened in the recent FTC v Qualcomm case (in which Judge Koh found in favour of the FTC) and now on appeal. The policy of the current administration and head of the Antitrust Division is in some senses a re-balancing of the risk of hold up versus hold out. All three briefs submitted by the DOJ reflect the view that the failure to licence on FRAND terms does not in itself equate to an antitrust violation. Instead that must depend on what happens in the market. The antitrust movement being seen today is on a scale that hasn't been seen for a hundred years - including presidential debate. The market concentration debate is an important one to be having right now and the DOJ have walked right into that debate; as shown with Qualcomm case, if they don't agree with the FTC in a market of significant importance then then will step in. Milan Kristof (Court of Justice for the EU) explained that interestingly a different approach has been taken in Europe. In the UK the Supreme Court has just heard the appeal on the extraterritoriality and global FRAND issues. From the CJEU's perspective, where a patent holder has given a commitment to license on FRAND terms, and there is a willing potential licensee, then an injunction based on the SEP may be an abuse of dominant position. Steven Geisler (Huawei) commented that it is difficult to even know what best practice is: as a matter of contract or as a matter of antitrust law? It is one thing looking at the appellate level but at the district court level it is clear that different judges have different views. As a result, every party has its own preferred Court and legislative framework that it wants to work through. Economically there is also a very important debate about licensing at the device level versus licensing at the component level. The current Qualcomm case clearly shows that the FTC are one side philosophically and the DOJ are on the other side. Anne Gron (Alix Partners) gave the economist viewpoint, being asked to what extent should we be concerned that the likes of Google, Amazon and Facebook have a huge proportion of data? Should they be under an obligation to share it with other companies who might need it? In Anne's view there is a concern that reduced competition in markets with strong digital platforms can harm consumers. 'Tippy' markets are often seen in areas of strong IP; such markets tend to tip to one platform. This results in periods of intense competition until the market tips and there is then a period of waiting for new platforms to come up. One particular concern is that companies with strong data platforms can use their position in the market and data collected to acquire competitors before they are large enough to come to the regulator's attention as a likely 'competitor'. These are sometimes called 'killer acquisitions' as the platform acquired is often then shelved and not developed any further. This can often be identified more easily in the pharma industry than the tech industry. Whilst there are of course arguments that start-ups want to be bought, the concerns of economists are that the power of the dominant companies is very strong. Asked about whether the US Courts should do something to disseminate technology and facilitate access to platforms, Chief Judge Wood stated that abuse of dominance assessments may be best carried out by an administrative agency as is the case with the European Commission. In the US, if a monopoly is found to exist then all the Courts can do is break it up. The European Commission, on the other hand, has a more flexible toolkit and can impose a civil fine, such as Google's €2.4 billion fine - which even they must feel in their balance sheet! Milan Kristof commented that the Google decision is being appealed and so we will see what the General Court thinks about that in due course. He also noted that the European Commission is investigating Amazon over the issue of owning the platform on which its own products sell well. Asked about the fact that the Federal Circuit has exclusive jurisdiction over patents, but that the judges clearly have very different views and what can be done to reconcile this, Koren noted that she was surprised that in the FTC v Qualcomm case there was not more reference to other Federal Circuit cases. Steven commented that it should be kept in mind that SEPs are either owned by a larger innovator company or may have been sold to a NPE. In the German related case to the UK Unwired Planet case, the patents were sold with a view to extracting a high royalty rate but without passing on the FRAND commitment. The Appellate Court in Dusseldorf found this to be an antitrust violation - i.e. selling on the patents but not the FRAND commitment. In Steven's view that had to be the right decision. Milan commented that there is now European Commission guidelines on this point, namely that there be a requirement to ensure that the onward entity in any sale is bound by the same FRAND commitment. urn:contentItem:6059-SK01-DXY4-X206-00000-00Jobless Claims Show Another 1.5 Million Filings2020-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisBUSINESSJobless Claims Show Another 1.5 Million Filings

The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

This briefing is no longer updating. The latest developments can be found here.

Hertz calls off its unusual $500 million stock offering.

It’s official: Hertz, the bankrupt car-rental company, has canceled its plan to sell $500 million in new stock.

The offering seemed like a good idea only a week ago. Some investors seemed keen to pour money into Hertz’s stock even after the company’s bankruptcy filing last month, so why not offer them more shares to buy? Hertz submitted a plan to a bankruptcy judge, who approved it on Friday. On Monday morning, the company said it was moving forward. But then it hit a snag.

The Securities and Exchange Commission told Hertz that it was reviewing the plan. “When you let a company know that the S.E.C. has comments on their disclosure, they do not go forward until those comments are resolved,” the commission’s chairman, Jay Clayton, told CNBC on Wednesday.

Trading in the company’s shares was halted midday on Wednesday, and Hertz said in a filing that it had suspended the sale “pending further understanding of the nature and timing” of the S.E.C.’s review. On Thursday afternoon, Hertz said its board had decided that it was “in the best interests of the company” to scrap the sale altogether.

That decision might end up protecting the very investors who would have bought the shares. After all, when Hertz announced the offering this week, it acknowledged that the new shares could become “worthless” — a common outcome in bankruptcies.

AMC offers more details on its plan to reopen its movie theaters.

AMC Theaters, the nation’s largest theater operator, gave more details on itspreviously announced plan to reopen its chain in the coming weeks.

About 450 AMC cineplexes in the United States will relight their marquees on July 15, with auditorium capacity capped at 30 percent (or less, where mandated by local health officials). Another 150 locations will reopen by July 24 to coincide with the release of Disney’s live-action “Mulan,” thefirst big-budget movie scheduled to come out of Hollywood since March.

AMC said that it expected to increase auditorium capacity to 50 percent “around Labor Day” and that capacity limits was likely to be phased out on Thanksgiving or thereabouts.

The company emphasized that it would reopen with an array of safety protocols developed with input from Harvard University’s T.H. Chan School of Public Health and the Clorox Company.

Big Tech is rushing out new work force health-vetting and tracking tools.

Verily Life Sciences, a sister company of Google, is introducing a health screening and analytics service for businesses trying to safely reopen during the pandemic.

The service, announced on Thursday, will offer Covid-19 diagnostic testing for employees and clear them to return to the workplace based on their test results and other health data. It will also make recommendations to employers on how often workers should be retested, based on the prevalence of the virus in their work force and the local community.

With its new service, Verily is joining numerous tech giants and start-ups rushing to help business across the United States as they grapple with how to safely reopen the workplace.

Microsoft and the large insurer UnitedHealth Group, for instance, recently collaborated on a free symptom-checking app that helps pinpoint workers at obvious risk for the virus and direct them to testing resources. On Tuesday, Fitbit introduced a program that includes a daily symptom-checking app for employees and a work force health-monitoring dashboard for employers.

There is such a glut of new coronavirus risk-reduction products that it’s a challenge for many employers to assess them all.

“A big market rose up overnight,” said Jeff Becker, a senior analyst for digital business strategy at Forrester, a market research firm, who recently surveyed two dozen vendors offering coronavirus solutions for employers. “But it’s a fractured ecosystem, much like traditional health care.”

DoorDash, another pandemic winner, reaches $16 billion valuation in latest funding found.

DoorDash, the largest food delivery company in the United States, said on Thursday that it had raised another $400 million in a new round of funding, valuing the company at $16 billion.

The cash infusion comes after months of growing demand for DoorDash’s services while restaurants are closed and people are staying home during the coronavirus pandemic.

The company was expected to go public this year after filing registration documents in February. But initial public offerings slowed as the markets became volatile, and DoorDash has focused on responding to the flood of demand.

The company faces challenges as it prepares to go public. It is not profitable and food delivery remains competitive. Its largest rivals, Grubhub and Uber Eats, held merger discussions, with Grubhub eventually agreeing to sell to Just Eat Takeaway, a European food delivery service, for $7.3 billion in June.

Restaurants are struggling to make ends meet on delivery apps, which charge fees for their services and sometimes list restaurants that have not signed up. In April, DoorDash cut its primary fees for independent restaurants during the pandemic, which it said cost it around $120 million.

The company also faces pushback from regulators and workers. California has required “on-demand” tech companies to classify their armies of gig workers as employees. This week, San Francisco’s district attorney sued DoorDash for unfair business practices, seeking an injunction requiring the company to comply with California’s worker classification law.

Fidelity and Durable Capital Partners led the $400 million round. DoorDash, based in San Francisco, has raised $2.3 billion since it was founded in 2013.

Unemployment claims top one million for the 13th straight week.

Businesses are reopening, but the layoffs won’t quit.

Another 1.5 million people applied for state unemployment benefits last week, the Labor Department said Thursday.

It was the 13th straight week that state filings topped one million. Until the coronavirus crisis, the most new claims in a single week had been 695,000, in 1982.

Claims for Pandemic Unemployment Assistance, a federal program for self-employed workers, independent contractors and others ineligible for standard benefits, added 760,000 to the total.

“It’s a sustained hemorrhaging of jobs unlike anything we’ve seen,” said Heidi Shierholz, director of policy at the Economic Policy Institute, a progressive think tank.

Economists said recent layoffs, though smaller than the wave in March and early April, suggested that the crisis was reaching deeper into the economy.

Hilton Worldwide, the hotel operator, said this week that it was eliminating 2,100 corporate jobs globally and would extend previous furloughs and cuts in hours and wages for 90 days. AT&T disclosed plans to shed 3,400 technician and clerical jobs nationwide and permanently close more than 250 stores, according to one of its unions. The gym chain 24 Hour Fitness said it was filing for bankruptcy protection and would permanently close more than 100 locations.

Coronavirus is hitting black business owners the hardest.

More than 40 percent of black business owners reported they were not working in April, when businesses were feeling the worst of the pandemic’s economic consequences. Only 17 percent of white small-business owners said the same, according to an analysis of government data by Robert Fairlie of the University of California, Santa Cruz.

Many small businesses are struggling during the pandemic because they lack easy access to loans and cannot easily move their businesses online. Black-owned businesses tend to have fewer employees than other small businesses. They are also more likely to be in industries like restaurants or retail that lockdowns have hit especially hard, said Ken Harris, president of the National Business League, an organization founded by Booker T. Washington in 1900.

“Most lack the capacity, scale and technical assistance needed to survive a pandemic,” Mr. Harris said.

Black-owned businesses also appear to be benefiting less from federal stimulus programs. Only 12 percent of black and Hispanic business owners polled from April 30 to May 12 received the funding they had requested. About one quarter received some funding. By contrast, half of all small businesses reported receiving from a single part of the stimulus packages — the Paycheck Protection Program — according to a census survey.

“Black businesses often don’t have a traditional banking partner,” Mr. Harris said. Without such a partner, many had trouble applying for assistance.

As small businesses reopen, owners are figuring it out as they go.

With capacity limited and demand uncertain, small-business owners say it’s hard to know whether to spend the money to reopen now or to wait.

With no revenue for months, small businesses must find ways to pay for the new sanitation regimens, thermometers, plexiglass, masks and other items necessary to open, without knowing whether customers will return.

“None of the relief packages have included specific funding for safety retrofitting, purchasing of safety equipment or even helping business getting a handle on uniform P.P.E. for employees and customers,” said Amanda Ballantyne, executive director of the Main Street Alliance, an advocacy group for small business.

Some businesses are taking a slow approach. At first, Chris Lynch and Michael Samer weren’t sure what to do about their ocean adventure tours business, Everyday California, when they got the go-ahead in late April.

Mr. Lynch and Mr. Samer decided to reopen with curbside kayak and surf rentals only, keeping their retail shop and tour business closed. Then, as they felt more comfortable, they reintroduced tours at a 50 percent capacity with everyone wearing a mask. They also invested in their neglected online shop.

The bet paid off: They increased what had been a small number of online merchandise sales by 750 percent in May, allowing them to bring back about 20 employees to help with shipping and marketing.

Wall Street wavers as global markets decline.

Wall Street faced another day of unsteady trading on Thursday, with stocks drifting between negative and positive territory as investors considered new data on unemployment claims and the latest reports on fresh coronavirus outbreaks.

In the end, the S&P 500 ended essentially unchanged.

Markets have become somewhat directionless as concerns about a rise in new coronavirus cases around the world have collided with expectations for a quick economic recovery in recent days. It’s a consolidation that many Wall Street analysts have described as long overdue, after the S&P 500 ripped higher with a string of gains from late March to early June.

But it also reflects growing uncertainty about the economic picture going forward.

Another 1.5 million U.S. workers applied for state unemployment benefits last week, a report released Thursday by the Labor Department showed. Not all the unemployment claims necessarily reflect new layoffs. Some states are still working through backlogs of claims filed earlier in the crisis; in other cases, people filing under multiple programs may be counted twice.

But three months into the crisis, there is little doubt that layoffs remain elevated. Economists warn that job losses could worsen if government support that has helped prop up the economy is allowed to lapse too soon.

Are you in need of pandemic relief? Our guide can help.

Many people are in the position of needing help they never imagined would be necessary. Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard created a guide to connect you with information about government benefits, free services and financial strategies to get you through this crisis.

If you need temporary relief on your credit card or auto loan payments, many lenders are offering at least some help. Start with the website for your lenders and read what they have posted. Some have made their policies more stingy since Ron first reported on changes in March.

If you call for help via phone, record the conversation if you can or at least get written documentation of any changes the lender agrees to. This column from Ron explains how and why. And be sure to ask how any change might affect your credit score.

Financial losses often come with emotional strain, at the very point when people may be least likely to spend money on care for themselves. If you are in severe distress, the number for the National Suicide Prevention Hotline is 1-800-273-8255. Or text HELLO to 741741.

The National Alliance on Mental Illness maintains a help line that can provide referrals to local resources as well. Its number is 1-800-950-6264.

Catch up: Here’s what else is happening.

McDonald’s said it was expecting to hire about 260,000 restaurant employees this summer as states reopen their economies and the company welcomes customers back to its dining rooms. To protect workers and customers, the company said that it put into place nearly 50 new safety procedures, including temperature checks for employees, protective barriers for ordering and social-distancing stickers on the floor. “We want candidates and their families to know we have one goal — to keep our people safe,” said Joe Erlinger, president of McDonald’s USA.

The Bank of England said Thursday that it would hold interest rates steady at 0.1 percent but increase its purchases of British government bonds by 100 billion pounds, or about $125 billion, as it tries to help shore up the economy.

Kroger, the grocer with about 2,800 stores in 35 states, said Thursday that its sales increased to $42 billion in the quarter that ended May 23, up from $37 billion in the same period last year. Digital sales jumped 92 percent during the period marked by pandemic shutdowns. The company, which has about 500,000 employees, said it had hired 100,000 workers.

Carnival Corporation, the giant cruise company, reported Thursday that it lost $2.4 billion in the three months that ended on May 31. Carnival, which offered refunds or credits for future cruises to passengers whose voyages were canceled by the pandemic, said that about half asked for their money back. Customer demand for 2021 was increasing, it said, with about two-thirds of bookings in a recent six-week period coming fresh and one-third from customers using credits. Carnival said it could not say when it would return to normal operations.

Chanel said it expected a “significant” reduction in sales and profitability for 2020, thelatest luxury business to warn on the serious hit to the sector caused by the coronavirus pandemic. On Thursday, Chanel’s global chief financial officer, Philippe Blondiaux, said the company had reopened 85 percent of its global boutiques and recorded a “double or even triple digit recovery in sales” in markets like China and India.

Reporting and research were contributed by Brooks Barnes, Niraj Chokshi, Ben Casselman, Tiffany Hsu, Coral Yang, Sapna Maheshwari, Mohammed Hadi, Amy Haimerl, Jeanna Smialek, Lauren Leatherby, Ron Lieber, Tara Siegel Bernard, Elizabeth Paton, Stacy Cowley, Jeff Sommer, Stanley Reed, Carlos Tejada and Gregory Schmidt.

urn:contentItem:4MV6-GYJ0-TWD3-V2Y2-00000-00Job needs in technology confound the experts2007-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisWORKINGPg. C1 Job needs in technology confound the expertsJennifer CampbellThe Ottawa Citizen

So you've decided on a career in technology. Should be easy to figure out what education you'll need, right?

Just contact the recruitment experts and ask them what employers will be looking for down the road. In short, what will be hot in high tech?

Well, don't expect useful answers. No one's done the research to tackle the question. And, says one Ottawa-area expert, it might not even be answerable.

"It's a very complex topic that's of great concern to a number of groups, but no one's been able to pull the trigger on it," says Keith Carter, vice-president of the recruitment firm Procom Consultants Group.

Mr. Carter said the task confounds tech giants, which find it hard to predict the future for their companies alone. "To do it for the city, the province and the country, it just becomes more and more challenging. The Ottawa Talent Initiative talked about doing it for Ottawa, and I questioned if it was even possible."

And there's some truth to the fact that predicting the next big tech trend is like predicting the next toy craze. Hula Hoops? T.M.X. Elmos? Who would have guessed?

Other groups that would like to get a handle on the future of technology include the Ottawa Centre for Research and Innovation, the Information and Communications Technology Council and the Canadian Advanced Technology Alliance.

The ICTC estimates tech jobs across the country will increase by 2.3 per cent annually through 2010. That translates to 58,000 jobs over the next three to five years. Replacing those who leave the sector will require another 31,000 jobs.

The report notes about half of Canada's IT workers don't actually work for high-tech companies but rather in IT departments.

But determining the nature of future jobs is more difficult.

"We have a huge people-supply problem in technology and now the unemployment rate is about two per cent so it's very thin," Mr. Carter says. "Governmental organizations and associations want the answer so they can start to promote through education and immigration -- to bring in more people."

Adding to the confusion is the difference in job markets across Canada. Ottawa, for example, is focused on telecommunications, but Toronto has no time for telecom and Montreal is different again.

"The problem is it's difficult to meet a demand when we don't know what that demand is and it varies so significantly from company to company," Mr. Carter said.

So what jobs were crossing his Ottawa desk this week? Mr. Carter cited requests for low-level C++ Linux developers and "very experienced" Java developers.

Others in the tech field ventured some opinions on what could be hot in information technology.

Kevin Dee, CEO of Eagle Professional Resources, deals largely with "business solutions" recruiting. He sees potential for those with experience in packaged business systems such as Siebel, SAP and PeopleSoft. The jobs for those with human-resource experience and functional knowledge will be in project management, but there will also be plenty of work for those in technical support.

"The big demand is going to come in the implementation of packaged software," Mr. Dee says.

Across Ottawa at Ajilon Consulting, Michel Plouffe, vice-president of IT services, pin-points a handful of places he expects to see job growth. His list includes positions for technical architects, Java and .Net Web developers, usability design and testing experts, telecom specialists (Cisco-CCIE and IP), business analysts, security specialists (C4ISR) and database specialists (ERP, CRM). In most cases, Mr. Plouffe said, employers will want three years' experience.

Life sciences are also expected to grow. Ken Lawless, president and CEO of the Ottawa Life Sciences Council, sees promise in clean or environmental technology, a field that should have much potential as India and China increase their power consumption.

But the growth will come "in twos and fours and 10s, not in hundreds," Mr. Lawless explains. Company requirements will be on the manufacturing side, where technical background will be essential. Such companies are also always looking for experts who combine business development talent with scientific background and expertise. Ottawa companies in this "space" include Iogen Corp. and Plasco Energy Group.

The biomedical field will grow at about the same pace as clean energy, Mr. Lawless said, describing it as gradual, as opposed to an "all-of-a-sudden big boom." There will be institutional work as hospitals and research labs expand. In the private sector, biochemists, critical researchers and laboratory technologists should do well.

Private-sector companies will be looking for people with clinical trial and regulatory affairs backgrounds as well as those with business development skills.

What else will be hot? It's anyone's guess.

Photo: Pat McGrath, The Ottawa Citizen; High-tech recruiter Keith Carter says nobody, not even employers, can forecast what skills will be in demand in the years to come.

urn:contentItem:5WB8-DDN1-DY0W-41GV-00000-00Jobs in America; Unemployment rate expected to tick-down; Debate over healthcare; Economy growth; Replacement of Obamacare; Impeachment of2017-03-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJobs in America; Unemployment rate expected to tick-down; Debate over healthcare; Economy growth; Replacement of Obamacare; Impeachment ofLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Report. It is expected to be a big one, economist, expecting 190 thousand jobs to have been added to the economy. Last month, the unemployment rate is expected to tick-down to 4.7 percent. Of course, we got very strong ADP numbers earlier in the week. So, we're expecting a good number.

What to watch for coming up? The Gorman debate over healthcare and America, some senators say the current bill is dead on arrival but Vice President Pence and House, Ways and Means committee Chairman Kevin Brady, they're hopeful.

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: What's different than back in 2010 though, Brad, when Obamacare was literally forced through the Congress with very little debate is what the American people are seeing, it's really what they expect Congress to do.

KEVIN BRADY, CHAIRMAN, WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE: At the end of the day here, Lou, we're going to come together to back the president on this and get it done.

BARTIROMO: We've got the very latest this morning. Checking market action, take a look, we're watching oil price. It's been a tough week for oil, crude rebounding after closing at the lowest level since November, yesterday. This morning, we're seeing a gain of about one half of 1 percent, still below $50 a barrel. That certainly helping stocks, though, around the world as the oil price is stabilized. Futures indicating a pretty good open for the (inaudible) averages today.

Dow Industrial seem to be up, that's 70 points at the opening of trading. In Europe, similar story, take a look. Of course, you heard from the ECD yesterday. The markets are higher across the boards to the tune of one half of a percent higher on the FT100, two thirds of a percent higher on the CAC (inaudible) in Paris and the DAX Index in Germany.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly higher. As you see, the Nikkei average in Japan, best performer of one and a half percent. Political unrest in South Korea, deadly protests overnight erupting after the country's president was removed from office, impeachment.

Then a terrifying moment to report in Ohio, a four year old girl blown away by extreme winds, amazing pictures here. Look at this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Wow. We'll bring you the latest there. Nissan, meanwhile, making a car for man's best friend. Check this out. The automaker's showing off a concept car designed with dogs in mind. We like that. All of those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox News Network's Dagen McDowell.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Barron's online editor, Jack Otter, is here and New York Times best-selling author, Peter Kiernan, is with us as well. Good morning to you.

PETER KIERNAN, AUTHOR, NEW YORK TIMES BEST-SELLING AUTHOR: (inaudible) with you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, happy Friday.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good Morning.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly, could be a big number. ADP number was what, 298.

JACK OTTER, BARRON'S ONLINE EDITOR: I think it might be huge.

BARTIROMO: Yes, huge.

OTTER: Huge.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: The first job report under President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Full report.

BARTIROMO: Well, we know the expectations are out there but does the market trade up on a huge number or does the market trade down because the Fed starts raising interest rates next week.

OTTER: Well, I think that the next -- the March interest rate hike is baked in.

BARTIROMO: OK.

OTTER: I mean, unless today is just terrible but everyone expects it's going to be good especially after that ADP number. I think, frankly, I'm already looking beyond the number. I'm looking the wages, and of course, the participation.

BARTIROMO: We've got a big show coming up. We have the jobs number at 8:00 AM Eastern and we will be looking at all of the above there. Joining our program this morning, a whole line up of experts to tell you where the jobs are right now. First, our top story republicans are moving forward with the replacement of Obamacare. The GOP plan cleared hurdles through two house committees yesterday. Those skepticism for the bill is still mounting. House Speaker Paul Ryan even gave a PowerPoint presentation to promote the merits of the bill. That was during his weekly press conference. Vice President Mike Pence, House Speaker Paul Ryan, Senator Rand Paul, all weighed in on the plane yesterday. Watch.

PENCE: Because of President Trump's leadership and support here in the congress, I'm very confident. We'll repeal and replace Obamacare and it'll all be done by this spring.

PAUL RYAN, HOUSE SPEAKER OF THE UNITED STATES: This is the closest we will ever get to repealing and replacing Obamacare.

RAND PAUL, SENATOR: Conservatives hate their bill. I promise you. Obamacare lied, dead on arrival. They might as well just start over.

BARTIROMO: Wow, dead on arrival. Joining us right now, former Michigan congressman and former Intelligence Committee Chairman, Pete Hoekstra. Congressman, good to see. Thanks so much for joining us.

PETE HOEKSTRA, CONGRESSMAN: Great to be here. Thank you. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: So much debate. I mean, do you think this current house bill has a chance of passing in the senate? You heard what Rand Paul just said, dead on arrival.

HOEKSTRA: Well, this current house bill is now what we will ultimately see be put into law. This is the normal process of making sausage or some call it making legislation. The house has its bill. There will be some changes that will be made to this bill has they -- as the house goes through the process, the senate will do its work. There'll be reconciliation, the work with the president. I think the reason for optimism is how engaged the White House is with the president and Mike Pence, both involve in this process, making it work. You know, the dialogue will continue. Ultimately, there will be a repeal and replace bill that makes it to the president's desk.

BARTIROMO: All right. So this is all to be expected. Then the back and forth as we make the sausage or make this legislation. Can we talk about what is so troubling though because the conservatives are so upset about this? I mean, they are calling this an expansion of Medicaid. Dagen, let's go through for our viewers, what is so bad about this plan?

MCDOWELL: The -- what the conservative don't like and there are a few things, and the congressman can jump in here. There were 19 states that resisted the Medicaid expansion. Many of the states and the representatives who took money to expand Medicaid, they demanded, basically, $100 billion subsidy fund to stabilize their transition away from -- as they go to block grants on Medicaid, for lack of a better word. They're also angry that the Cadillac tax is still in there, although, it's extended out to 2025 and a lot of these conservatives seem to have gotten religion, if you will, on these tax credits, they're mad that the tax credits are a subsidy, which they are. The republicans and that their leadership, they're trying to level the playing field in terms of the tax treatment of employer insurance, it's an employer provided insurance and that the individuals buy. They call it a subsidy but I'll point out the head of this freedom caucus, Congressman Mark Meadows in North Carolina was a cosponsor of Tom Price's healthcare bill before Tom Price became Health and Human Services secretary. That has tax credits in it. So now, he's got religion on it. That's what I don't understand. There is a lot of pushback. I do you think -- there will be compromise though as Congressman Hoesktra.

BARTIROMO: What do you think congressman? I mean, is it mostly this thought that it's an expansion of Medicare -- Medicaid rather or the Cadillac tax? Is that what's so troubling from the conservative's point of view.

HOEKSTRA: Well, I think all of the above is accurate. I think the republicans will get over and they will unite on the tax credit. They'll recognized that this is actually a leveling of the tax treatment for those of who get an employer base healthcare plan versus those who have to go buy it out on the market themselves. I think they will also - yes, they'll reach a compromise on the Medicaid expansion because, you know, certain states did it, other did not. So, they will get there. The other thing that I think that they will want to do is they -- yes, they'll have to get rid of the Cadillac tax. You know, republicans could not be seen as keeping a tax that is part of Obamacare in place in moving forward and somewhere in this thing not as phase three. They're going to have to move phase three into phase one which is allowing the sale of insurance across state lines.

BARTIMOMO: Peter Kiernan?

(CROSSTALK)

KIERNAN: For just a second, I have a question for you because, on one hand, you have Speaker Ryan saying this is a binary choice, either or and the other hand, the president is saying let's go bowling and let's make a deal and somewhere in between that, you have the house and look what they're doing. They speed through Ways and Means. They speed through Energy and Commerce. They're on their way to the budget committee. This is lightning fast. What do you think is going to happen here? Where are these compromises going to be made?

HOEKSTRA: Well, the compromise, that I think are going to be made -- there will be compromise throughout this process. There will be compromises made to get to 218 votes in the house. The speaker doesn't have the votes right now. He will get there. There will be compromises or there will be a senate agenda that puts out, probably -- maybe, a very significant different bill and then there'll be a reconciliation pack or there will be a conference report that will come out as the house and the Senate work out their differences. This will be all about compromise all the way through. It is not unusual. Remember, back at '96, we did welfare. I think we passed it three times before President Clinton actually signed. This is expected. This should not be easy. It is healthcare. It's a huge change. It -- this is the normal process.

MCDOWELL: I will add this, that if you had republicans who step back and cross their arms and essentially stand shoulder to shoulder with the likes of Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi on this, they will regret it. Whether it's in the midterm elections whether it is four years from now, they will regret it because if they -- if the republicans do nothing here. It will speed up or if they just repeal it and then don't have anything to replace it. It will speed up the already looming collapse of Obamacare and you're talking about people getting kicked off their insurance, spiraling of -- premium spiraling high -- of the higher.

BARTIROMO: And then they own it.

MCDOWELL: Yes, they will -- the republicans will own it. Particularly the people who stood back and let it happen.

KIERNAN: Yes, they'll be the ones who are dead on arrival. I think -- if you pull that trick. I think (inaudible)

BARTIROMO: They've got a window. This is the window.

OTTER: You know guys, there's one thing. So, there are a lot of thing -- the things that people most hated about Obamacare tended to be the things that were necessary in order to get more people on healthcare, the penalty for instance. The idea that, you know, you couldn't charge older people, frankly, as much as it cost to insure older people. That was a very anti- free market move but what it did was it got more people coverage. How you do make those tough choices with this.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, what's the timeline on this? You said, there's going to be a lot of debate. There's going to be a lot of choices to make but what's your timeline on that? Do you think we're going to see this before Eastern, which is I think that the date that they were talking about, you want to have something done by Easter, which is in a couple of weeks.

HOEKSTRA: Yes, I think you'll see it out of the house clearly by Easter. I think it's going to be sometime between Easter and the August Recess before they get it passed into law and get something on the president's desk. I think one of the really interesting things to watch is what's going to happen to the August Recess. The senate -- the house and senate, they're going to go out of session roughly the end of July and then they're not going to come back into session until September. Are they really can take a whole month off? I think they're going to have to pass healthcare. They're going to have to pass tax reform. I believe before they go on their traditional August Recess because I think Donald Trump is going to come back and say, yes, hey, we got to get -- make America great again. We got to get the economy going. We got to get more money in people's pockets. These two things have to happen before you go home.

BARTIROMO: Well, they'll better be working on a tax reform package if they're going to take a month off. Maybe, they're going to work on it.

MCDOWELL: Oh, Mitch McConnell said yesterday, the senate majority leader, the tax reform is not getting done by August. He said I don't think that --

HOEKSTRA: I know he said that thing. The interesting thing he's going to - -

MCDOWELL: He's going to -- I don't think it will get done by August.

BARTIROMO: That's a big statement.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I saw that. I was like, what? Oh.

(LAUGHTER)

HOEKSTRA: And I think Donald Trump will ask Mitch McConnell to stay in session in August until they get it done and guess what, with those jet fumes always going in the end of July, they may actually find a way to get it done by August. I think Donald Trump is going to stand firm and say don't go home until these two things are done.

BARTIROMO: I think you're right.

HOEKSTRA: This is what I promised, what we all promised the American people don't go home until your work is done.

BARTIROMO: Well, I think you're right and I think the American people are going to shame them into having a tax plan after Obamacare ready to go after that July Recess. So, we'll see about that. OK. Now, we're talking about dates, and this is real impactful for markets. Congressman, good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

HOEKSTRA: OK, great. Thank you. Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Pete Hoekstra there and stay tuned, we'll be bringing you live coverage and announcements of the February jobs report. It is Jobs Day. Jobs in America begins at 8:00 A.M. Eastern. Q&As for all the experts on where exactly the jobs are and what are wages doing now. Coming up next, the car designed for man's best friend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The latest concept from Nissan that dog owners are drooling over and then serving up these. What restaurants are doing to make you put the bill for rising minimum wage. Wait until you this. Have you checked your check lately? Back in a minute.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back with that breaking news overnight. Out of South Korea, violent clashes breaking out after the country's president was officially ousted from office. Cheryl Casone with the story now, in headline. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: It's quite a scandal in South Korea, Maria. The president, President Park, has become the country's first democratically elected leader forced from office in that country after a panel of judges unanimously upheld parliament's decision to impeach her over a corruption scandal. She was also the first female leader of South Korea. Violent clashes immediately breaking out between supporters of Park and police after the (inaudible) that happened in Seoul. It left at least two people dead. The country now has 60 days to hold a new presidential election.

(inaudible) that the same corruption scandal has enveloped the error of Samsung and then bribery charges.

Meanwhile, let's turn our focus to Germany. Police have arrested a man who wounded seven people with an axe at a train station in Dusseldorf yesterday. Officials describe the suspect as a 36-year-old man, from the former Yugoslavia, who obviously has mental health problems, they added. Three of the victims suffered severe injuries. Police believed the suspect acted alone.

Well, let's turn to some corporate news this morning. Staples says it's looking to close another 70 stores in North America following sharp sales decline. The news comes as the company reports disappointing returns for the quarter. Earnings coming in at 25 cents a share, that was a penny less than analyst expected. Store closings follow the elimination of 48 locations last year and as well affected about five percent of stores in North America. They'll have about 1600 stores left after these closings.

And finally this headline, the restaurant industry is handling higher labor costs by adding them to your bill. Rather than raise menu prices to cover the higher cost of wages, some eateries are now attacking on labor surcharges. The Wall Street Journal reports that change in states like Arizona, California, Colorado, and right here in New York are adding the surcharges of three to four percent to the bill. Maria, you will see them on your bill, just ask your server for details.

BARTIROMO: Yes, incredible. I mean, people just miss it but that's who's paying for minimum wage increases.

CASONE: We are, we are.

BARTIROMO: There you go. Who do you think was going to pay for it, anyway? Coming up next, soda sales going flat -- thanks Cheryl. The beverage Americans are reaching for instead of soda. Future is pointing to a higher opening ahead of the February jobs report a little more than two hours away. What to expect from the February jobs number coming out at 8:30 A.M. Eastern. Market's rallying ahead of that. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. It's pretty good market day this morning. Take a look. We're expecting a big rally at the opening of trading. Dow Industrials, expected to be up about 80 points. This is, of course, ahead of the February jobs report. It's going to hit the (inaudible) in about two hours. We will bring you the latest numbers, obviously but we're expecting an addition of 190 thousand jobs to the economy in the last month with the unemployment rate falling back to 4.7 percent. Jack Otter is with us this morning and, Jack, we know that we got a very strong ADP number. 298 thousand was reported on Thursday and the estimate was 190, do you think it's going to be equivalent?

OTTER: Yes, I think it's going to be closer to the ADP number than the 190 if you look at a chart of ADP versus the non-farm's payroll, especially, on these blowout numbers. How often non-farm payroll has actually been above ADP? So, it's not impossible. We could see a 350 thousand number today. On the downside, I think it's 250, I don't think it's 190. So -- now, really, and everyone else is weather, weather, weather. I am starting to wonder if maybe they're not quite figuring out the seasonal adjustments correctly. 66 thousand construction jobs was a wonderful figure in the ADP number. I don't believe it. We are not creating 66 thousand construction jobs every month. I'm sure there was a bump because of the weather and then you add the seasonal adjustment on top of that and you get this but still goodness. We'll look - I'm looking through that. Look for wages.

BARTIROMO: It's clear the things are beginning to unleash, Peter. Isn't that right?

KIERNAN: It really does feel. There's never been a damn just burst all at once. There is a little bit here and a little bit there. What's happening here is really exciting. Job creation is fantastic. There are some spots like in retail and some spots like in oil but they have Amazon turning around and say, we're going to create 100 thousand jobs this year. This is an economy that's on the march and what I love about this is if we get the spectacular number you're talking about, as far as Janet Yellen is down said hike -- we hike raises. We hike rates. What happens when? I think the financials are going to have a spectacular year particularly if there are three more rate hikes to follow.

BARTIROMO: They've already have a spectacular year since Election Day, right, Dagen? The financials are on fire. The Fed meeting is next week, the 15th. A strong jobs number probably does lead to a rate hike, right? You said it's a rate hike.

KIERNAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: The rate hiked -- price in the market last week. At the beginning of the week there was a little more than a third of a chance that the Federal Reserve would hike interest rates next week and then it went to about 90 percent.

KIERNAN: It's over 90 percent. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Right. It went to 90 percent by the end of the week. So, some people will call it flat footed. The question will be looking down the road. The Fed expecting three interest rate hikes this year. They're going to hike most definitely next week. Do they even speed that up? If they think that the jobs market is getting hot here. The job growth, it's only running the three month average of 183 thousand jobs. So, they will wait at least a couple months to see if you have three or four consecutive months of strong job creation.

BARTIROMO: How about --

KIERNAN: People will be looking very closely at wage growth. It's actually slowed. It was 0.1 percent wage growth last month. If it doesn't get up to 0.3, at least, I think people are going to say, well, this is great but not good enough and frankly it puts the policymakers in a pickle because you're creating jobs but not well enough paid jobs.

BARTIROMO: Right, let's talk about the oil prices for a second. They're higher this morning but they took a real hit this week over concerns of a glut in oil. We have, David, showing stockpiles heading record levels. Does the oil story once again impact the stock market story? And I'll point that just a couple of stories in the Wall Street Journal this morning. S&P 500 up 250 percent from its lowest crisis year close eight years ago. Household net worth in the U.S. up to record $92.8 trillion in the fourth quarter because of that year and surge in stocks.

KIERNAN: Yes, I think oil is really exciting right now. It's going to tell a lot of stories. Number one, no matter what OPEC tried to do to kind of lift that price of oil. The United States is producing. We're producing 9 million barrels a day. Our record for us and these guys are doing it because they have debts to pay. Remember, it was only a couple of years ago that oil was $100 a barrel and interest rates from two percent and, so, that's it. Let's borrow and pump. We're doing the same thing again and I don't think that the Saudis and others are going to be, like, keep that price up as long as United States is pumping, pumping, pumping.

BARTIROMO: Because there's more oil, means lower prices.

KIERNAN: Yes, and we're going to keep pumping. We have a great business, we have an oil dividend for our nation and I think it's a great time for us.

BARTIROMO: And it's a job creator.

KIERNAN: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: There's that as well. We're going to stay tuned. We've got a big show ahead. We're bringing you live coverage and announcements of the February jobs report. Jobs in America begins 8:00 A.M. Eastern, 30 minutes before The Numbers which will hit the tape at 8:30. (inaudible) break when we come back. Pressure building on Capitol Hill. FBI director, Jim Comey meeting with lawmakers over the president's wiretapping claims. What it means for the future of those allegations and then a heart stopping moment in Ohio.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: A little girl, literally blown away literally blown away by heavy winds, luckily unharmed. The dramatic moment. Watch.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Good Friday morning, welcome back, everybody. Thanks for being with us. I'm Marie Bartiromo. Happy Friday and it's Friday, March 10th. Your top service right now at 6:30 A.M. on the East Coast.

It's job's day, two hours away from the February jobs report. Economists are expecting 190 thousand jobs to have been added to the economy in the month of February. The unemployment rate is expected to tick down to 4.7 percent. What you need to know, coming up this morning.

FBI Director, James Comey, briefs lawmakers. Director Comey spoke with congressional leaders over President Trump's wiretapping claims as well as allegations that President Trump's associates have links to Russia. All of this coming as WikiLeaks takes on the CIA. White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer weighed in on the leak.

SEAN SPICER, PRESS SECRETARY: There's grave concern that the president has about to release of national security and classified information that threatens and undermines our nation's security. Obviously he believes that the systems at the CIA are outdated and need to be updated.

BARTIROMO: The video of WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, says he will give technology companies access to the CIA's hacking tools. He says he wants to help technology companies, see where their vulnerabilities are.

Refugees using Facebook to seek asylum -- the new online tool that's helping them get legal advice -- the outrage ahead. Markets this morning in rally mode.

We're watching oil prices today because crude is rebounding after closing at the lowest level since November. Equities once again focused on the oil market.

Oil prices up three quarters of one percent, still below $50 a barrel. But nonetheless, the gain is helping stocks across the world.

Futures indicating a gain at the opening of trading this morning ahead of the jobs report. Market is expected to open up almost 80 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

PAYNE: But you could get lower rates quicker than you could get a full-fledged -

OTTER: And I'd love to see growth. That's the good Trump, and market wants that.

MCDOWELL: If you're going to spend your political capital? Give the American people their capital back. Let them keep more if their income. Do it immediately, and make it retroactive to January 1. Do you know how much - people would have backed off, and be like, OK, now you can deal with reforming Obamacare.

PAYNE: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: I'm perfectly happy. I'm going to go buy a new ATV.

KIERNAN: And you to prove to people that you're a good guy, that you can get things done, that you can make your deals - and by the way, everyone is going home saying, I brought you home tax reform. And with that, winning can take on the tough stuff.

MCDOWELL: But instead they work GOP, and the House.

CORTES: Let's do it then! It's all talk, let's do it!

BARTIROMO: Guys, does anybody -

CORTES: They keep talking about tax cut, let's do it Donald Trump.

MCDOWELL: I've been saying that.

BARTIROMO: You have been.

MCDOWELL: I've been saying that, instead we got the border adjustment tax shoved in there.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Some tax to raise a trillion dollars over 10 years. Does anybody want to touch on retail here, Charles? Down 26,000 jobs in retail. That's one of the few areas where we actually showed job cuts. We got strength in construction up 50,000, strength leisure hospitality, strength in manufacturing, strength in government.

PAYNE: It's the long - everyone just talked about the death of brick and mortar, you know. And as I already mentioned here, it's been off-set to a degree by Amazon. But even these retailers doing well, children's place this week, one of the biggest winners in the market - two days ago, was up 20 percent in one day. They're doing well because of last two years, they've closed 142 non-performing stores. So, even if these stores that are doing well, relatively speaking, are closing stores, are firing people, so, you know, that's just something that's not going to exist.

MCDOWELL: Some of this could be seasonal adjustment from the Labor Department, though.

BARTIROMO: In retail?

MCDOWELL: Yes. In the post-holiday months. That, it could be some of that. You could see some give back in the next month's jobs' report.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

MCDOWELL: That's a pretty steep decline.

KIERNAN: And Texas had a very tough month last month on their oil patch. And so, there are punch on these things that I think are little moments in the sun, where I we can see them come back. And I think jobs are going to continue to grow throughout the rest of the year.

BARTIROMO: All right. Hot morning here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, we're going to talk a short break. More on the February jobs report, after this short break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, the February jobs report just out. As we've been reporting, the economy created 235,000 jobs, in the month of February, beating economists' expectations. The unemployment rate ticked down slightly to 4.7 percent. Also expected, the labor force participation rate; this was highlight came in at 63 percent. That was better than expected. I want to bring in the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY", Stuart Varney now, joining us with his thoughts. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK VARNEY & COMPANY HOST: Good morning, Maria. I will say this. I think it was a solid report; not spectacular, not a blowout, but I think it marks what I'm going to call the beginning of the Trump expansion. Call me crazy but I think that's where it's at. Now, you're going to get folks on the left who say this was a solid jobs' report result of President Obama's policy or Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve. That's nonsense.

The change in the mood of the country towards more optimism, towards more growth, towards more confidence, that started November the 8th with the election. So, I'm calling this the beginnings of the Trump expansion. 58,000 new construction jobs, what was it? 28,000 manufacturing, those are good well paid-jobs. And I think they're' going to expand that front in the future. That's where I'm coming from.

BARTIMORO: Wait till we get an infrastructure program, right? I mean, those construction jobs are going to benefit even more.

VARNEY: Absolutely. And that infrastructure program will come. I think it's got bi-partisan support, not sure how you pay for it. But it's got bipartisan support. Something on that front is going to get done this year. That is very good news for those high paid construction jobs and manufacturing, too, positive.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Sir, what do you think about your buddy though, Elon Musk? He might get a bit chunk of that infrastructure for the hyper loop.

VARNEY: My buddy, Elon Musk. Well, said with tongue-in-cheek there, Charles? I do declare. I'm not wild about companies that live on government subsidies especially green subsidies. But look, if this guy can come up with a way of making a battery that stores enormous amounts of electricity, then you are on to a winner. That's my story.

MCDOWELL: Let me just point something out. All the people who drive Teslas don't pay for our infrastructure now because they don't pay any gas taxes. They're plugging in and refuelling that way, and so they're basically getting a free ride on the back of all the other taxpayers in this country. So that -- it shocks me a little bit too.

VARNEY: It's -- you are pointing the finger towards real outrage here. I think Tesla should be banned. OK, I'm joking.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

VARNEY: Just warming it up.

BARTIMORO: Well, you know, what do you think about retail? Retail was down 26,000. Does that matter or do you think that's just a fluke because of the holidays.

VARNEY: Oh no. I think that, that really reinforces our story. We keep talking about the retail ice age. They're having a very hard time. The bricks-and-mortar people meeting the challenge of online selling and this down , 26,000 -- 26,000 retail jobs, that's a big deal.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: That tells the story. I wouldn't want to be a mall operator right now. I wouldn't want to be buying real estate in a shopping mall in this day and age. I think they got a real problem here.

BARTIMORO: Yes, that's a good point. It's really online that's winning here. Hey Stu, are you tired of winning it?

VARNEY: You mean in the ratings? I'll never get tired of winning.

BARTIMORO: You'll never get tired of that. Now that we have Donald Trump, you're going to get so sick of winning. We're winning, right. OK. Stu, we'll see you in about --

VARNEY: We'll you give an opportunity, Maria. I thought I'd grab it with both hands.

BARTIMORO: Yes, I love it. That was a lob. That's what they call a lob, Stu. Congratulations to you and Fox Business Network. We got the All-Stars right here.

PAYNE: There you go.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations everybody .

PAYNE: Yes, thank you, you too.

BARTIROMO: For beating the competition. Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes. Join "VARNEY & COMPANY" top of the hour. Steve, final thoughts from you and Jonathan. Your take on today's number, final word.

CORTES: You know, final thoughts, Maria. Between Fox Business and the ratings and Trump and the White House, and the stock market, I'm not tired of winning yet but we might get there soon. I think this is a fantastic report. I really do, particularly the participation. Too many people had given up on America, had given up on life really, in a lot of ways. Not to be too philosophical but we need them back in the workforce and they're coming back and that's great news.

BARTIMORO: Jonathan Hoenig.

HOENIG: There's an unlimited amount of wealth and jobs that can be created, Maria. It's freedom that's needed to make that happen. So long as the government and you're right, Washington, is very much at the center of Wall Street these days. As so long as the government can keep this trend going, lower taxes, lower regulation, more individual and economic freedom, I think 200,000 new jobs is just the start.

BARTIMORO: All right we will leave it there. Steve Cortes, Jonathan Hoenig, good to see you both. Gentlemen, have a good weekend. We got the best team in business. After this short break, right here at the panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIMORO: Welcome back, final thoughts from our All-Star Panel. We got markets on fire this morning on the hills. It has been better than expected jobs report. Financials leading the rally at Peter Kiernan, you called it.

PETER KIERNAN, ENTREPENEUR: I have to say financers are incredibly well positioned and what's going to be exciting to see is whether small businesses really take this opportunity to hire, to expand and whether the big company starts parting some of that cash and the best thing in the long term. Property plan equipment and expanding.

BARTIMORO: Yes, I want to get Charles' take on this though. Because Charles, you know how to make money in this market. Would you think it's overvalued at this point?

PAYNE: I think there are a lot of individual names that are overvalued. When you see companies miss, they're taken out to the woodshed pretty good so that's where your risk is. And this is by no means a dart throwing kind of rally. I think that people need to understand too, a handful of names have been overwhelmingly responsible for the move, right? Because of the way the Dow forensics is weighted. But you know, we've got to think longer term. And this motion of occasional dips, you know yesterday, we talked about the eight-year anniversary of the market.

Think about the longest streak ever, right. It went from '87 to 2000. Well, guess what? From '82 to '87, there was also a rally. So you can almost argue from '82 to 2000, with a three month blip, could you live with that? Hell yes, if you were in the market. So, it's going to happen. I think we don't want to get too fixated on the market occasionally pulling back. Think longer term.

BARTIMORO: Yes.

JACK OTTER, AMERICAN JOURNALIST: It's important for investors to understand the good news does not always mean good start. The good news was baked in a long time ago, Jonathan Hoenig was making that point. And so we have to be careful of buy the rumor and sell the news, and especially if maybe the market is too optimistic about tax breaks, about deregulation and we get bogged down in Obamacare or bore taxes.

BARTIMORO: What do you mean by good news was baked in? I mean, you - how many people we're like Trump's going to win and the markets are going to sell off? Well, what is baked in?

OTTER: Well, because as soon as he was elected, suddenly the market took off. And we've been - I watch the market.

PAYNE: The $3 trillion in additional market evaluation.

OTTER: Yes, yes.

BARTIMORO: The anticipation about policy.

OTTER: That's what I'm saying.

(CROSSTALK)

PAYNE: Materializing so far into reality. We're seeing sentiment materialize into reality as long as you have that, that's the ultimate support.

OTTER: How long to keep up?

MCDOWELL: I want to point out in terms of optimism. 300,000 people re-entered the work force. The unemployment rate falls which means that people found work. The labor participation rate continues to go up, that is your Trump optimism right there.

BARTIMORO: How about wages, Dagen? I mean, you got wages up 2.8 percent.

MCDOWELL: Again, and not hot enough to make people worry about the Federal Reserve.

KIERNAN: And I think the central point, in addition, there's room to grow. We still have a lot of room to grow to get where we've been before and I think that's great news for this economy.

BARTIMORO: And then there's trade this Sunday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES," I'm going to be speaking with Commerce Secretary, Wilbur Ross. He is my special guest to talk about trade and how that fits into all of this. That's one of the worries out there. We'll talk with the Wilbur Ross, joining me on the Fox News Channel. Thanks, everybody.

KIERNAN: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Have a great weekend. "VARNEY & COMPANY" right now. Stuart, take it away

END
