urn:contentItem:5VKT-36P1-DY0W-42D3-00000-00Jobs Report Out Tomorrow; Mark Zuckerberg Unveiling New Privacy Focused Plan For Facebook; Sears Sued Over Craftsman; Huawei Sues U.S. Over Ban; Clinton's 2020 Vision; Bridging Bipartisan Divide; Dog Anti-Barking Ordinance; Ohio General Motors Plant Shuts Down; King James' Big Moment2019-03-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJobs Report Out Tomorrow; Mark Zuckerberg Unveiling New Privacy Focused Plan For Facebook; Sears Sued Over Craftsman; Huawei Sues U.S. Over Ban; Clinton's 2020 Vision; Bridging Bipartisan Divide; Dog Anti-Barking Ordinance; OhioGeneral Motors Plant Shuts Down; King James' Big MomentLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hello there, Ashley. Hello there, Lauren, thank you so much. Good morning, everyone, thanks for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday, March 7th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the east coast. The push for privacy at Facebook, CEO Mark Zuckerberg is shifting focus to private communication, the details on this major strategy shift for the world's largest social network.

Chinese Telecom giant Huawei making it official this morning, the company will file a lawsuit against the United States, saying that Congress acted as judge, jury, and executor. The end of an era, General Motors closing its Lordstown Ohio plant, what it means for workers there, as the White House focuses on jobs in America this week. Last one standing, there is one remaining blockbuster store in the entire world, find out where it is exactly, coming up right here, right now. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: All right. Welcome back. Well, markets are watching China and the U.S. Trade talk for any sign of progress this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating we are seeing a lower opening, for the broader averages this morning. Futures indicating the Dow Industrials will open down about 70 points, one-third of one percent, 76 points lower. S&P 500 right now is down 5-3/4 points, and the NASDAQ down 15. This as the U.S. trade deficit for 2018 hit a record of $891.3 billion, excluding services.

Joining me now to talk markets and investing, is Altium Wealth Portfolio Manager and Market Strategist, Michael Lee. Michael, good to see you this morning. What do you want to focus on here in terms of the China deal, the Fed, ECB meeting coming up -- what's the most important?

MICHAEL LEE, PORTFOLIO MANAGER & MARKET STRATEGIST, ALTIUM WEALTH MANAGEMENT: So, what I think is the most important is manufacturing in the U.S. The U.S. is out of the half a million new manufacturing jobs in the last two years, this is nothing short of remarkable. What I think everybody is missing is the multiplier effect that that's going to take effect into the economy. So, a dollar in manufacturing is a dollar (INAUDIBLE) to the economy.

Every new manufacturing job is responsible for two to four other jobs as you look into it, and what's really crazy and what's happened over the last couple of years is the U.S. resurgence in manufacturing. I think that has put the economy in a much sounder footing and while we didn't have four or five percent GDP growth last year, we had three. I think the chances of us falling below two or slowing into that secular stagnation that many were worried about that we're heading into than say, 2015-2016, it's just not a reality, and we're set up for a lot more continued growth.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we've got the February jobs report out tomorrow morning, 8:30 a.m. Eastern. The unemployment rate is expected to tick down to 3.9 percent. We're expecting 180,000 jobs added to the economy. Is this largely priced in? I mean, you talked about manufacturing jobs at the top. What would be a market mover from this report tomorrow?

LEE: Well -- so, what I'm looking for is not only the headline number but the revisions. So, we got, you know, 300,000 number in December which got it down to 225,000. The 300,000 number in January, we'll see what that's revised to. So, tomorrow, if we get a big blow-out number, we have two lower revisions. I would say, you know, that's fine. But if we're somewhere in the neighborhood of 200,000 jobs, you know, this is good. This is steady growth. In terms of a catalyst, if we have another 300,000 number, I think that could push the markets higher.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But look at these markets here. We had a really nice beginning to 2019, but this week is the weakest week, worst week for Dow, S&P, NASDAQ in several weeks.

LEE: Yes, it seems like we ran out of a little bit of a gas here. And I would say to most investors that have missed this rally, this is probably the beginnings of what could be a good entry point in that. The Fed is on hold, OK? The Fed has -- the Fed has decided they're not moving from the time being, and I think that's more political than it is economic. So, if you look at the Taylor Rule -- and the Taylor Rule is equilibrium between containing inflation and maximizing economic growth. That puts the frontend somewhere between 4-1/4 and 4-3/4.

So, the fact that the Fed stopping where it is now in the low to mid-twos, means that they want these trade -- they want the U.S. to win these trade wars, they want sustaining growth, they want a strong equity market, and so why fight the Fed.

BARTIROMO: Yes, one of the top stories in The Journal today about the trade deficit, basically, that the U.S. trade deficit expanded 10 percent last year. We mentioned it early, 891 billion despite the effort by this administration to narrow the gap.

LEE: Yes, you know, I don't know that narrowing the gap is the best metric. I think you want to look at total trade, and total trade for the U.S. expanded just under 370 billion last year. That's the largest -- that's the largest growth since 2011. And, also, tariffs in China have come down in 2017-2018 from just under 10 percent to 7-1/2 percent.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LEE: So, what we're doing, our economic strength, the tariffs, all of these policies are working in our favor. And if these policies were working in our favor, we wouldn't have added these manufacturing jobs, which I think going to have many long-term positive economic benefits.

BARTIROMO: Does it -- does it bother you that not just the Dow is having a tough week, but even the Dow Transports. You're looking at the worst performance here in 11 weeks or so.

LEE: No. I mean, market can't go straight up forever or straight down forever. So --

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you are talking about a very good rally year-to-date, 11 percent or something.

LEE: Yes. A very -- you know, a very strong move in a very short period of time. Eventually, you kind of ran out of gas.

BARTIROMO: So, what do you want to do, you want to take to the sidelines now, or should we be putting new -- looking at this market for entries?

LEE: Well, look, I think -- look, it's -- this is an extremely difficult market to trade. So, if you missed this rally, say, you are out in cash in the fall and you did not get invested after Christmas, you know, now is the time to start getting in because I ultimately think before the year is over, we hit all-time new highs on all three major investors.

BARTIROMO: Wow. New highs in '19, even though earnings are slowing down this year.

LEE: Yes, but we still have five percent revenue growth, and I'm a big believer that earnings are managed and manipulated to fit, you know, corporate strategy and, you know, markets (INAUDIBLE) and all sorts other factors need to be taken into account in addition to earnings. So, with five percent revenue growth not really stretched value -- multiple valuations, and what I think will be much greater economic growth this year, I'd say GDP comes in the high 2s versus the low 2s, which most people are predicting. Meaning, 2020 should look a lot better than I think people are looking at right now, and that 2020 earnings will be the story as you move into the back half of 2019.

BARTIROMO: That's what we're going to be trading on, the 2020 numbers. Yes, it's a good point. Michael, good to see you.

LEE: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Michael Lee joining us there. Be sure to tune in tomorrow morning for our full coverage of the Jobs report, "JOBS IN AMERICA" specials kicks off at 8:00 a.m. Eastern tomorrow morning when we identify where the jobs are, where the wage increases are as well, tomorrow morning, right here.

Meanwhile, top story this morning, Facebook's future, founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg unveiling a new plan to address privacy concerns. Something that Dagen McDowell has been looking up for a long time. Good morning, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Do not laugh, I'm being serious, this is a real story. So, Facebook says its future lies in private messaging, not the sharing of public content, which has been the focus of much ire. Here is what Facebook is doing, Facebook is going to start focusing on private messaging and small group chats.

This, according to a blog post from founder Mark Zuckerberg. It's going to offer encrypted messaging across all of its major products and allow people to make private conversations (INAUDIBLE) or make them disappear. Zuckerberg in that blog post also talks about it's going to develop products within these messaging services, payments, e-commerce products that will eventually allow it to diversify away from ad-supported businesses that led to these privacy mishaps, missteps, if you will.

Think of the WhatsApp messaging platform as kind of the idea of where Facebook is going with this. Here is what Mark Zuckerberg -- these are a couple of comments from that blog post I want to point out. "I believe the future of communication will increasingly shift to private encrypted services, where people can be confident what they say to each other stays secure, and their messages and content won't stick around forever. This is the future, I hope we will help bring about. I believe we should be working toward a world --

Let me read it like I would. This is how I was thinking about it. "I believe we should be working toward a world where people can speak privately and live freely, knowing that their information will only be seen by who they want to see it and won't all stick around forever. If we can help move the world in this direction, I will be proud of the difference we've made." Do you trust Mark Zuckerberg to keep your information private as the central issue? Facebook is not going to be able to read these messages, apparently, they are end-to-end encrypted, and advertisers won't be able to mine the contents to target users. It also basically helps alleviate the pressure on Facebook to monitor or police the content on its platforms.

But I will leave you with this, Jason Gay is the sports writer at The Wall Street Journal. Here's what he said, I'm paraphrasing on Twitter, this is like McDonalds pivoting to protecting cows. Back to you.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: That's a good one.

MCDOWELL: I couldn't steal it. I had to give Jason Gay credit for that.

BARTIROMO: Of course. Oh God. All right. Wow, that's a big change. We're going to talk more about that.

MCDOWELL: Do you believe him? Do you believe him?

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Do you trust Facebook more than Huawei, by the way? Taking me into the next story, that's another good question. Huawei is escalating its fight with the United States this morning. Lauren Simonetti with the details there. Lauren, good morning to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good question, Maria. Good morning. Well, Huawei is now suing the U.S. government, saying a law limiting its business in the United States is unconstitutional. The law was signed by President Trump last August. It bars federal agencies and their contractors from using Huawei equipment and Huawei services. Huawei has been accused of stealing trade secrets from U.S. companies, but its Chief Security Officer told you earlier this week, Maria, that Huawei is not a security threat.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Are you saying that Huawei Technologies has not stolen trade secrets from other companies in the west?

ANDY PURDY, CHIEF SECURITY OFFICER, HUAWEI TECHNOLOGIES: We have been trusted for the last 30 years in 170 countries. There have been no major cyber security incidents involving Huawei in the world. But we're not saying that because of the record, there should not be strict scrutiny of the kinds of products and technologies that we sell.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: The lawsuit marks the latest confrontation between China and the United States. Last year, it ended with the arrest of Huawei's Chief Financial Officer in Canada at the request of the U.S.

Well, Sears is headed back to courts. Stanley Black & Decker now suing Sears over its new line of tools under the Craftsman Ultimate Collection brand. Sears sold Craftsman brand to Stanley in 2017 for about $900 million and retained a limited license to sell some Craftsman products. But Sears is touting its story as the real home of Craftsman which Stanley says undermines its Craftsman products. Now you know.

And then there was one. Yes, Bend, Oregon is now home to the last Blockbuster Store in the entire world. There was one other location, it was in Perth, Australia. It is now closing. The manager of the last Blockbuster in Oregon says she's excited hers is the only one left on the planet. When two stores closed in Alaska last year, the Bend Blockbuster sold hats and they sold t-shirts celebrating the occasion. The store continues to attract tourists and those seeking nostalgia. But the issue is, a lot of people don't have DVDs anymore, the players. To play the DVDs that you can rent.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

SIMONETTI: So, you got to buy the t-shirt in memory of the fact that one still exists, right?

BARTIROMO: Yes (INAUDIBLE) the hats. Oh, the sign of the times. Thank you, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

BARTIROMO: All right, coming up next, high emotions at G.M. this morning, the final Chevy rolls off the line at the company's Lordstown, Ohio plant. We're taking a look at what's next for the automaker as that plant closes. Then, a change of plans, Hillary Clinton reportedly still mulling a run in 2020, despite saying that she would not early this week. Oh, I was kidding. It comes as one major pop star readies her voice for politics. All right here, next up. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big program this morning. Coming up, Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson is with us this morning. New York Congressman and Ways and Means Committee member Tom Reed joining us, he will be on the panel with New Jersey Congressman and Problem Solvers Caucus co-chair Josh Gottheimer joining us this morning. Florida Congressman and House Judiciary and Foreign Affairs Committee member Ted Deutch joining us, along with the former White House Press Secretary and author of "The Briefing" Sean Spicer here as well. Big three hours ahead, don't miss a moment of it.

And we want to kick it off here this hour with this, 2020 vision, Hillary Clinton saying that she is not running for President in 2020 but that may not be the case after all actually. New York Times White House Correspondent Maggie Haberman, tweeting this. "Spoke to someone close with Hillary -- with Clinton in contact with her today. They say she was not trying to be emphatic and close the door on running when she spoke to a local reporter yesterday, and that she was surprised but how definitively it played. The person also says that she is extremely unlikely to run, but that she remains bothered that she's expected to close the door on it when, say, John Kerry is not. She has told her team she is waiting at least to see the Mueller report."

Then this, Taylor Swift also weighing in on 2020, the popstar telling L Magazine that she's finding her voice in politics. She said, quote, "I'm going to do more to help. We have a big race coming up next year." Joining the conversation to talk about all of that, The Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman is here this morning, along with Fox News Contributor and Columnist for The Hill, Liz Peek. Great to see you guys this morning.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: I'm just going to lay down because I have such a headache from that.

(LAUGHTER)

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Really? What's bothering you?

PEEK: Fell by Hillary Clinton.

BARTIROMO: I think you talked about the Haberman tweet yesterday during the show. We didn't get to it. Wow.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: So, she's mad about Kerry not giving up. I think that's --

MCDOWELL: That's a -- that's a perfect gender pivot. Let me make it about my gender and not about the fact that I was this -- an utter failure for the Democratic Party and an embarrassment, too.

PEEK: But I think tying -- hitching her wagon to John Kerry's potential candidacy. Are you kidding? That's like a very low bar. Look, Hillary Clinton is not going to run for President because the Democratic Party absolutely wants her gone, end of story. And I think we've seen that in the way of -- their comments are covered and, you know, in terms of where her place in the party right now, it doesn't exist.

BARTIROMO: And you wrote a good piece about Hillary the other day about the fake crisis that she created, as you wrote.

PEEK: Yes, I mean, the crisis in America? Come on, folks, I mean, look at every gauge of consumer sentiment, comfort level, contentment with the way the country is going, Americans are feeling pretty good about where things are.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I just want to add really quickly. If Democrats truly feel that the election was stolen from Hillary Clinton, why aren't they shouting to the rooftop, screaming to the heavens for her to run? That it's her --

PEEK: That's a good point.

MCDOWELL: -- her role, it's hers, everybody ought to get out of the way -- they already tried that, but I didn't mean to interrupt.

BARTIROMO: Well, to chime that with -- you know, with Nadler and Elijah Cummings trying to get all these investigations going against the Trump administration. But I loved your op-ed in the Journal today, James.

FREEMAN: Oh, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about that, Republicans, Democrats, and decent guys, or any 2020 candidates interested in civility? You talk about all the troubled politicians are falling into when they try to cross partisan lines. Tell us more.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think they're actually -- among voters, I think there is an appetite for civility. I think people do find it a little exhausting watching this sort of non-stop partisan warfare, but it's been kind of an interesting disturbing phenomenon as candidates get into the 2020 race. Joe Biden thinking about a run and thinking about kind of being the moderate voice in the race, but he recanted after calling Mike Pence, the vice president, a decent guy, he got some static on Twitter from Cynthia Nixon, and he backed off agreeing that Pence was horrible. And now, you have Montana Governor Steve Bullok, testing the waters in Iowa, he's out there, and he's asked, do you think Pence is a decent guy?

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

FREEMAN: And even though he's worked with him and said nice things with him on others -- on other occasions, wouldn't go there. So, it's -- really, it's kind of an amazing time (INAUDIBLE) politics.

BARTIROMO: I don't -- yes. I don't know if it looks good on paper either.

FREEMAN: From a -- from a shareholder perspective. If you're saying -- when you said these huge audiences (INAUDIBLE) now we're going to tiny audiences, that doesn't sound like an advertisement bonanza --

MCDOWELL: Well, like --

IVES: And investors have seen -- and investors have seen through it. Investors looked at this and kind of, you know, I think shrugged their shoulders in terms of what this release ultimately (INAUDIBLE)

FREEMAN: (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: It lets -- it -- well, you have to think about it in terms of, say, the iMessage that Apple offers on its phones, which is a protected messaging service, like in iMessage, you can use your Apple Pay and send cash to people. That's the model that Facebook is potential using within the -- offering private messaging across its platform.

IVES: That's really the ultimate goal --

MCDOWELL: Right.

IVES: -- on the next step, but the first step is where you have to really get those private message and you could ultimately monetize.

BARTIROMO: It seems --

MCDOWELL: And then this raises the issue though of Mark Zuckerberg because he's -- well, a phony baloney, has damaged the company's reputation and his reputation so much, does anybody believe him? Again, it's -- this is impossible to quantify, but it raises the issue of like -- but can they build out this idea with the users trusting this guy?

BARTIROMO: What do you think?

IVES: Yes. Look, I think right now, it's an average, like, uphill battle for him to prove, you know, not just to consumers but even investors, that they can do this successfully, and that's why right now then you see the stock in the penalty box.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

IVES: And then the other side --

BARTIROMO: Are you still avoiding the stock?

IVES: Look, we continue -- we would much rather own a name like, you know, a name like Microsoft, on the Clouds on large cap --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

IVES: -- rather than Facebook here, you know, in terms of our opinion, or even Apple. Just to --

BARTIROMO: But what about Apple? I mean they have their own issues, slowing iPhone sales. Apple's app fees might be next because companies are pushing back on how much Apple is charging them.

IVES: Look, iPhones obviously fell off the cliff in China, and it's really about to services business, 50 billion a year right now. And, look, you saw with Netflix, Netflix pulled the ripcord going off of, you know, the App Store, and I think that's why right now for Apple, March 25th, they'll announce their video streaming service, it's about putting few (INAUDIBLE) on that content on the services side. We ultimately think Apple is continuing to have pressure to do an acquisition on content, on original content. And I think right now, remember that case is going to the courts, too, in terms of the App Store.

PEEK: It seems to me one of the sort of derivative problems for the tech companies is that with all these bad publicity, Europe is feeling freer and freer to impose taxes on revenues. I mean, you know -- and this is a small thing, but Europeans really don't like these big tech companies very well, and I think the latest thing was in fact a proposal that they're going to start to tax revenues. I mean maybe that's what all this bad publicity leads to, not regulations on privacy because we all agree that's unenforceable possibly. But simply a money pull.

IVES: Yes, and, look, the four letters that no tech company wants to hear, GDPR.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well --

IVES: And if you look at what happened in Europe --

BARTIROMO: It's in place.

IVES: And it's in place, and that's really the star, and I think that's the fear of tech companies, but when you look at Apple specifically, services is really the linchpin to the valuation, the installed base. Right now, it's seeing more and more pressure on the services side, and I think Netflix is just the start of this.

PEEK: Interesting.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We will leave it there. It's great to have you on the program, Dan.

IVES: No, thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Dan Ives. Joining us there. Coming up, high emotions at General Motors this morning, the final Chevy rolls off the line at the company's Lordstown Ohio Plant, we're taking a look at what's next for the automaker. by Caitlin Yilek Presidential nominee Joe Biden and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders are the top two recipients of 2020 campaign contributions among Americans who work at all 10 of the biggest U.S. tech companies, according to a nonpartisan watchdog organization. Federal Election Commission data compiled by the Center for Responsive Politics show a sea of blue at Apple , Amazon , Microsoft , Alphabet , Facebook , Nvidia , PayPal , Adobe , Intel and SalesForce.com , the 10 U.S. tech companies with the highest market caps. President Donald Trump was the only Republican among the top 10 recipients of political donations at seven of the 10 companies. No Republican registered in the top tier at Adobe, Facebook and Google's parent company Alphabet. Workers at all 10 have favored Democrats heavily with their giving, even though tech stocks and profits have soared during the Trump’s presidency. One leader in Silicon Valley thinks she knows why: a guilt complex. “I think [employees] end up with a lot of money and not particularly—I’m now armchair psychologizing—but probably feeling really guilty, or at least pretty lucky, and wanting to pay back some of that,” said Misha Chellam, founder of the Council on Technology and Society. The group bills itself as a noprofit community of venture capitalists, startup CEOs, and big tech companies. Chellam said social issues are likely more of a priority than headier issues like antitrust legislation. “We see people donating or voting against their economic self-interest all the time,” he said. Political contributions tracked by the center include money from political action committees fnuded by companies, plus donations made by employees, owners, and their immediate family members. Publicly traded companies cannot themselves contribute to candidates or party-run committees. Poltical donors in the tech industry have long been among the most partisan , according to the center, a nonpartisan watchdog famous for its “Open Secrets” website. Employees at tech companies in the U.S. have showered Democrats with nearly $23 million during the current election cycle. Republicans hauled in just $3.3 million. Democrats’ receipts from Big Tech totaled $9.2 million eight years ago, during the 2012 cycle, the last time an incumbent president stood for re-election. Republican donations that year were on par with their 2020 level, still barely one-third of what their opponents raised from top Silicon Valley brands. Donations from the tech sector have also given a boost to Democratic candidates in tight Senate races, including Mark Kelly in Arizona and Amy McGrath in Kentucky. The top 10 companies have donated $18.5 million to Democratic candidates at the federal level in 2019 and 2020, compared with nearly $2.6 million that went to Republicans. Stuffing Democratic pockets with campaign cash is no guarantee it won't be openly hostile to Silicon Valley. Democrats have threatened to regulate tech giants, even as Republicans have accused them of censoring free speech online. And while tech employees favor Democrats, company executives have cultivated relationships with the Trump White House. Apple’s Tim Cook has visited 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue to discuss jobs training, and Trump repaid the favor with a visit to an Apple manufacturing plant in Texas. Cook had been alarmed by Trump's stated aim of piling new tariffs on everything China exports to the U.S. Like many of its peers, Apple might have to raise its prices if Trump raised the cost of doing transpacific business. Microsoft worked closely with the Trump administration in its failed bid to acquire Chinese video app TikTok. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with Trump in 2019. And despite their eagerness to engage with federal officeholders and regulators 2,800 miles away, America's tech titans are barely a blip on the radar screen of U.S. political largesse. Still, the tech industry hardly registers among the top 50 organizations making political donations in the election cycle that will culminate on Nov. 3. Only Alphabet, Amazon and Microsoft are on that list. Political money emerging from two of the top four organizations, shipping company Uline Inc. and Blackstone Group, have favored Republicans. Donations to Republicans from those companies, their affiliates and their employees fell just short of $69 million as of Sept. 8. (Edited by Jeff Epstein, Matt Rasnic and David Martosko.)

urn:contentItem:5VYV-06P1-JB20-G14Y-00000-00Joe Biden Announces 2020 Run; Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong-un Historic Summit; Bayer Faces Shareholder Showdown Over Monsanto; Venmo has Over 40 Million Users; Magic Johnson Quit Over e-mail; Pizza Hut Draft Special2019-04-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Alex Moazed, Doug WeadNEWSFinancial042502cb.231Joe Biden Announces 2020 Run; Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong-un Historic Summit; Bayer Faces Shareholder Showdown Over Monsanto; Venmo has Over 40 Million Users; Magic Johnson Quit Over e-mail; Pizza Hut Draft SpecialMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, James Freeman, Cheryl Casone, Donna Brazile, Jared Max, Walid Phares

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, April 25th.

We have breaking news this morning.

Joe Biden has entered the 2020 presidential race.

We're talking with former DNC Chairman Donna Brazile this morning about what his candidacy means to the already crowded field of Democratic contenders this morning.

Plus earnings in focus, 3M with a miss on revenue and earnings, set to shave more than 100 points off the Dow Industrials right at the opening of trading this morning.

Southwest says that the grounding of the 737 contributed to a $200 million hit on revenue in the quarter.

We are waiting on Amazon and Starbucks and Ford, that happens after the bell tonight. We have a preview. Take a look, at 3m shares right now nine and two-thirds percent. A big hit on the heels of that miss on revenue.

Southwest Airlines is up. It's almost 3 percent on its numbers which were better than expected despite the hit from the 737.

Merger breakdown -- Deutsche Bank ending talks with Commerzbank, the merger between the two ailing banks would have created Germany's largest financial institution.

Markets this morning look like this. Futures indicating a lower opening for the broader averages. Dow Industrials now down 113 points as I said, largely due to 3M. S&P 500 is up, futures showing a gain there and the Nasdaq futures right now up 19 points, that's a quarter of a percent higher on Nasdaq.

Yesterday's markets were lower -- the Dow, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq finished down as you can see.

Microsoft and Disney though hit record highs. The DowIndustrials were down 59 points, the S&P down 6.5 and the Nasdaq down 18 points at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday.

European indices this morning are lower. FT 100 down 21 points, a third of a percent. The CAC in Paris down 13, quarter of a percent. Dax index in Germany lower by 17.

In Asia overnight, mixed story there. You have the Bank of Japan saying it's not going to ease and its' not going to cut right now. It's not going to raise either. The Nikkei average as expected from the BOJ, the Nikkei average was up one of half of 1 percent.

Shanghai getting a hit. Take a look at China. The index there down two and-a-half percent overnight. The Hang Seng and the Kospi also lower.

The Bank of Japan said that it will hold rates until -- at zero until the spring of 2020. There is concern about slowing growth in Japan and reaching the 2 percent inflation objective as well.

Resignation revelation, Magic Johnson reportedly resigned from the Lakers after accidentally being copied on an e-mail about bad job performance -- his own.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman; and PWC partner Mitch Roschelle. Great to see everybody this morning.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: It wouldn't be the first time somebody stumbled across an e-mail that they weren't supposed to get.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We've got to be careful when you're e-mailing people and who you cc on it. Don't cc the subject.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Yes. People are very careful in my office not to copy me, because they know it would hurt my feelings.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: You're so thin-skinned.

BARTIROMO: Breaking news: Joe Biden is in. And he's going to give his first interview to "The View". Dagen -- what's that all about? ?

MCDOWELL: So he is going to join "The View" tomorrow for his first interview since announcing that he's entering the 2020 presidential race. And then Robin Roberts on Tuesday will have an interview with Joe and his wife, Dr. Jill Biden -- that.

So part of this is the relationship between -- Meghan McCain is one of the co-hosts on "The View. And Joe Biden -- Meghan tweeted back on April 1st that Joe Biden is one of the truly decent and compassionate men in all of American politics. He helped her through her father's cancer diagnosis. Again -- Joe Biden's son, Bo, died of the same brain cancer, glioblastoma.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- through his treatment and ultimate passing. "More than any one of my father's friends combined I wish there was more empathy from our politicians, not less."

That kind of led to speculation -- there was a story going around yesterday that the McCain family was going to support Joe Biden trying to unseat President Trump. Cindy McCain came out on Twitter yesterday and said "Joe Biden is a wonderful man and dear friend of the McCain family. However, I have no intention of getting involved in presidential politics," said Cindy McCain.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I saw that tweet. So look, we were expecting that Joe Biden enters the race and he did so on YouTube. He launched his 2020 presidential campaign like this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I believe history will look back on four years of this president and all he embraces as an aberrant moment in time.

But if we give Donald Trump eight years in the White House, he will forever and fundamentally alter the character of this nation -- who we are. And I cannot stand by and watch that happen.

The core values of this nation are standing in the world, our very democracy, everything that made America, America is at stake. That's why today I'm announcing my candidacy for president of the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now over the phone is former Democratic National Committee chairman and Fox News contributor Donna Brazile. Donna -- always a pleasure to talk with you. Thanks so much for weighing in this morning.

DONNA BRAZILE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR (via telephone): Absolutely. Look, this is a big deal. Joe Biden is not only a proven leader but he is someone I think that will unify many Democrats, especially those who are center left.

I think he will bring much need assets to the field. But this is not going to be a cake walk, Maria. He has many candidates in the race already that's raising money and building up a very big grass roots operation.

So Joe Biden I think is talented and let's see if he can appeal to a younger generation of Democrats who may not be as familiar with his record.

BARTIROMO: Donna, let me ask you, what do you think he's talking about in that the video when he says we can't have Donald Trump in for eight years because he will forever alter the nation. Is he talking about the fact that Donald Trump, should he win another four years, will name more Supreme Court justices?

BRAZILE: Well, that's part of the argument. But I do believe that there's a large group of people in this country, especially in the Democratic Party, that believe that it's time for a different form of leadership.

They believe that the President is divisive, that he has not tried to unify the country. He is basically focused on his base and not really worked to improve America's standing in the world.

So Joe Biden also said -- I just saw the video for the second time -- that it's time for respected leadership on the world stage, dignified leadership at home. It is time for equal rights and equal justice.

So this is, again, a candidate who knows his way around Washington but also I believe his biggest challenge is to appeal to a different generation of Americans who may not be as familiar with his record.

FREEMAN: Donna -- hi. James Freeman here at the "Wall Street Journal". Wondering about the issue of climate for Biden. The premise of his candidacy it seems to me is that he can win blue collar voters in the industrial Midwest. He has called climate the biggest threat we face. But if he goes all the way to the GREEN NEW DEAL where the senators running for the Democratic nomination have gone, doesn't he alienate those blue collar voters?

BRAZILE: Well, everyone knows that, you know, the Obama-Biden administration made a big push for the Paris accord. They made a big push to make sure that we had a plan to begin the transition to renewable fuel and renewable energy.

So I don't think Joe Biden's record on climate will put him in any danger of reaching out to blue collar voters in the Midwest or in the sun belt.

ROSCHELLE: Donna, good morning. Mitch Roschelle.

President Obama referred to it as a circular firing squad. How much Kevlar is Biden going to have to wear to avoid getting hit with shrapnel once the debates start.

BRAZILE: well I mean, you know, He's the front runner. As one of the frontrunners in the Democratic Party, many of the candidates will go after his record. They will also try to point out that the American people are not interested in a third Obama, Biden term. So I'm sure the vice president can handle all of the incumbents.

MCDOWELL: Donna, there was -- Maria brought this up earlier, Mike Emmanuel too at Fox News. This is Dagen McDowell, by the way. Made it clear that President Obama has said that he does not to endorse early in the primary process if at all in the primaries. What do you make of that? Seems a little bit odd.

BRAZILE: No, I think that's a great move on his part. Look, president Obama along with the former first lady has spent -- they've spent a lot of time trying to encourage young people to vote. They have embarked on a campaign to help with the reapportionment and redistricting battles ahead. I think they're going to continue to enlarge the electorate and convince a new generation of Americans to heed the call of leadership.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But I mean, the fact that it's his vice president and he's not going to be there, I mean, you've got a crowded field here, Donna. And it's interesting to note, you know, that he's coming out as a moderate but largely the entire field is progressive, radical in many cases. Is he going to be able to break through all the radicals?

BRAZILE: Well, the only thing radical within the Democratic Party or the Republican Party are those that sit on the sidelines and not get involved. These are people who --

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: Oh no, no, no. No I'm talking about Bernie Sanders. I'm talking about Bernie Sanders, Medicare for all. I'm talking about Elizabeth Warren and her wealth tax. I'm talking about AOC in the party, you know. I'm talking about the radical ideas comings out of the Democratic Party right now -- Donna.

(CROSSTALKING)

BRAZILE: But these are ideas, I mean you are bringing forward ideas. Yes. But these are public policy ideas. Raising the minimum wage, trying to find jobs for people who are still out there looking. I mean --

BARTIROMO: No, I'm talking about the Green New Deal and the Medicare for all, Donna.

BRAZILE: Well, the cost of healthcare rising and more and more Americans spending their disposable income on healthcare, I mean, these are issues that people would like us to talk about.

I don't believe that we have all of the solutions, but you cannot allow these programs to go unaddressed. Look, go back to Joe Biden. Joe Biden has a wonderful opportunity because he is a proven leader, because he's run twice before. He has high name recognition.

Can he raise the money? Can he pull together a coalition? Can he convince a new generation of Americans that he has a vision for the future? And if he can, he will become the Democratic nominee. But it's going to be a battle.

BARTIROMO: Yes, especially with Bernie Sanders raising all that money. Bernie Sanders has been very successful.

BRAZILE: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Right now --

BRAZILE: People know Bernie. They know Bernie, they know his record, they know what he stands for. They know that he's an independent.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BRAZILE: He caucuses with the Democrats. And he's the only self-identified Democratic socialist in the race. But Joe Biden brings a different type of leadership, a different message. But again, like many of the candidates of his generation, I think there's a hunger within the Democratic Party for new leadership and a new vision.

And that's one of his challenges. But he will bring tremendous assets to the race.

MCDOWELL: Donna, really quickly -- it's Dagen again. Bernie Sanders kind of got booed. When he -- he name-dropped Dr. Martin Luther King at the "she, the people" summit said that I marched on Washington with Dr. King and he was feeling some heat from the crowd to the point he had to kind of hold up his finger, trying to get a word in. What does that mean? What did that say?

BRAZILE: Because, you know, it's one thing to say I marched with Dr. back in 1963, 1965 -- whatever year you marched. What are you doing now? You know, it's an old song that Janet Jackson performed. What have you done for us lately. What are you doing now about criminal justice reform? What are you doing now to bring jobs and opportunities to the inner city? What are you doing now to build a new class of --

BARTIROMO: Well President Trump did actually did -- the President Trump --

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: President Trump did prison reform as well.

BRAZILE: Well, look, President Trump has challenge as well. But as you know, President Trump would spin it that he was down in Atlanta while Bernie was in Houston -- he was at a very important lead in on the opioid crisis. Something else that we have to address as well.

BARTIROMO: For sure. Donna -- it's great to get your insights. Thanks so much.

BRAZILE: Look, forward to seeing you soon.

BARTIROMO: And you too. Donna Brazile joining us there.

Joe Biden becoming one of 12 vice presidents to seek the White House throughout history. Some have been successful, others not so much.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE H.W. BUSH, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: For seven and-a- half years I've helped the President conduct the most difficult job on earth. Ronald Reagan asked for and received my candor.

Now you must see me for what I am, the Republican candidate for president of the United States.

AL GORE, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: For almost eight years now I've been the partner of a leader who moved us out of the valley of recession and into the longest period of prosperity in American history. I say to you tonight, millions of Americans will remember for a long time to come because of the job that's been done by President Bill Clinton.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was then vice presidents George H.W. Bush and Al Gore accepting their nominations for president back in 1988 and the year 2000.

One of those men, of course, was successful; the other was not. Today another vice president enters the race. Historically it might not be all easy for Joe Biden. Joining us right now is presidential historian Doug Wead. Doug -- great to see you this morning. Thanks for coming in.

DOUG WEAD, PRESIDENTIAL HISTORIAN: Hi -- Maria.

Your reaction this morning?

WEAD: Well, you know, if you're betting in Las Vegas, 14 vice presidents have become presidents of the United States. But as you said, it's very hard, only four were elected as sitting vice presidents and only one in all of history took a sabbatical like Joe Biden and then came back and won. So it's going to be brutal, I'll put it that way.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What does he need to do to break through?

WEAD: Well, he's got to distinguish himself from the others and he's going to have to run in the primaries, not the general. George H.W. Bush 1985 started his campaign. I tell you -- Maria, it looked like the highway was absolutely clear all the way to the presidency. He had money, name recognition but almost didn't make it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Unbelievable. Doug -- it's great to get your insights. Thank you.

WEAD: Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Doug Wead.

Coming up -- coming up next, merger collapse, Deutsche Bank ending talks with Commerzbank. We've got the details after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We've got breaking news this morning. It's official, Joe Biden has entered the 2020 presidential race. We've got a lot more coming up throughout the morning to look at that.

But first, Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank scrap merger talks.

Cheryl Casone with the details there -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Big news breaking this morning -- Maria. The Deutsche Bank/Commerzbank deal was expected to be announced as soon as tomorrow. "Wall Street Journal" though is reporting that the agreement lacked investor support and it faced stiff opposition from labor unions.

The merger between the two struggling banks would have created Germany's largest financial institution. And is no more.

Well, the measles outbreak in the U.S. surging to a 25-year high. 69 new cases reported. The CDC in just this past weeks folks, this placed the number of cases to 695 across 22 save. This is the worst tally since 1994. The highest number of outbreaks is here in New York and also in Washington state.

Well, Amazon's Alexa under fire again over privacy worries. Workers at the company can reportedly use location data to find users' home address through Alexa.

Enough incidents have been reported so far but Amazon says that quote, "Access to internal tools is highly controlled and it's only granted to a limited number of employees who require these tools to train and improve the service for those users that like Alexa.

Amazon we should say, the big news going to report their latest earnings, that's after the bell today. Ahead of all that, in the premarket -- Maria, the stock by a little more than 1 percent. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Cheryl -- thank you so much.

James, what do you think about that?

FREEMAN: You know this measles outbreak is just -- it's tragic. It is -- people believing junk science, you've got to vaccinate. This is a disease that was eradicated years ago. Now it's back in the United States. It can be fatal and it also destroys the immune system so that kids who get it can be vulnerable to other illnesses.

BARTIROMO: There's a lot of misinformation about vaccines. And that's the issue here.

FREEMAN: Yes. And you know, these objections, they're not really religious objections in many cases. But I think people have unfortunately -- I guess they're not believing medical authorities for some reason. They're getting bad information from celebrities who have made this kind of a campaign. You got to vaccinate.

MCDOWELL: But the problem is, this misinformation campaign by celebrities and the like has been going on for years about vaccinations.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And now you see the results of basically preaching these individuals with a little bit of name recognition, preaching magic at people and just preaching lies and now it's kind of gotten away from the entire nation.

BARTIROMO: All right. We've got to jump we've got to jump. Biden's White House bid is up next. The former vice president adding his name to the crowded Democratic field.

Plus Magic Johnson's shocking exit from the Lakers. Wait until you see what happened. Reportedly he wasp copied accidentally on an e-mail about his bad performance.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Earnings in focus this morning, Facebook reporting first quarter results, beating on both earnings per share and revenue. The company attributing the strong numbers to growth in stories, users and ads. The stock is up almost 9 percent right now.

Microsoft posted a double beat last night as well, the company moving past a trillion dollar market value. The market cap above a trillion dollars with the most recent move up, up 5 percent this morning.

This is a third of these major tech companies to hit the valuation of a trillion dollars after Apple and Amazon. Amazon releasing hits first quarter numbers later this afternoon, right after the close.

Joining us right now is Applico CEO, Alex Moazed and joining us right now. Alex -- good to see you.

ALEX MOAZED, APPLICO CEO: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. But first sort of assess the field for us in terms of these tech companies. What was your reaction to all the earnings that we saw.

MOAZED: We're really just getting started with big tech. These tech monopolies like Microsoft and Facebook, could be earnings and that's just the beginning. And I predict that Amazon is also going to beat quite aggressively.

BARTIROMO: Yes but we were tough on her earlier. I mean the business model of selling data to the advertising companies. I mean this breach of privacy that we see over and over again.

Is this just a state of the business model. Do you really want to own a stock if you see these kinds of pressure on the companies business model?

MOAZED: You know, the funny thing is privacy actually helps them and supports them to actually have a more dominant role if we look at what GDPR has done to Factbook and Google in the E.U.

BARTIROMO: Mitch.

ROSCHELLE: Are they able to grow users and do they need users to grow and do privacy concerns sort of stunt user growth?

MOAZED: Privacy concerns get this legislation going. That actually prevents the competition from Facebook and Google, from competing with them. So GDPR put all these rules and fines into place and Facebook and Google are in the best position to comply with those rules, post GDPR, Facebook and google have a more dominant share of digital advertising as a result.

ROSCHELLE: So the fundamentals of their business may not be changing but they're freezing out competition.

MCDOWELL: Until Elizabeth Warren comes along and breaks the company up.

BARTIROMO: What if she breaks them up.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly.

FREEMAN: And the theory is that they're kind of dominant monopolies and that there's not a market place competitor able to displace them which I think is your view as well.

MOAZED: Yes. and that's where -- that's really the vulnerability That's really the vulnerability, to your point right, is really the anti-trust regulation that these businesses are monopolies. But the question is, how do they compete with their supply and that's where they get into trouble. How are they regulating supply? How are they regulating the sellers on Amazon or the content creators on Facebook or Twitter. That's really where they're vulnerable.

FREEMAN: But you look at the history of tech. AOL was thought to dominate online consumer activity. Yahoo at one time dominating the search business. Competition tends to come out of nowhere more quickly than we expect.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good point there.

MOAZED: There is a lot of competition amongst the big tech monopolies. They do compete quite aggressively.

BARTIROMO: Not for google, they have 90 percent market share in search.

MOAZED: Google has -- yes magically somehow those numbers are under 70 percent but Google absolutely has a monopoly on search. They have a monopoly on content if you look in YouTube. And they're just getting started. There's huge growth in front of these companies.

BARTIROMO: You're saying it's 70 percent, not 90 percent.

MOAZED: They will report under 70 percent. But if you look internationally it's always over 70 percent. It's funny how those numbers work out.

BARTIROMO: Yes. They don't want to show that it's dominant.

MOAZED: Yes. That would create some problems. But when it comes to their suppliers, that's really where this can be a problem for them, especially as we look towards, say, the elections next year.

BARTIROMO: Tell us what Applico does.

MOAZED: Applico helps these old, traditional incumbents say I need to compete against big tech, big tech has these new business models, I should build or buy this new business model because this is the inevitable future state of my industry.

ROSCHELLE: So you help an old analog business become more digital.

MOAZED: Yes, by essentially reinventing themselves. Amazon, Facebook, Microsoft, Google, they have the new business model. Why aren't the traditional companies trying to adopt the new as opposed to the new tech trying to go into the old.

MCDOWELL: Like geo tagging, you got your McDonald's app with your location on, you drive by McDonald's, it will let you know, we'll have your favorite quarter pounder with cheese and large fry ready for you, you can just hit a button, order it and pull through the drive-through and they have it ready for you. That's traditional business doing something right.

MOAZED: Yes.

FREEMAN: Well, that's the golden arches in golden years I was hoping for.

BARTIROMO: Not the AARP.

MOAZED: I think Amazon, you know. Just in the past year they turned on the revenues from advertising on the marketplace, but they have multiple other platform businesses coming behind that. B2B distribution is three times the size of consumer retail, it's a $6-8 trillion market. Consumer retails to a half trillion.

MOAZED: I think Amazon is going to do very well.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, April 25th.

We have breaking news this morning, Joe Biden has entered the 2020 presidential race officially. Former Trump campaign foreign policy affairs expert Walid Phares is with us. He will weigh in on that, coming up.

Japan was up about a half a percent, the Bank of Japan said that it is keeping extremely low interest rates where they are until at least the spring of 2020, pretty much expected that the BOJ wasn't going to do anything.

We've got streaming wars that viewers love watching reruns on Netflix. But some popular shows could be pulled. Which of your favorite shows could go away and not be on Netflix. We're going to tell you.

Plus, resignation revelations, check this out, Magic Johnson reportedly resigning from the Lakers after accidentally being copied on an e-mail about his bad job performance. All those stories coming up.

But first, the breaking news of the morning and that is Joe Biden made it official, entering the 2020 presidential race. Joining an already crowded Democratic field.

Joining us right now is former Trump campaign foreign policy advisor, Fox News national security and foreign affairs expert, Walid Phares. And great to see you, Walid. Thanks very much for weighing in here.

WALID PHARES, FOX NEWS NATIONAL SECURITY AND FOREIGN AFFAIRS ANALYST: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to Joe Biden.

PHARES: Well, that was expected by most observers, that the most senior politician in the Democratic Party, the former vice president is in the best position in view of his advisors and the supporters to be the leading candidates of that field.

BARTIROMO: How significant a challenge is this to Donald Trump?

PHARES: Probably this is the best shot that the Democratic party would have, because Biden is experienced. He was for eight years in the White House and all is going to rest now with his team, who is he going to have as a teammate, who is going to be the vice presidential candidate would be the bigger question.

FREEMAN: Walid, hi, James Freeman here with the Wall Street Journal. How would a Biden foreign policy differ from the Trump foreign policy?

PHARES: Oh, it will be completely different. It will be a return to the Obama administration policies, including let's begin with Iran deal, a return to the Iran deal, a different policy with China. I am not sure what they're going to do with North Korea now that Chairman Kim is meeting with Putin. That's changing a lot of the chess game going on. So, we're going to see -- we're going to see a very clear difference between a Biden platform and a Trump platform.

ROSCHELLE: Walid, good morning, Mitch Roschelle. You mentioned the China deal and I think we've talked about on the air Chinese are slow-playing the Trump administration in hopes that he doesn't win re-election and they don't have to sort of make the deal that's on the table.

How do you think China would potentially handicap a Biden administration and how could that influence potentially the remainder of the Trump first term from a negotiating with China perspective?

PHARES: Well, your angle is very interesting because it applies not only to China but to Iran and many other players who are under pressure by the Trump administration. China is the biggest actor who's under pressure -- who are under pressure to get a new deal in terms of finances, in terms of economy. And China is playing all the cards including as I said earlier, Chairman Kim now meeting with President Putin. I believe China is behind that. So that it's not dealing with this issue and now it's opening a new chapter so far that president Putin will be the one who will bring back Kim to the table of negotiations.

So I believe as you said that the next year and-a-half are going to be attempts by many international players to gain time, hoping that there will be no second presidency for President Trump but they may fail.

MCDOWELL: The meeting -- the meeting between -- it's Dagen McDowell, Walid. The meeting between Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un, how is that not a black eye for the Trump administration and what's been going on with our two less than successful summits with North Korea?

PHARES: I think Chairman Kim meeting with Putin is in preparation and repositioning to speak with our president, with President Trump. That's what he's trying to do.

Chapter one failed. I mean, it all began when Kim fired those missiles, expecting that as was the case before, a Trump administration is going to go and negotiate and accept some sort of aid. It did not work.

President Trump tweeted first and then sent task forces. North Korean leaders ran to China and China told them you have to talk with the United States, and we saw what we saw. I mean, he was gratified that he has been at the high visibility. But when the time came and Trump asked him to deliver on nukes, he couldn't. So now he's going to Putin.

And Putin, it's very good for him because he's going to reposition himself to speak with President Trump after two years of -- you know, impossibilities.

BARTIROMO: And then there's China. The White House announcing that U.S. trade representative Robert Lighthizer and Secretary of Treasury Steven Mnuchin are headed back to Beijing next week. They're going to go on the 30th to resume talks.

First, your thoughts on that. Are we going to see a deal? And what do you think Biden's policy platform will be? Will he take on China the way the president has?

PHARES: He is going in my view to be tougher on China but in reality they're going to negotiate with China from a weaker position. The Trump administration is stronger in terms of narrative but they will try to cut a deal with China and China understands that now they have two partners that they're going to be dealing with this, a sitting president and a strong candidate.

BARTIROMO: Yes, do you think Biden has articulated his strategy yet? What is it? I mean, or is it go -- I mean, is it going to be anything more than take down Trump?

PHARES: It's going to be first of all a strong primary. He's going to distinguish himself on foreign policy from everybody else. He's going to tell them, look, I have been vice-president for eight years, I know better on China, on Iran, on Russia and everything else, to win that first battle.

These would be the criticisms that will be used by vice president -- former vice president Biden against our president now.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that makes a lot of sense. Walid, great to have your insights. Thank you so much.

PHARES: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5W3S-G2N1-JBSS-S094-00000-00Joe Biden: Breaking up Facebook deserves 'really hard look'2019-05-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJoe Biden: Breaking up Facebook deserves 'really hard look'By Eric Bradner, CNN(CNN)

(CNN) -- Former Vice President Joe Biden said Monday in an interview with The Associated Press that breaking up Facebook is "something we should take a really hard look at."

The 2020 Democratic presidential front-runner's comment is the latest sign of growing skepticism on the left of major technology companies as they become increasingly intertwined with Americans' lives.

"I don't think we spend nearly enough time focusing on antitrust measures. And the truth of the matter is, I think it's something we should take a really hard look at," Biden told the AP.

Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, one of Biden's competitors for the Democratic nomination, has led the push for the break-up of big tech. In March she proposed that Facebook, Google and Amazon be dismantled, with the companies forced to sell off some of their major acquisitions, like Facebook's Instagram and WhatsApp.

In an interview with The Associated Press, Biden praised Warren for her push, saying that she "has a very strong case to be made." But he also said it is "premature" to make a final judgment.

Biden's comments come the day after fellow 2020 contender Sen. Kamala Harris of California said on CNN that the United States "should seriously take a look at" dismantling Facebook.

Harris said Facebook "has experienced massive growth and has prioritized its growth over the best interests of its consumers, especially on the issue of privacy." She said there needs to be "serious regulation" and "more oversight" of Facebook.

Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes wrote in a New York Times op-ed that the company has become a monopoly and should be forced to sell off Instagram and WhatsApp -- a position that led to Democratic presidential candidates weighing in.

Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders praised Hughes' op-ed on Twitter.

"We are living in an era of monopolies that dominate every aspect of our lives -- including our government. It's time to take that power back," Sanders tweeted.

urn:contentItem:5W3S-G2P1-JBPX-X0B7-00000-00Joe Biden: Breaking up Facebook deserves 'really hard look'2019-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisPOLITICSJoe Biden: Breaking up Facebook deserves 'really hard look'By Eric Bradner, CNN

Former Vice President Joe Biden said Monday in an interview with The Associated Press that breaking up Facebook is "something we should take a really hard look at."

The 2020 Democratic presidential front-runner's comment is the latest sign of growing skepticism on the left of major technology companies as they become increasingly intertwined with Americans' lives.

"I don't think we spend nearly enough time focusing on antitrust measures. And the truth of the matter is, I think it's something we should take a really hard look at," Biden told the AP.

Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, one of Biden's competitors for the Democratic nomination, has led the push for the break-up of big tech. In March she proposed that Facebook, Google and Amazon be dismantled, with the companies forced to sell off some of their major acquisitions, like Facebook's Instagram and WhatsApp.

In an interview with The Associated Press, Biden praised Warren for her push, saying that she "has a very strong case to be made." But he also said it is "premature" to make a final judgment.

Biden's comments come the day after fellow 2020 contender Sen. Kamala Harris of California said on CNN that the United States "should seriously take a look at" dismantling Facebook.

Harris said Facebook "has experienced massive growth and has prioritized its growth over the best interests of its consumers, especially on the issue of privacy." She said there needs to be "serious regulation" and "more oversight" of Facebook.

Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes wrote in a New York Times op-ed that the company has become a monopoly and should be forced to sell off Instagram and WhatsApp -- a position that led to Democratic presidential candidates weighing in.

Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders praised Hughes' op-ed on Twitter.

"We are living in an era of monopolies that dominate every aspect of our lives -- including our government. It's time to take that power back," Sanders tweeted.

New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker has opposed Facebook's break-up, calling it "more like a Donald Trump thing" in an interview with ABC on Sunday.

"I don't think that a president should be running around pointing at companies and saying break them up without any kind of process here," Booker said. "It's not me and my own personal opinion about going after folks. That sounds more like a Donald Trump thing to say, 'I'm going to break up you guys.'"

urn:contentItem:5Y0S-15D1-F03R-N239-00000-00Joe Biden Can't Tell The Difference Between The 1st Amendment Section 230; Still Thinks Video Games Cause Violence2020-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJoe Biden Can't Tell The Difference Between The 1st Amendment Section 230; Still Thinks Video Games Cause ViolenceMike Masnick

Jan 17, 2020( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) Joe Biden is the latest Democratic candidate for President interviewed by the NY Times editorial board, and if you're interested in tech policy, well, it's a doozy. Biden seems confused, misinformed, or simply wrong about a lot of issues from free speech to Section 230 to copyright to video games. It's really bad. We already knew he was on an anti 230 kick when he gave a confused quote[1] on it late last year, but for the NY Times he goes even further[2]:Charlie Warzel: Sure.

Mr. Vice President, in October, your campaign sent a letter to Facebook regarding an ad that falsely claimed that you blackmailed Ukrainian officials to not investigate your son. I'm curious, did that experience, dealing with Facebook and their power, did that change the way that you see the power of tech platforms right now? No, I've never been a fan of Facebook, as you probably know. I've never been a big Zuckerberg fan. I think he's a real problem. I think —— CW: Can you elaborate? No, I can. He knows better. And you know, from my perspective, I've been in the view that not only should we be worrying about the concentration of power, we should be worried about the lack of privacy and them being exempt, which you're not exempt. [The Times] can't write something you know to be false and be exempt from being sued. But he can. The idea that it's a tech company is that Section 230 should be revoked, immediately should be revoked, number one. For Zuckerberg and other platforms. CW: That's a pretty foundational laws of the modern internet. That's right. Exactly right. And it should be revoked. It should be revoked because it is not merely an internet company. It is propagating falsehoods they know to be false, and we should be setting standards not unlike the Europeans are doing relative to privacy. You guys still have editors. I'm sitting with them. Not a joke. There is no editorial impact at all on Facebook. None. None whatsoever. It's irresponsible. It's totally irresponsible.There is so much to talk about here. First of all, Biden admits upfront that the reason he thinks CDA 230 should be repealed is because of his personal dislike of Facebook's founder and CEO. It's one thing to argue that the platform creates harms and therefore we need a different regulatory approach, but to start out by saying you just don't like the guy, and use that as the basis for punishing the entire internet is... really something. Second, Biden seems to be (again) confusing the 1st Amendment with Section 230. It's not Section 230 that allows people to post false things on Facebook. It's the 1st Amendment. You know, the thing that Biden is supposed to "protect and defend" if he becomes President. Third, the comparison with the NY Times is completely offbase. The NY Times is also protected by Section 230 if a third party says something on its platform, they cannot be sued. And, similarly, if Facebook itself said something that violated the law, it can be sued. All 230 does is put the liability in the right place: on the actual speaker. Facebook is not "exempt" from any law. Biden is just wrong. Fourth, he's not even talking about reforming 230, he's talking about revoking it. That's insane and would lead to crippling litigation and vast silencing of the public. It's not even in the realm of reasonable discussion. Fifth, notice at casual he is about lumping in the rest of the internet, just because he dislikes Facebook. Take away 230 for the entire internet, even as it's what enabled free speech to really flourish on the internet. And, again, it's amazing how confused he is thinking that 230 is the issue when it's actually the 1st Amendment. Sixth, the point about "editors" is also completely nonsensical. Editors have nothing to do with it, unless he's saying that no one should be allowed to be posted on the internet unless it's been edited first. And just to be clear here, a lot of what Biden says in this interview is factually false. Yet, here, he's arguing that the NY Times should be liable for posting his falsehoods. And Facebook should be liable if people repost them there. And I should be liable because I'm posting his nonsense here. This is not someone who understand even the first thing about Section 230, how the internet works, or free speech online. He continued with more word salad:CW: If there's proven harm that Facebook has done, should someone like Mark Zuckerberg be submitted to criminal penalties, perhaps? He should be submitted to civil liability and his company to civil liability, just like you would be here at The New York Times. Whether he engaged in something and amounted to collusion that in fact caused harm that would in fact be equal to a criminal offense, that's a different issue. That's possible. That's possible it could happen. Zuckerberg finally took down those ads that Russia was running. All those bots about me. They're no longer being run. He was getting paid a lot of money to put them up. I learned three things. Number one, Putin doesn't want me to be president. Number two, Kim Jong-un thinks I should be beaten to death like a rabid dog and three, this president of the United States is spending millions of dollars to try to keep me from being the nominee. I wonder why.Civil liability for what? What exactly is the legal violation he's talking about? And notice, again, that he immediately resorts to a personal vendetta and stuff about Russia, ignoring that Facebook has a huge team constantly fighting and trying to take down Russian ads. Yet, Biden falsely states that Facebook was leaving them up to give Zuckerberg money. Does he not know how any of this works? Of course, then he more or less admits the reason he hates Silicon Valley is because they opposed him on SOPA/PIPA. If you don't recall, for years, Biden was one of Hollywood's biggest friends in the Senate. Even once he became VP, he convened a "summit" about copyright in which he only invited maximalists[3]. In the White House, he was the main voice pushing for SOPA/PIPA and apparently got quite upset when Obama eventually came out against the law. Here, he tries to rewrite history, pretending that SOPA/PIPA was just about "protecting" copyright and artists, when it was actually a massive tool for internet censorship -- and notice how he calls an internet exec "a little creep." He goes on to display near total ignorance and direct hatred for Silicon Valley and innovation.There are places where [President Obama] and I have disagreed. About 30 percent of the time, I was able to convince him to my side of the equation. Seventy percent of the time I wasn't when we disagreed, when he laid something out. And you may recall, the criticism I got for meeting with the leaders in Silicon Valley, when I was trying to work out an agreement dealing with them protecting intellectual property for artists in the United States of America. And at one point, one of the little creeps sitting around that table, who was a multi- — close to a billionaire — who told me he was an artist because he was able to come up with games to teach you how to kill people, you know the —— CW: Like video games. Yeah, video games. And I was lectured by one of the senior leaders there that by saying if I insisted on what Leahy'd put together and we were, I thought we were going to fully support, that they would blow up the network, figuratively speaking. Have everybody contact. They get out and go out and contact the switchboard, just blow it up. And then one of these righteous people said to me that, you know, 'We are the economic engine of America. We are the ones.' And fortunately I had done a little homework before I went and I said, you know, I find it fascinating. As I added up the seven outfits, everyone's there but Microsoft. I said, you have fewer people on your payroll than all the losses that General Motors just faced in the last quarter, of employees. So don't lecture me about how you've created all this employment. The point is, there's an arrogance about it, an overwhelming arrogance that we are, we are the ones. We can do what we want to do. I disagree. Every industrial revolution, every major technological breakthrough, every single one. We're in the fourth one. The hardest speech I've ever had to make in my life, I was asked to speak at the World Economic Forum, to give an answer on, to speak to the fourth industrial revolution. Will there be a middle class? It's not so clear there will be, and I've worked on it harder than any speech I've ever worked on. The fact is, in every other revolution that we've had technologically, it's taken somewhere between six years and a generation for a government to come in and level the playing field again. All of a sudden, remember the Luddites smashing the machinery in the Midlands? That was their answer when the culture was changing. Same thing with television. Same thing before that with radio. Same thing, but this is gigantic. And it's a responsibility of government to make sure it is not abused. Not abused. And so this is one of those areas where I think it's being abused. For example, the idea that he cooperates with knowing that Russia was engaged in dealing with using the internet, I mean using their platform, to try to undermine American elections. That's close to criminal.I can't even follow half of that word salad. It's nonsensical word spewing. The fact that the big tech companies don't employ so many people directly, completely misses the point that was being made: that the internet has enabled so many jobs around the world, not directly at those companies, but enabling so many people to start their own companies and businesses, and to create jobs at other companies because of the internet. Notice that Biden's world view is totally focused on how many jobs are created by single large companies. That's completely missing the point. And that final paragraph is just bizarre. He's suggesting government has to "level the playing field" with each new technological revolution. But he can't explain when or how they did that. When or how did they do that with the Luddites? When or how did they do that with TV? When or how did they do that with radio? What is he even talking about? At the end of this section he also insists that the internet is bad for children:Well the tech industry, look, not everyone in the tech industry is a bad guy, and I'm not suggesting that. What I'm suggesting is that some of the things that are going on are simply wrong and require government regulation. And it's happened every single time there's been a major technological breakthrough in humanities since the 1800s, and this requires it. For example, you have children? CW: No. Well, when you do and you'll watch them on the internet, it gets a little concerning. What in fact they can see and not see, and whether or not what they're seeing is true or not true. It matters. It matters. It's like — well, anyway.It's like -- well, anyway. Yeah. Look, there is false information on the internet. There is false information elsewhere. Hell, much of this interview with Biden is him spewing false information. Perhaps children shouldn't be allowed to read it. Or, perhaps, we teach our children how to be good information citizens, and teach them how to be skeptical and how to do more research. Perhaps, it's the job of parents and school teachers and other mentors to teach kids how to take in, filter, and understand information. Having politicians who don't know the first thing about the internet come in and tell them how to run things doesn't fix any of that. Indeed, it only makes the problem worse, by sweeping reality under the rug. Not that any of the candidates running for President seem particularly good on tech policy, but Biden's outright hatred for the internet, and "creeps" in Silicon Valley seems to have completely clouded his thinking.Permalink[4] | Comments[5] | Email This Story[6] [ 1]: https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20191112/10392843372/biden-spreads-false-info-saying-that-taking-away-section-230-will-make-facebook-liable-spreading-false-info.shtml [ 2]:   https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/17/opinion/joe-biden-nytimes-interview.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share [ 3]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20091215/0200387354.shtml [ 4]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20200117/09245943750/joe-biden-cant-tell-difference-between-1st-amendment-section-230-still-thinks-video-games-cause-violence.shtml [ 5]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20200117/09245943750/joe-biden-cant-tell-difference-between-1st-amendment-section-230-still-thinks-video-games-cause-violence.shtml#comments [ 6]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20200117/09245943750/joe-biden-cant-tell-difference-between-1st-amendment-section-230-still-thinks-video-games-cause-violence.shtml?op=sharethis
