It is called "Measure What Matters: How Google, Bono, and the Gates Foundation Rock the World with OKRs." He joins me now here in the studio.

John, welcome.

JOHN DOERR, CHAIRMAN, KLEINER PERKINS: Thank you.

CHANG: OKRs, Objectives and Key Results, this is a slideshow presentation you've been doing for many, many years, companies talk about it all the time like it's their religion. It is about setting objectives and key results. Ideas don't matter so much as execution.

DOERR: Executions, everything.

CHANG: What is so radical about this idea?

DOERR: Well, it is not practice in almost every company and what I mean by that is take one feature, just the notion that everybody in an organization would write down their goals and publish them and share them transparently, that's radical in most businesses or nonprofits. And that's just one of five things that set it apart.

CHANG: And you say that it's not just goals being set at the top, but employees sitting their own goal, right?

DOERR: Everyone transparently, top to bottom. So, when Larry and Sergey Google were 24 years old, I took them in this goal setting system. And I'd like to tell you that Sergey said, yes, John, we'll enthusiastically adopt this. The truth is, he said, we don't have any better way to manage the company's. So we'll give this one a try.

And Emily, every quarter since then, every Googler has written down her results and key results, publish them internally, graded them and then toss them aside because they don't count for bonuses, they don't count for promotions. They serve a higher purpose, a kind of collective calling and commitment to getting people focus in the line and tracking on stretching for the things that really matter the most.

CHANG: So you've presented this to Google, where you had just place your biggest butt of all time in 1999 $11.8 million for 12 percent of the company. And Larry Page who (ph) at the forward to your book and he called it a gift. So, I'm curious what would OKRs be for Google today? They are grappling with artificial intelligence, self-driving cars, fake news. There's a lot of change that's happening in the last two decades.

DOERR: Well, they have a very clear and crypt side of OKRs. And if I told you what they were, I'd be leaking. So, but everyone has them and this quarter, Sundar will stand up in front of 70,000 employees on a web cast and say these are our Googles objectives and key results and here are mine personally. And they won't get them all done. They'll maybe achieve 70 percent of them and that's considered a great, great.

CHANG: Now, one of the things you say about ORK is they're not a silver bullet. They don't take the place of values or culture.

DOERR: Or strong management.

CHANG: Exactly. And so --

DOERR: Can't substitute for those.

CHANG: How -- the book is called Measure What Matters, how do you measure something so intangible culture?

DOERR: Well, culture answers the question why. Objectives answer the question what, key results answer the question how. Your question to me was how do you measure culture? In fact, you do culture survey. You drop a definition of what your culture is and you periodically pulls your organization to say, do you feel we're not just saying but living up to these values with a transparency or aggressiveness or accountability. And I've seen this Emily, there's no one right culture. Every organization has its own and different ones can succeed in different ways.

CHANG: So, I want to ask you about Facebook and I know you're on the board of Google so you can't say so much about Google but you can opine about Facebook and incliner was an early investor. We've seen Facebook go through election meddling, also fake news problems, data privacy issues, data being mishandled. What would your ORKs be for Facebook? Or what would you recommend that they do in this situation?

DOERR: Well, it's a little hard being outside the organization to be prescriptive about that. So forgive me for saying that, but I think this is an incredibly well-run company with really good people in it. And I would expect that there are internal goals, I have no way of knowing this, to achieve a certain measure of growth and engagement together with, paired with, a measure of trust and user satisfaction. And the book talks about the importance of pairing goals.

You go all the way back to Lee Lacocca and the Pinto he had with an iron fist, goals to make the least expensive car he could. And the failure was, he didn't pair that with the goal in and around quality. So, for one of a part that cost less than a buck when someone ran into the back of a Pinto, the gas tank exploded, 100 people died, one of the largest recalls I ever had.

So, if you just let your goals be one-dimensional, you're going to miss the mark.

CHANG: You went to the White House, you met with President Trump. This as, you know, questions of tech regulation are looming, a potential trade war, what are your biggest concerns about sort of the economic and business consequences of this administration?

DOERR: So, I'm a red-blooded patriotic capitalist who believes in free markets, but also in putting a safety net in our economy. And I believe technology fundamentally advantages the rich, not the poor, and education is the counter bailing force that provides for upward mobility.

I've said then, I believe now that we should invest more in research and development, a lot more across the board that we should take data which has been bottled up and siloed and liberated, especially in the health care system. And this administration is moving very smartly on that front.

I'm a believer in free trade. I have differences with the administration on that, but I think this is a really good time for entrepreneurs to start new companies and to be working in the field of technology.

I do hold maybe the debatable view that every company, either is there is going to become a tech company. That you can't really compete in the new connected world without understanding what artificial intelligence or machine learning can mean to the products and services you offer your customers.

CHANG: What is your view on artificial intelligence? Elon Musk has said it's apocalyptic. We were just talking about that, it could be --

DOERR: It'll turn us all in the house pets.

CHANG: Absolutely. I mean, that is certainly one view, could it get that dark?

DOERR: I don't think so. But I want to put it in context. It seems every dozen years or so there is Tsunami like transformation to the innovation economy. Starting in 1980, it was the microchip in the P.C. right. That takes us forward to about one dozen years, '93, '94, the next big wave was the web browser.

Remember Mosaic and that's keep (ph) on all those internet companies including all the way up to and through Google. Then in 2006, Steve jobs introduced the iPhone. And at the same time, the cloud came along. So, that was the third great wave to right about today.

So, fair question is what is it now John? And I think this field has been overhyped, but now I think it's underappreciated, and that field is artificial intelligence. Its programs that learn as they go along, its deep reinforcement learning, neural networks that mimic in some ways the ways humans think. And the effects of this are going to be profound. We can't have self-driving cars without artificial intelligence.

What we can do with health care is incredibly exciting to me. Right now, you can take an image of a retina and not only predict the likelihood that that person will develop diabetes, but also the likelihood of hard incident in advance and you can apply artificial intelligence today to all kinds of imaging in health care and get better diagnosis that humans can give. We're just getting started.

CHANG: As our lives become more tech infused, do you worry about tech addiction or the negative impact of technology? I mean Chamath Palihapitiya who worked at Facebook for a long time has talked about the guilt he feels and how he believes it -- Facebook could be destroying the very fabric of our society.

DOERR: Yes. But good parenting can deal with this handedly. When my girls were growing up, I had a personal objective to have a healthy family and a key result that's --

CHANG: Right. And OKRs can be applied to family life as you talk about in the book.

DOERR: In fact, before we end I want to talk about that. But my key result was to get home from dinner 20 nights a month by 6:00 p.m., and the period quality result was to be fully present.

So, I pulled the plug on the router. Nobody could get anything on the internet. And, you know, I got that it was hard. I got it done maybe 70 percent of the time which was a pretty good grade.

CHANG: So, you're not worried?

DOERR: No.

CHANG: About the negative potential of all of these amazing things that are -- that you've done.

DOERR: Not when there's at least one and preferably two diligent parents in a household. I do think we want to be concerned about the families and kids or that's not the case.

CHANG: Let's talk about leadership, you know, I mentioned Elon Musk, he's obviously going through production issues at Tesla. There was just an analyst call where he referred to questions as boring and bone headed. He's got another company, SpaceX. Id t know, what would you recommend to a leader in that position running two really companies that are really pushing the limits of technology?

DOERR: Well, the same thing I recommend to others disruptive entrepreneurs. I mean make sure you have a strategic focus on a large unserved market need. Bring to it a proprietary technology and a commitment to assemble an outstanding management team, raise of reasonable amount of money. You can raise too much money as well as too little. Above all, never lose your sense of urgency which allows Tesla to move far faster than the rest of the automotive players. And I recommend you use objectives and key results.

CHANG: All right. John Doerr, we are going to continue this conversation.

Coming up, more of our exclusive conversation with John Doerr, Chairman of Kleiner Perk, and including his thoughts on a road map to diversity using OKRs and the best opportunities in D.C. right now.

(BREAK)

CHANG: This is "Bloomberg Technology", I'm Emily Chang in San Francisco. Over the course of his career, Kleiner Perkins chair John Doerr has pretty much seen it all, making early investments in Google, Amazon, and Facebook. His popularized a management philosophy, objectives and key results with top tech companies. And now, we're going to apply that to something else, techs massive diversity problem, John Doerr with me here now.

I do want to mention, you say this is much more than a book. In fact, it's a handbook.

DOERR: I'd like to say it's a handbook. It's not a business book. Because it's full of dozens of stories of real entrepreneurs and leaders, struggling, succeeding to set goals that matter. But my hope is that this isn't just for businesses. I think we can take OKR's certainly to our nonprofits, but even to our families, our schools, and our government.

We're really at a critical moment in time where I think many of our leaders and some of our great institutions have failed us.

CHANG: What should Trump's OKR's be?

DOERR: I don't know. I haven't given that thought. I mean, that's a really very good question. But I would imagine they're grow the economy, have the country be respected in and around the world. His objective would probably be "Make America Great Again" right?

The objectives are very important to get, so too are the key results. And so I can see us using -- well, let me say this. Sylvia Mathews Burwell used OKRs to manage the Ebola crisis. Government is to be transparent and accountable. So, why not have a city council adopt the system of goal setting? I think we can and we must measure what really matters.

CHANG: So, let's talk about diversity in Silicon Valley because we are increasingly holding Silicon Valley to account when it comes to diversity, and I know that you are very aware of this problem. You know, as you're advising young companies, how do you tell them how to approach setting goals and results for something that is so important but so easily is lost sight of?

DOERR: So, the first thing I ask them to do is answer the question why. The answer to the question why we do this work, why we're on this is all important. And it'll reflect and be expressed in both our values and a mission statement.

And you ought to have a powerful, inspiring mission. Because that's going to help you get the people together to do it. Something like organize all the world's information and make it available to everybody for free anywhere at any time. That's pretty timeless something like connect everybody in the world.

So, you've got to get the mission and the values right, and then this goal system, these objectives and key results. I think of those as kind of transparent vessels, the what and how into which we pour these values.

Because it's very clear that the transformational teams have managed to combine passion with purpose in a way that says they clearly know how to answer the question why we do the work that matters the most.

CHANG: So, I just wrote a story in "Business Week" with my colleagues challenging Amazon to build its new headquarters -- they're starting from scratch , 50,000 new workers to shoot for 50/50. Is that a fair proposal?

DOERR: I think that's a great goal. And not so much for social equality or for social progress, but because we know that diverse groups make better business decisions. The data shows it. And so, you know, until we, the tech industry, the venture industry and Kleiner Perkins, get to a 50/50 world that reflects the customers we're trying to serve the society we work in, we're making less good decisions.

CHANG: So, I have to ask you about your reflections on Ellen Powell in light of the MeToo movement and obviously, you know, she sued your firm for a gender discrimination, lost in court, but public opinion maybe had mixed feelings. In this new world as we have this national conversation, what are your sort of reflections on that?

DOERR: So, it's hard to add much to what's been said or written, or in fact you and I have discussed before about Ellen Powell. I'm human. The whole situation made me very sad, I think she's doing goof work now and I really do wish her well.

I think the more important -- sorry, not the more important question. I think the other dimension to this is I and we should have zero tolerance for a workplace that makes anyone in that workplace uncomfortable. And on the particular question of diversity, I think you know, we've been a leader in this field and we don't think we've gone far enough.

So, there's three areas in which I've been fighting really hard to make more progress at Kleiner. One of which is in our own people, our partnership, the second is out portfolio and then the third is the pipeline.

In our own partnership, 21 percent of our investing professionals are female. The average for the venture industry is pathetic. It's nine percent as you know. Within our portfolio, nine percent of our CEOs are founders are female, the average in the tech industry is 2.7 percent. That's outrageous.

And with respect to the pipeline in 20 -- I guess it was in 2015, 10 percent of the participants in Kleiner fellows program which is harder to get into then are getting the harder for a female. This year, it's 50-50 and 11 percent of them are African-American.

So, I'm not satisfied with where we are. I think we all have to do more, but we just have to put women and minorities in positions of power if we're going to right this wrong.

CHANG: So, you've brought in some new blood, Mamoon Hamid joined the firm.

DOERR: Ilya Fushman.

CHANG: Ilya.

DOERR: We've got a wonderful in town.

CHANG: We've heard he sort of your era parent, Mamoon is. Talk to us a little bit about the transition that's to come and how you expect the firm to change over the next few years.

DOERR: Sure. So Kleiner's in very good shape. I'm really excited about it. One of my key results when I took on this new role is to help the team attract and grow more talent. It's important to note though that Kleiner ha always been in transition.

Since I joined in 1980, we had partners who were in there 60s, 50s, 40s, and 30s. And so, I've had kind of an outsized presence maybe externally. But this is a very natural process that I think is going well.

CHANG: Where do you see the biggest opportunities indenture capital right now? Crypto? More in buffet just called in rap poisoned squared if that's any context.

DOERR: Sure. And I think Charlie Munger said he was transferring thirds.

CHANG: Right. Do you think that coin is a good investment or crypto in general?

DOERR: I think that blockchain is a very powerful new technology. It's not as bigger deal as mobility when I talk about these Tsunamis. And I don't think it's as big as A.I. But we've invested both in blockchain and the use of blockchain to facilitate international and cross boarder transactions.

I'd love to see blockchain applied in a powerful way to the healthcare system. So that you have fine grain control over where do you have -- where your health information goes. So that you can automatically at any time have a longitudinal record of all your healthcare experiences.

CHANG: What else? What's next?

DOERR: We invested in NICO, we'll --

CHANG: But in tech more broadly. I mean where do you see the opportunities in the next ten years?

DOERR: I think there are, you know, artificial intelligence. I remain convinced that selectively they are in the areas of innovations around energy and energy technologies. I'd -- I'm quite convinced we'll see a lot more disruption in systems for enterprises.

I want to say this though. The big tech giants especially those with strong positions in consumer markets, they're a lot more competitive than their predecessors were. And so, I think it's harder to start a new consumer internet based metric.

CHANG: All right, John Doerr, Chair of Kleiner Perkins out with a new book "Measure What Matters" or handbook did you say?

DOERR: A new handbook it's whatmatters.com.

CHANG: All right. Thank you so much John for joining us, great to have you.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5P55-3CH1-F15W-H0MY-00000-00JOHN MANLEY, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ASSET MANAGEMENT, ON BLOOMBERG RADIO REGARDING EARNINGS AND MARKETS2017-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:08ZLexisNexisJOHN MANLEY, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ASSET MANAGEMENT, ON BLOOMBERG RADIO REGARDING EARNINGS AND MARKETS

July 31, 2017

NEWS PROGRAM

JOHN MANLEY, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ASSET MANAGEMENT,

GURA: John Manley joins us now here in our Bloomberg 1130 studio. He's the Chief Equity Strategist at Wells Fargo Funds. And, John, great to have you with us here in the middle of earning seasons, squarely in the middle of the second quarter earning season.

Let's take stock of where we are as the big tech companies reporting last week, some financial companies reporting as well. Just give us the lay of the land as you see it as these results to continue to come in.

MANLEY: All the way from benign to good. I think the numbers are coming in pretty well. The revenue numbers are starting to surprise, which is sort of interesting. And this is giving large to something that a lot of people thought that profits were so high, they couldn't go higher even if the economy got better.

Well, the revenues, Tom, we were seeing a better economy and the profit numbers are just what they. They're saying things are getting better.

LACQUA: Yes. But, John, at the same, a lot of these aren't cost cuts. I know the revenue is a strong kind of indication that things are getting better. But what if we were loved in a false sense of security because it's all cost cuts and not actual growth?

MANLEY: Any sense of security in the stock market is a false sense of security. Of course, we have done this long this long enough. But ultimately, it will prove me false.

However, what you're seeing are just early stages. Ideally, what corporation should do is make themselves into very, very efficient machines. And that's what they've done. And then build it that way and the economy will come. This is the United States over here. We still have -- I wouldn't call pens up to me. We have natural exam.

People came to the United States. Our ancestors came from the United States to have more. We're willing to work for it in most cases. And I think what happens is we put the problems 10 years ago further and further behind us. And yes, a little bit of stimulation from the fed. You get yourself a pretty decent economy. And if that happens that just poured over an efficient machine, I mean, profits come out of it.

LACQUA: Is it really only a little bit of stimulus from the fed? What happens if they actually move too quickly? I mean, they telegraphed, right, that they are starting to normalize. But what happens if companies are not ready for it?

MANLEY: They'll stop -- they'll stop doing it. One of the things that I have a chat (ph), you know, says a few weeks ago was that she gets -- she's aware. She knows there's a risk in stimulating too quickly or not stimulating enough. She knows there's a risk in how they unwind the balance sheet. She knows the risk of inflation. She knows the risk of deflation.

Now, she may not know exactly the road or the path to follow down on the way to recovery, but she knows to look for any misstep on her part. Anything she's done that possibly could derail. So, I guess what I can say about Janet Yellen is sure, she may be wrong but she won't be wrong for long and that's really what matters to the markets.

GURA: John, what's your sense of the degree to which this Fed Reserve, this Federal Open Market Committee is paying attention to the market? How big a concern is that for them?

MANLEY: I think they read the papers and, obviously, they listen to some very good radio broadcast from time to time. They have to be aware. I mean, you know, it's like asking your doctor did he read the thermometer after he test you.

We're pretty didn't care to what's going on. We're not perfect. We bounce around in awful lot. But we're pretty good in here.

And now, I think it's also important to remember, the fed and the capital markets and the economy are linked, because when the fed wants to push money at the economy, it goes through us first. So then let's think of it as a pipe carrying out, in or out of the economy. They sort of look at us, they get an obvious sign as money headed the right direction And, you know, they see a meltdown in stock market a little bit, they know that's can't be good for the rest of the real world.

The same thing is true for housing and a few others things. Look at what wealth is doing. If wealth is being created or at least maintained, they've got to feel reasonably comfortable.

GURA: And look at the soft data, you look the surveys, how businesses feel, their willingness to hire, their willingness to expand. And it seems like there is still a gap between the soft data and the hard data.

As you look at these earnings reports, what's the sense that you have of when the two are going to meet? Where we're going to see companies try to invest more in CAPEX?

MANLEY: I think you're starting to see -- I think what you have to realize too is that when -- it probably happen quickly because we're still on a fairly competitive landscape. And so far, it's been better for corporations who are competing against other corporations to buyback shares, to reinvest in their businesses by buying into their businesses. That doesn't have capacity obviously.

But at some point in time, it's not because the companies want to do it, it's because their consumers are demanding more of their products. If you and I are competing and I see you beginning to pick up share because you expand a little bit, watch out quickly, I would start my CAPEX of them.

LACQUA: John, are market merger is good for evaluations or bad?

MANLEY: Well, it depends on merger it has.

LACQUA: I know, in the industry, but -- because, you know, in general, just full of desperation.

MANLEY: I think that merge is to create synergy without being tremendously destructive to jobs, to create more efficient, more logical corporations are generally good. You don't want restraining the trade. I don't want restraining the trade. You do want efficiencies. You do want logical structures to a degree they foster that, I think it's fine. You just always keep your eyes open. There's nothing wrong with regulation. It's just got to be done, you know, a fair, even-handed way.

LACQUA: John, you know, we went into 2017, looking at Brexit, looking at President Trump. And there was this wave of anti-populism of -- or populism anti-globalization. Should that do anything to stock markets?

MANLEY: Well, it hasn't. I mean, there's an old saying, expect the worse and you'll never be disappointed. And the things to market has not been disappointed this year.

People talk about the lack of downside volatility. The only explanation for that is there have been non-negative surprises or any consequence. Well, so many negative things that come out of Washington or (inaudible) or even Berlin or Paris, how can one say there aren't negative surprises? Of course, there are negative.

Well, the thing is it's not a surprise. I think investors have a fairly low expectation, maybe a very low expectation of what comes out of Washington or Berlin or Britain. And I think in that respect, it's going to be pretty hard to disappoint us.]

GURA: Let me ask about financials in particular. A number of banks have reported already. How enthusiastic are you about financial stocks at this point? And how radically have they sort of trigged around from where we're a few years back?

MANLEY: Well, 40 years ago, I made choices from my life amongst them, so --

GURA: Yes.

MANLEY: -- we're very intimate with financial stocks and financial corporations and all the big -- it can be the best business and the worst business in the world. And believe me, I've seen both.

I think what you have to look for is reasonable regulation. There is no way that banks or financial institutions should be wide open. On the other hand, regulation go too far. You look for just the amount of regulation that seems to be moving in the right direction.

Interest rates also have corporations when they're facing very, very low rates, have a very difficult time placing fees on things that should have fees on them. If that's the case, their earnings power is being starved. Higher rates to a degree, it doesn't represent real fed tightening allows financial corporations to charge those fees, right adjustable fees that tends to improve their profitability. I think that part still in front of them.

GURA: Let me ask you how much personality matters. We spent some time this morning on television talking about Stuart Gulliver who is outgoing head of HSBC. You look at who's heading up these banks now. You can say few more years left and a lot of these guys who are running these banks. And how worried are you about transition? How much do you associate performances, the big bangs in particular with the men, largely men who are running those companies?

MANLEY: That's really good question. I don't know the straight answer I can give you. I think a character. When I invest my money over the long term, I know I can't possibly know what's going to happen in 5, 10 years. But I can look at the corporate culture, I guess that's where giving else. A good corporate culture should have depth, strong managers, truly strong managers, shouldn't be afraid of having people alongside them from replacing. That's the whole idea.

And I think that's a good way to buy stocks. You might want to find a good industry. But find a good industry that's being run by good men and women, who bring up good men and women internally. And I think you have -- it could be a fair of good investment.

LACQUA: And so, you have that in financials done or are you just talking about another industry?

MANLEY: We're talking industries in general and some financials --

LACQUA: Right.

MANLEY: I'm not assuming bad that I don't believe you.

LACQUA: OK. So which industries do you think are doing better in terms of succession but also, you know, having fewer legacy issues?

MANLEY: Well, the fundamentals were -- I think the fundamentals will come through. I think health care is a great sort of hard (ph) parts had collision between an Asian population like myself, improving health care, technology, and representative markers that can vote the money towards the people who need it.

I think technology, which we've been talking about, business to business technology, I think you're going to see wage pressures in the next few years. And the only way to cheapskates around corporations are going to let that go through is that they can prove productivity somehow, and that means spending on technology.

We mentioned financials, and for sure down in our value, I still think, well it was pretty good place to be. I'm focused on the big high quality large paying dividend stocks in the oil industry.

LACQUA: And those are mainly, which ones?

MANLEY: Well, I can't name them.
